What does a conditional knowledge base entail? â€ â€ thanks: This work was partially supported by grant 351/89 from the Basic Research Foundation, Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities and by the Jean and Helene Alfassa fund for research in Artificial Intelligence. Its final version was prepared while the first author was visiting the Laboratoire dâ€™Informatique ThÃ©orique et de Programmation, Univ. Paris 6

Daniel Lehmann Department of Computer Science, Hebrew University, Jerusalem 91904 (Israel) â€ƒâ€ƒ Menachem Magidor Department of Mathematics, Hebrew University, Jerusalem 91904 (Israel)
Abstract

This paper presents a logical approach to nonmonotonic reasoning based on the notion of a nonmonotonic consequence relation. A conditional knowledge base, consisting of a set of conditional assertions of the type if â€¦then â€¦, represents the explicit defeasible knowledge an agent has about the way the world generally behaves. We look for a plausible definition of the set of all conditional assertions entailed by a conditional knowledge base. In a previous paperÂ [17], S. Kraus and the authors defined and studied preferential consequence relations. They noticed that not all preferential relations could be considered as reasonable inference procedures. This paper studies a more restricted class of consequence relations, rational relations. It is argued that any reasonable nonmonotonic inference procedure should define a rational relation. It is shown that the rational relations are exactly those that may be represented by a ranked preferential model, or by a (non-standard) probabilistic model. The rational closure of a conditional knowledge base is defined and shown to provide an attractive answer to the question of the title. Global properties of this closure operation are proved: it is a cumulative operation. It is also computationally tractable. This paper assumes the underlying language is propositional.

1 Introduction

1.1 Background

Inference is the process of achieving explicit information that was only implicit in the agentâ€™s knowledge. Human beings are astoundingly good at infering useful and very often reliable information from knowledge that seems mostly irrelevant, sometimes erroneous and even self-contradictory. They are even better at correcting inferences they learn to be in contradiction with reality. It is already a decade now that Artificial Intelligence has realized that the analysis of models of such inferences was a major task.

Many nonmonotonic systems have been proposed as formal models of this kind of inferences. The best known are probably: circumscription [22], the modal systems of [23] and [24], default logic [29] and negation as failure [5]. An up-to-date survey of the field of nonmonotonic reasoning may be found in [30]. Though each of these systems is interesting per se, it is not clear that any one of them really captures the whole generality of nonmonotonic reasoning. Recently (see in particular the panel discussion of [36]) a number of researchers expressed their disappointment at existing systems and suggested that no purely logical analysis could be satisfactory.

This work tries to contradict this pessimistic outlook. It takes a purely logical approach, grounded in A.Â Tarskiâ€™s framework of consequence relations [35] and studies the very general notion of a sensible conclusion. It seems that this is a common ground that can be widely accepted: all reasonable inference systems draw only sensible conclusions. On the other hand, as will be shown, the notion of a sensible conclusion has a non-trivial mathematical theory and many interesting properties are shared by all ways of drawing sensible conclusions.

The reader is referred toÂ [17] for a full description of background, motivation and the relationship of the present approach with previous work in Conditional Logic. We only wish to add here that, even though the present work will be compared explicitly only with previous work of E.Â Adams, some of the intuitions developed here are related with intuitions exposed already in the first works on Conditional Logic, such asÂ [28] orÂ [4]. The interested reader may find many relevant articles inÂ [15] and should in particular look atÂ [14]. The main difference between our approach and Conditional Logic is that we take the view that the truth of a conditional assertion is necessary, i.e., does not depend on the state of the world. For us, worlds give truth values to propositions but not to assertions, preferential models give truth values to assertions, but not to propositions. The models we propose are therefore much simpler than those previously proposed in Conditional Logic and it is doubtful whether they can shed light on the very complex questions of interest to the Conditional Logic community.

Notations and terminology conform with those ofÂ [17], but the present paper is essentially self-contained. Preliminary versions of part of the material contained in this paper appeared inÂ [19, 18]. InÂ [17] it was suggested that items of default, i.e., defeasible information should be represented as conditional assertions, i.e., pairs of formulas. For example, the information that birds normally fly will be represented by the conditional assertion bğ‘bitalic_b Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ fğ‘“fitalic_f, where bğ‘bitalic_b and fğ‘“fitalic_f are propositional variables representing being a bird and flying respectively. A set (finite or infinite) of conditional assertions is called a conditional knowledge base (knowledge base, in short) and represents the defeasible knowledge an agent may have. The fundamental question studied in this paper is the following: given a knowledge base K, what are the conditional assertions that should be considered as entailed, i.e., logically implied, by K? We consider that an assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â should be entailed by KÂ if, on the basis of the defeasible information contained in KÂ and knowing that the proposition Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is true, it would be sensible to conclude (defeasibly) that Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is true.

The question asked in the title and detailed just above has no simple answer and has probably no unique answer good for everyone in every situation. It may well be the case that, in different situations or for different domains of knowledge, the pragmatically right answers to the question of the title differ. This feeling has been recently expressed inÂ [9]. The first part of this paper defines the notion of a rational set of assertions and defends the thesis that any reasonable answer to the question of the title must consist of such a set of assertions.

Thesis 1

The set of assertions entailed by any set of assertions is rational.

The second part of the paper describes a specific construction, rational closure, and shows that the rational closure of a set of assertions is rational. This construction is then studied and its value as an answer to the question of the title assessed. We think that, in many situations, this is an acceptable answer, but do not claim that it provides an answer suitable to any situation. We have just argued that such an answer probably does not exist. One of the main interests of the rational closure construction is that it provides a proof of the existence of some uniform, well-behaved and elegant way of answering the question. In doing so, we develop criteria by which to judge possible answers. We shall in particular consider properties of the mapping from KÂ to the set of all the assertions it entails and prove that our construction of the rational closure satisfies them. This effort and these results have to be compared with the essential absence, for the moment, of similar results about the systems of nonmonotonic reasoning mentioned above.

1.2 Plan of this paper

We survey here the main parts of this paper. The introductions to the different sections contain a detailed description. SectionÂ 2 is devoted to preferential consequence relations. This family of relations was defined and studied inÂ [17]. The first part of this section mainly recalls definitions and results ofÂ [17], its last part presents deep new technical results on preferential entailment that will be used in the sequel, but it may be skipped on a first reading. SectionÂ 3 presents the restricted family of relations that is of interest to us: rational relations. This family was first defined, but not studied, inÂ [17, Section 5.4]. The main result of this section is a representation theorem characterizing rational relations in terms of ranked models. SectionÂ 4 shows that entailment with respect to ranked models is exactly entailment with respect to preferential models and provides an alternative proof of E.Â Adamsâ€™Â [1] characterization of preferential entailment in terms of his probabilistic semantics. AppendixÂ B describes a family of models based on non-standard (in the sense of A.Â Robinson) probability models and shows that these models provide another exact representation for rational consequence relations. This provides us with a strong justification for considering rational relations. SectionÂ 5 draws on all previous sections and is the heart of this paper. It proposes an answer to the question of the title. The notion of rational closure is first defined abstractly and global properties proved. It is then showed that finite knowledge bases have a rational closure and a model-theoretic construction is provided. An efficient algorithm is proposed for computing the rational closure of a finite knowledge base. We then discuss some examples, remark that rational closure does not provide for inheritance of generic properties to exceptional classes, and finally propose a second thesis.

2 Preferential relations and models

2.1 Introduction

The first part of this section, i.e., SectionsÂ 2.2â€“2.3, recalls definitions and results ofÂ [17] and provides an example (new) of a preferential relation that cannot be defined by a well-founded model. Then, in SectionÂ 2.4, the definition and some properties of preferential entailment are recalled fromÂ [17] and some new remarks included. Preferential entailment is a fundamental notion that is used throughout the paper. The last three sections are essentially independent of each other. They present an in-depth study of preferential entailment. In a first reading, they should probably be read only cursorily. The results of SectionÂ 2.5 expand on part ofÂ [18] and are used in SectionÂ 4.2. SectionÂ 2.6 presents a new technique to study preferential entailment (i.e., ranking). It is fundamental from SectionÂ 5.6 and onwards. SectionÂ 2.7 shows that preferential entailment is in the class co-NP, and hence is an co-NP-complete problem. A preliminary version of this last result appeared inÂ [18].

2.2 Preferential relations

Our first step must be to define a language in which to express the basic propositions. In this paper Propositional Calculus is chosen. Let â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L be the set of well formed propositional formulas (thereafter formulas) over a set of propositional variables. If the set of propositional variables chosen is finite, we shall say that â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is logically finite. The classical propositional connectives will be denoted by Â¬,âˆ¨,âˆ§,â†’â†’\neg,\vee,\wedge,\rightarrowÂ¬ , âˆ¨ , âˆ§ , â†’ and â†”â†”\leftrightarrowâ†”. The connective â†’â†’\rightarrowâ†’ therefore denotes material implication. Small Greek letters will be used to denote formulas.

A world is an assignment of truth values to the propositional variables. The set ğ’°ğ’°{\cal U}caligraphic_U is the set of all worlds. The satisfaction of a formula by a world is defined as usual. The notions of satisfaction of a set of formulas, validity of a formula and satisfiability of a set of formulas are defined as usual. We shall write âŠ§Î±modelsabsentğ›¼\models\alphaâŠ§ italic_Î± if Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is valid, i.e., iff âˆ€uâˆˆğ’°for-allğ‘¢ğ’°\forall u\in{\cal U}âˆ€ italic_u âˆˆ caligraphic_U, uâŠ§Î±modelsğ‘¢ğ›¼u\models\alphaitalic_u âŠ§ italic_Î±.

If Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± and Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² are formulas then the pair Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î²ğ›¼Â âˆ¼Â ğ›½\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î² (read â€œfrom Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± sensibly concludeÂ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²â€) is called a conditional assertion. A conditional assertion is a syntactic object to which the reader may attach any meaning he wants, but the meaning we attach to such an assertion, and against which the reader should check the logical systems to be presented in the upcoming sections, is the following: if Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± represents the information I have about the true state of the world, I will jump to the conclusion that Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² is true. A conditional knowledge base is any set of conditional assertions. Typically it is a finite set, but need not be so. Conditional knowledge bases seem to provide a terse and versatile way of specifying defeasible information. They correspond to the explicit information an agent may have.

Certain well-behaved sets of conditional assertions will be deemed worthy of being called consequence relations. We shall use the notation usual for binary relations to describe consequence relations. So, if Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ is a consequence relation, Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î²ğ›¼Â âˆ¼Â ğ›½\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î² indicates that the pair âŸ¨Î±,Î²âŸ©ğ›¼ğ›½\langle\alpha,\beta\rangleâŸ¨ italic_Î± , italic_Î² âŸ© is in the consequence relation Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ and Î±â¢Â Â âˆ¼Ì¸Â â¢Î²ğ›¼Â Â âˆ¼Ì¸Â ğ›½\alpha\mbox{ $\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim$ }\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¼Ì¸ italic_Î² indicates it is not in the relation. Consequence relations correspond to the implicit information an intelligent agent may have. Consequence relations are typically infinite sets.

Certain especially interesting properties of sets of conditional assertions (i.e., binary relations on â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L) will be described and discussed now. They are presented in the form of inference rules. Consequence relations are expected to satisfy those properties.

âŠ§Î±â†”Î²,Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î³Î²â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î³(ğ‹ğğŸğ­â¢ğ‹ğ¨ğ ğ¢ğœğšğ¥â¢ğ„ğªğ®ğ¢ğ¯ğšğ¥ğğ§ğœğ){{\models\alpha\leftrightarrow\beta\ \ ,\ \ \alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}\over{\beta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}}\hskip 15.6491pt{\rm({\bf Left\ Logical\ Equivalence})}divide start_ARG âŠ§ italic_Î± â†” italic_Î² , italic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î² âˆ¼ italic_Î³ end_ARG ( bold_Left bold_Logical bold_Equivalence ) (1)
âŠ§Î±â†’Î²,Î³Â âˆ¼Â Î±Î³â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î²(ğ‘ğ¢ğ ğ¡ğ­â¢ğ–ğğšğ¤ğğ§ğ¢ğ§ğ ){{\models\alpha\rightarrow\beta\ \ ,\ \ \gamma\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\alpha}\over{\gamma\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\beta}}\hskip 17.07182pt{\rm({\bf Right\ Weakening})}divide start_ARG âŠ§ italic_Î± â†’ italic_Î² , italic_Î³ âˆ¼ italic_Î± end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ âˆ¼ italic_Î² end_ARG ( bold_Right bold_Weakening ) (2)

Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î²,Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î³Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î²âˆ§Î³(ğ€ğ§ğ){{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\beta\ \ ,\ \ \alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}\ \ \ \over{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\beta\wedge\gamma}}\hskip 22.76228pt{\rm({\bf And})}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î² , italic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î² âˆ§ italic_Î³ end_ARG ( bold_And ) (4)
Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î³,Î²Â âˆ¼Â Î³Î±âˆ¨Î²â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î³(ğğ«){{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma\ \ ,\ \ \beta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}\over{\alpha\vee\beta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}}\hskip 32.72049pt{\rm({\bf Or})}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î³ , italic_Î² âˆ¼ italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² âˆ¼ italic_Î³ end_ARG ( bold_Or ) (5)
Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î²,Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î³Î±âˆ§Î²â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î³(ğ‚ğšğ®ğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ®ğ¬â¢ğŒğ¨ğ§ğ¨ğ­ğ¨ğ§ğ¢ğœğ¢ğ­ğ²){{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\beta\ \ ,\ \ \alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}\over{\alpha\wedge\beta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}}\hskip 32.72049pt{\rm({\bf Cautious\ Monotonicity})}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î² , italic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² âˆ¼ italic_Î³ end_ARG ( bold_Cautious bold_Monotonicity ) (6)
Definition 1

A set of conditional assertions that satisfies all six properties above is called a preferential consequence relation.

A more leisurely introduction with motivation may be found inÂ [17] where a larger family of consequence relations, that of cumulative relations, was also studied. This family is closely related to the cumulative inference operations studied by D.Â Makinson in [21]. The attentive reader ofÂ [17] may have noticed that, there, we reserved ourselves an additional degree of freedom, that we have denied ourselves here. There, we allowed ğ’°ğ’°{\cal U}caligraphic_UÂ to be a subset of the set of all worlds and considered the âŠ§models\modelsâŠ§ symbol appearing in Left Logical Equivalence and in Right Weakening to be interpreted relatively to this subset. This was felt necessary to deal with hard constraints. In this work, we shall suppose that a hard constraint Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is interpreted as the soft constraint, i.e., the assertion, Â¬â¢Î±ğ›¼\neg\alphaÂ¬ italic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false, which was recognized as equivalent to considering ğ’°ğ’°{\cal U}caligraphic_UÂ to be the set of all worlds satisfying Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â inÂ [17, page 174]. The second proposal there, i.e., to consider Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â to be part of the facts, would not be consistent with our treatment of rational closure.

For the readerâ€™s ease of mind we shall mention two important derived rules. Both S and Cut are satisfied by any preferential relation.

Î±âˆ§Î²â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î³Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î²â†’Î³(ğ’)ğ›¼ğ›½Â âˆ¼Â ğ›¾â†’ğ›¼Â âˆ¼Â ğ›½ğ›¾ğ’{{\alpha\wedge\beta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma}\over{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\>\beta\rightarrow\gamma}}\hskip 62.59596pt{\rm({\bf S})}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² âˆ¼ italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î² â†’ italic_Î³ end_ARG ( bold_S ) (7)
Î±âˆ§Î²Â âˆ¼Â Î³,Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î²Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î³(ğ‚ğ®ğ­){{\alpha\wedge\beta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma\ \ ,\ \ \alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\beta}\over{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma\;}}\hskip 22.76228pt{\rm({\bf Cut})}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² âˆ¼ italic_Î³ , italic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î² end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î³ end_ARG ( bold_Cut ) (8)

The rule of Cut is presented here in a form that is not the most usual one. Notice, in particular, that we require the left-hand side of the second assumption to be part of the left-hand side of the first assumption. This version of Cut is close to the original form proposed by G.Â Gentzen. The following form, more usually used now, is not acceptable since it implies monotonicity.

Î±âˆ§Î²Â âˆ¼Â Î³,Î±â€²Â âˆ¼Â Î²Î±âˆ§Î±â€²â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î³{{\alpha\wedge\beta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma\ \ ,\ \ \alpha^{\prime}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\beta}\over{\alpha\wedge\alpha^{\prime}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gamma\;}}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² âˆ¼ italic_Î³ , italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Î² end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Î³ end_ARG (9)

2.3 Preferential models and representation theorem

The following definitions are also taken fromÂ [17] and justified there. We shall define a class of models that we call preferential since they represent a slight variation on those proposed in [33]. The differences are nevertheless technically important.

Preferential models give a model-theoretic account of the way one performs nonmonotonic inferences. The main idea is that the agent has, in his mind, a partial ordering on possible states of the world. State sğ‘ sitalic_s is less than state tğ‘¡titalic_t, if, in the agentâ€™s mind, sğ‘ sitalic_s is preferred to or more natural than tğ‘¡titalic_t. The agent is willing to conclude Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² from Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, if all most natural states that satisfy Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± also satisfy Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î².

Some technical definitions are needed. Let Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U be a set and â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º a strict partial order on Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U, i.e., a binary relation that is antireflexive and transitive.

Definition 2

Let VâŠ†Uğ‘‰ğ‘ˆV\subseteq Uitalic_V âŠ† italic_U. We shall say that tâˆˆVğ‘¡ğ‘‰t\in Vitalic_t âˆˆ italic_V is minimal in Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V iff there is no sâˆˆVğ‘ ğ‘‰s\in Vitalic_s âˆˆ italic_V, such that sâ‰ºtprecedesğ‘ ğ‘¡s\prec titalic_s â‰º italic_t. We shall say that tâˆˆVğ‘¡ğ‘‰t\in Vitalic_t âˆˆ italic_V is a minimum of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V iff for every sâˆˆV,sâ‰ tformulae-sequenceğ‘ ğ‘‰ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\in V,s\neq titalic_s âˆˆ italic_V , italic_s â‰  italic_t, we have tâ‰ºsprecedesğ‘¡ğ‘ t\prec sitalic_t â‰º italic_s.

Definition 3

Let VâŠ†Uğ‘‰ğ‘ˆV\subseteq Uitalic_V âŠ† italic_U. We shall say that Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V is smooth iff Â âˆ€tâˆˆVfor-allğ‘¡ğ‘‰\forall t\in Vâˆ€ italic_t âˆˆ italic_V, either âˆƒsğ‘ \exists sâˆƒ italic_s minimal in Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V, such that sâ‰ºtprecedesğ‘ ğ‘¡s\prec titalic_s â‰º italic_t or tğ‘¡titalic_t is itself minimal in Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V.

We may now define the family of models we are interested in.

Definition 4

A preferential model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is a triple âŸ¨S,l,â‰ºâŸ©ğ‘†ğ‘™precedes\langle S,l,\prec\rangleâŸ¨ italic_S , italic_l , â‰º âŸ© where Sğ‘†Sitalic_S is a set, the elements of which will be called states, l:Sâ†¦ğ’°normal-:ğ‘™maps-toğ‘†ğ’°l:S\mapsto{\cal U}italic_l : italic_S â†¦ caligraphic_U assigns a world to each state and â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º is a strict partial order on Sğ‘†Sitalic_S satisfying the following smoothness condition: âˆ€Î±âˆˆLfor-allğ›¼ğ¿\forall\alpha\in Lâˆ€ italic_Î± âˆˆ italic_L, the set of states Î±^=def{sâˆ£sâˆˆS,sâ¢Â â‰¡Î±}superscriptnormal-defnormal-^ğ›¼conditional-setğ‘ formulae-sequenceğ‘ ğ‘†ğ‘ Â ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\{s\mid s\in S,\>s\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv\alpha\}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP { italic_s âˆ£ italic_s âˆˆ italic_S , italic_s â‰¡ italic_Î± } is smooth, where Â â‰¡Â absent\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equivâ‰¡ is defined as sâ¢Â â‰¡Î±ğ‘ Â ğ›¼s\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv\alphaitalic_s â‰¡ italic_Î± (read sğ‘ sitalic_s satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±) iff lâ¢(s)âŠ§Î±modelsğ‘™ğ‘ ğ›¼l(s)\models\alphaitalic_l ( italic_s ) âŠ§ italic_Î±. The model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W will be said to be finite iff Sğ‘†Sitalic_S is finite. It will be said to be well-founded iff âŸ¨S,â‰ºâŸ©ğ‘†precedes\langle S,\prec\rangleâŸ¨ italic_S , â‰º âŸ© is well-founded, i.e., iff there is no infinite descending chain of states.

The smoothness condition is only a technical condition. It is satisfied in any well-founded preferential model, and, in particular, in any finite model. When the language â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_LÂ is logically finite, we could have limited ourselves to finite models and forgotten the smoothness condition. Nevertheless, LemmaÂ 1 will show that, in the general case, for the representation result of TheoremÂ 1 to hold we could not have required preferential models to be well-founded. The requirement that the relation â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º be a strict partial order has been introduced only because such models are nicer and the smoothness condition is easier to check on those models, but the soundness result is true for the larger family of models, where â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º is just any binary relation (DefinitionsÂ 2 and 3 also make sense for any binary relation â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º). In such a case, obviously, the smoothness condition cannot be dropped even for finite models. The completeness result holds, obviously, also for the larger family, but is less interesting.

We shall now describe the consequence relation defined by a model.

Definition 5

Suppose a model W=âŸ¨S,l,â‰ºâŸ©ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ‘™precedesW=\langle S,l,\prec\rangleitalic_W = âŸ¨ italic_S , italic_l , â‰º âŸ© and Î±,Î²âˆˆLğ›¼ğ›½ğ¿\alpha,\beta\in Litalic_Î± , italic_Î² âˆˆ italic_L are given. The consequence relation defined by Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W will be denoted by Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and is defined by: Î±â¢Â Â âˆ¼WÂ â¢Î²ğ›¼Â Â âˆ¼WÂ ğ›½\alpha\mbox{ $\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}$ }\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² iff for any sğ‘ sitalic_s minimal in Î±^normal-^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG, sâ¢Â â‰¡Î²ğ‘ Â ğ›½s\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv\betaitalic_s â‰¡ italic_Î².

If Î±â¢Â Â âˆ¼WÂ â¢Î²ğ›¼Â Â âˆ¼WÂ ğ›½\alpha\mbox{ $\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}$ }\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î² we shall say that the model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W satisfies the conditional assertion Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î²ğ›¼Â âˆ¼Â ğ›½\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î², or that Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is a model of Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î²ğ›¼Â âˆ¼Â ğ›½\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î².

The following theorem characterizes preferential consequence relations.

Theorem 1 (Kraus, Lehmann and Magidor)

A binary relation Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ on â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is a preferential consequence relation iff it is the consequence relation defined by some preferential model. If the language â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is logically finite, then every preferential consequence relation is defined by some finite preferential model.

The next result shows we could not have restricted ourselves to well-founded models.

Lemma 1

There is a preferential relation that is defined by no well-founded preferential model.

Proof: Let â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L be the propositional calculus on the variables pi,iâˆˆÏ‰subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–ğœ”p_{i},i\in\omegaitalic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i âˆˆ italic_Ï‰ (Ï‰ğœ”\omegaitalic_Ï‰ is the set of natural numbers). We shall consider the model W=defâŸ¨V,l,â‰ºâŸ©superscriptdefğ‘Šğ‘‰ğ‘™precedesW\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\langle V,l,\prec\rangleitalic_W start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP âŸ¨ italic_V , italic_l , â‰º âŸ© where Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V is the set {siâˆ£iâˆˆÏ‰âˆª{âˆ}}conditional-setsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘–ğœ”\{s_{i}\mid i\in\omega\cup\{\infty\}\}{ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ italic_i âˆˆ italic_Ï‰ âˆª { âˆ } }, siâ‰ºsjprecedessubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—s_{i}\prec s_{j}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰º italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT iff i>jğ‘–ğ‘—i>jitalic_i > italic_j (i.e., there is an infinite descending chain of states with a bottom element) and lâ¢(si)â¢(pj)ğ‘™subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—l(s_{i})(p_{j})italic_l ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is true iff jâ‰¥iğ‘—ğ‘–j\geq iitalic_j â‰¥ italic_i, for iâˆˆÏ‰âˆª{âˆ}ğ‘–ğœ”i\in\omega\cup\{\infty\}italic_i âˆˆ italic_Ï‰ âˆª { âˆ } and jâˆˆÏ‰ğ‘—ğœ”j\in\omegaitalic_j âˆˆ italic_Ï‰. The smoothness property is satisfied since the only subsets of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V that do not have a minimum are infinite sets Ağ´Aitalic_A that do not contain sâˆsubscriptğ‘ s_{\infty}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and any Î±âˆˆLğ›¼ğ¿\alpha\in Litalic_Î± âˆˆ italic_L that is satisfied in all states of such a set Ağ´Aitalic_A is also satisfied in sâˆsubscriptğ‘ s_{\infty}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W defines a preferential relation Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that âˆ€iâˆˆÏ‰for-allğ‘–ğœ”\forall i\in\omegaâˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ italic_Ï‰ , pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT pi+1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1p_{i+1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pi+1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1p_{i+1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â¬â¢pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–\neg p_{i}Â¬ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â âˆ¼Ì¸Wsubscriptnot-similar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}âˆ¼Ì¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT false. But clearly, any preferential model defining such a relation must contain an infinite descending chain of states. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

We do not know of any direct characterization of those relations that may be defined by well-founded preferential models. But LemmaÂ 3 will show that many relations may be defined by well-founded preferential models. It is clear, though, that the canonical preferential model provided by the proof of TheoremÂ 1 is rarely well-founded. Consider, for example, the preferential closure of the empty knowledge base on a logically infinite language â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L. It may be defined by some well-founded preferential model (the order â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º is empty). But its canonical model is not well-founded (consider states whose second components are larger and larger disjunctions). We may only make the following obvious remark: if the underlying language â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is logically finite, then all canonical models are well-founded.

2.4 Preferential entailment

Now that we have a proof-theoretic definition of a class of relations, a class of models and a representation theorem relating them, it is natural to put down the following definition. It will serve us as a first approximate answer to the question of the title.

Definition 6

The assertion ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A is preferentially entailed by K iff it is satisfied by all preferential models of K. The set of all conditional assertions that are preferentially entailed by K will be denoted by ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The preferential consequence relation ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is called the preferential closure of K.

InÂ [17] it was noted that the characterization of preferential consequence relations obtained in TheoremÂ 1 enables us to prove the following.

Theorem 2

Let K be a set of conditional assertions, and ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A a conditional assertion. The following conditions are equivalent:

  1. 1.

    ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A is preferentially entailed by K, i.e., ğ’œâˆˆğŠpğ’œsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\cal A}\in{\bf K}^{p}caligraphic_A âˆˆ bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

  2. 2.

    ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A has a proof from K in the system P consisting of the RulesÂ 1 toÂ 6.

The following compactness result follows.

Corollary 1 (compactness)

K preferentially entails ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A iff a finite subset of K does.

The following also follows from TheoremÂ 2.

Corollary 2

The set ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, considered as a consequence relation, is a preferential consequence relation, therefore there is a preferential model that satisfies exactly the assertions of ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. If K is itself a preferential consequence relation then ğŠ=ğŠpğŠsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}={\bf K}^{p}bold_K = bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The set ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT grows monotonically with K.

We see that the operation ğŠâ†¦ğŠpmaps-toğŠsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}\mapsto{\bf K}^{p}bold_K â†¦ bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a compact monotonic consequence operation in the sense of TarskiÂ [35]. We have a particular interest in finite knowledge bases. It is therefore useful to put down the following definition.

Definition 7

A preferential consequence relation is finitely generated iff it is the preferential closure of a finite knowledge base.

LemmaÂ 3 will show that finitely generated relations have interesting properties. InÂ [17], it was shown that any preferential relation defines a strict ordering on formulas by: Î±<Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha<\betaitalic_Î± < italic_Î² iff Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±âˆ¨\veeâˆ¨Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±âˆ¨\veeâˆ¨Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î².

Definition 8

A preferential relation is well-founded iff the strict ordering relation <<< it defines is well-founded.

The following is easy to show.

Lemma 2

A preferential relation is well-founded iff the canonical model built in the proof of TheoremÂ 1 is well-founded.

We noticed, at the end of SectionÂ 2.3, that not all preferential relations that may be defined by well-founded preferential models are well-founded.

Lemma 3

Any finitely generated preferential relation is defined by some well-founded preferential model.

Proof: Let KÂ be any finite set of assertions. Let Li,iâˆˆÏ‰subscriptğ¿ğ‘–ğ‘–ğœ”L_{i},i\in\omegaitalic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i âˆˆ italic_Ï‰ be an infinite sequence of larger and larger logically finite sublanguages of Lğ¿Litalic_L such that every Lisubscriptğ¿ğ‘–L_{i}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains all the formulas appearing in the assertions of KÂ and such that Lğ¿Litalic_L is the union of the Lisubscriptğ¿ğ‘–L_{i}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s. By TheoremÂ 1, for each iğ‘–iitalic_i there is a finite preferential model Wiâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šâ€²ğ‘–W^{\prime}_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that defines the preferential closure of KÂ over Lisubscriptğ¿ğ‘–L_{i}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let Wisubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–W_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the finite preferential model (over Lğ¿Litalic_L) obtained by extending the labeling function of Wiâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šâ€²ğ‘–W^{\prime}_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the variables of Lâˆ’Liğ¿subscriptğ¿ğ‘–L-L_{i}italic_L - italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in some arbitrary way. Clearly Wisubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–W_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a preferential model of K. Let Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W be the structure obtained by putting all the Wisubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–W_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s one alongside the other (the partial ordering â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º on Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W never relates states belonging to Wisubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–W_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s with different iğ‘–iitalic_iâ€™s). The structure Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is well-founded, therefore satisfies the smoothness condition and is a preferential model. Any assertion that is preferentially entailed by KÂ (over Lğ¿Litalic_L) is satisfied by every Wisubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–W_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and is therefore satisfied by Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W. For any assertion ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_AÂ that is not preferentially entailed by Kâ€‰ one may find a language Lisubscriptğ¿ğ‘–L_{i}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT large enough to include the formulas of ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A. Over Lisubscriptğ¿ğ‘–L_{i}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the assertion ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_AÂ is not preferentially entailed by K, by TheoremÂ 2, since a proof in the small language is a proof in the larger one. Therefore Wiâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Šâ€²ğ‘–W^{\prime}_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not satisfy ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A. We conclude that Wisubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–W_{i}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not satisfy ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_AÂ and that Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W does not satisfy ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

2.5 Some properties of preferential entailment

The following result, TheoremÂ 3, is new. It is important for several reasons. It uses the semantic representation of TheoremÂ 1 and a direct proof using only proof-theoretic arguments seems difficult. It will be used in SectionÂ 4.2. Its CorollaryÂ 3 should provide a starting point for the application to preferential entailment of methods based on or related to resolution. First a definition.

Definition 9

If a formula Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is such that Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ false, we shall say that Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is consistent (for the consequence relation Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ ). A formula is consistent for a model iff it is consistent for the consequence relation defined by the model, or equivalently iff there is a state in the model that satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±.

We shall now define a basic operation on preferential models. Suppose Mğ‘€Mitalic_M is a preferential model âŸ¨V,l,â‰ºâŸ©ğ‘‰ğ‘™precedes\langle V,l,\prec\rangleâŸ¨ italic_V , italic_l , â‰º âŸ©. For s,tâˆˆVğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘‰s,t\in Vitalic_s , italic_t âˆˆ italic_V we shall write sâª¯tprecedes-or-equalsğ‘ ğ‘¡s\preceq titalic_s âª¯ italic_t iff sâ‰ºtprecedesğ‘ ğ‘¡s\prec titalic_s â‰º italic_t or s=tğ‘ ğ‘¡s=titalic_s = italic_t. Let Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± be a formula and uâˆˆVğ‘¢ğ‘‰u\in Vitalic_u âˆˆ italic_V be a minimal element of Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG. Let â‰ºÎ±usuperscriptsubscriptprecedesğ›¼ğ‘¢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}â‰º start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the strict partial order obtained from â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º by making uğ‘¢uitalic_u a minimum of Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG, i.e., sâ‰ºÎ±utsuperscriptsubscriptprecedesğ›¼ğ‘¢ğ‘ ğ‘¡s\prec_{\alpha}^{u}titalic_s â‰º start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t iff sâ‰ºtprecedesğ‘ ğ‘¡s\prec titalic_s â‰º italic_t or sâª¯uprecedes-or-equalsğ‘ ğ‘¢s\preceq uitalic_s âª¯ italic_u and there exists a state wâˆˆÎ±^ğ‘¤^ğ›¼w\in\widehat{\alpha}italic_w âˆˆ over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG such that wâª¯tprecedes-or-equalsğ‘¤ğ‘¡w\preceq titalic_w âª¯ italic_t. The following lemma describes the properties of the construction described above.

Lemma 4

The structure MÎ±u=defâŸ¨V,l,â‰ºÎ±uâŸ©superscriptnormal-defsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ›¼ğ‘¢ğ‘‰ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptprecedesğ›¼ğ‘¢M_{\alpha}^{u}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\langle V,l,\prec_{\alpha}^{u}\rangleitalic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP âŸ¨ italic_V , italic_l , â‰º start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© is a preferential model. The consequence relation defined by MÎ±usuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ›¼ğ‘¢M_{\alpha}^{u}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT extends the consequence relation defined by Mğ‘€Mitalic_M. In this model uğ‘¢uitalic_u is a minimum of Î±^normal-^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG. Both models have the same set of consistent formulas.

Proof: It is easy to see that â‰ºÎ±usuperscriptsubscriptprecedesğ›¼ğ‘¢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}â‰º start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is irreflexive and transitive. It is also easy to see that, under â‰ºÎ±usuperscriptsubscriptprecedesğ›¼ğ‘¢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}â‰º start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, uğ‘¢uitalic_u is a minimum of Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG. We want to show now that, for any Î²âˆˆLğ›½ğ¿\beta\in Litalic_Î² âˆˆ italic_L, the set Î²^^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG is smooth, under â‰ºÎ±usuperscriptsubscriptprecedesğ›¼ğ‘¢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}â‰º start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let sâˆˆÎ²^ğ‘ ^ğ›½s\in\widehat{\beta}italic_s âˆˆ over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG. Since Î²^^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG is smooth under â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º, there is a state tğ‘¡titalic_t, minimal under â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º in Î²^^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG such that tâª¯sprecedes-or-equalsğ‘¡ğ‘ t\preceq sitalic_t âª¯ italic_s. If tğ‘¡titalic_t is still minimal in Î²^^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG under â‰ºÎ±usuperscriptsubscriptprecedesğ›¼ğ‘¢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}â‰º start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then we are done. If not, there is some state vâˆˆÎ²^ğ‘£^ğ›½v\in\widehat{\beta}italic_v âˆˆ over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG such that vâª¯uprecedes-or-equalsğ‘£ğ‘¢v\preceq uitalic_v âª¯ italic_u and vâ‰ºÎ±ussuperscriptsubscriptprecedesğ›¼ğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘ v\prec_{\alpha}^{u}sitalic_v â‰º start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s. Since Î²^^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG is smooth under â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º, there is a state wğ‘¤witalic_w, minimal in Î²^^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG under â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º such that wâ‰ºvprecedesğ‘¤ğ‘£w\prec vitalic_w â‰º italic_v. Since wâ‰ºuprecedesğ‘¤ğ‘¢w\prec uitalic_w â‰º italic_u, wğ‘¤witalic_w must be minimal in Î²^^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG also under â‰ºÎ±usuperscriptsubscriptprecedesğ›¼ğ‘¢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}â‰º start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. But wâ‰ºÎ±ussuperscriptsubscriptprecedesğ›¼ğ‘¢ğ‘¤ğ‘ w\prec_{\alpha}^{u}sitalic_w â‰º start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s. We have shown that Î²^^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG is smooth under â‰ºÎ±usuperscriptsubscriptprecedesğ›¼ğ‘¢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}â‰º start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To see that the consequence relation defined by MÎ±usuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ›¼ğ‘¢M_{\alpha}^{u}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT extends the one defined by Mğ‘€Mitalic_M, just notice that, since â‰ºÎ±usuperscriptsubscriptprecedesğ›¼ğ‘¢\prec_{\alpha}^{u}â‰º start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT extends â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º, all minimal elements under the former are also minimal under the latter. Lastly, since Mğ‘€Mitalic_M and MÎ±usuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ›¼ğ‘¢M_{\alpha}^{u}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have exactly the same set of worlds and the same labeling function, they define exactly the same set of consistent formulas. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Theorem 3

Let KÂ be a knowledge base and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â an assertion that is not preferentially entailed by K. The formulas that are inconsistent for the preferential closure of ğŠâˆª{Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Â¬â¢Î²}ğŠğ›¼Â âˆ¼Â ğ›½{\bf K}\cup\{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\neg\beta\}bold_K âˆª { italic_Î± âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î² } are those that are inconsistent for the preferential closure of K.

Proof: Suppose that Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is not preferentially entailed by K. Then, let W=âŸ¨S,l,â‰ºâŸ©ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ‘™precedesW=\langle S,l,\prec\rangleitalic_W = âŸ¨ italic_S , italic_l , â‰º âŸ© be the preferential model the existence of which is guaranteed by TheoremÂ 1 and that defines ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W does not satisfy Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². There is therefore a minimal element sâˆˆSğ‘ ğ‘†s\in Sitalic_s âˆˆ italic_S of Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG that does not satisfy Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². Consider now the model Wâ€²=defWÎ±ssuperscriptdefsuperscriptğ‘Šâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ›¼ğ‘ W^{\prime}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}W_{\alpha}^{s}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. By LemmaÂ 4 this is a preferential model that satisfies all the assertions satisfied by Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, therefore it satisfies all the assertions of K. Since sğ‘ sitalic_s is the only minimal element of Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG, it satisfies ğŠâˆª{Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â¬â¢Î²}ğŠsimilar-toğ›¼Â ğ›½{\bf K}\cup\{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\beta\}bold_K âˆª { italic_Î± âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î² }. Suppose Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â is inconsistent for (ğŠâˆª{Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Â¬â¢Î²})psuperscriptğŠğ›¼Â âˆ¼Â ğ›½ğ‘({\bf K}\cup\{\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\neg\beta\})^{p}( bold_K âˆª { italic_Î± âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î² } ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then it must be inconsistent for Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. By LemmaÂ 4 it is inconsistent for Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, therefore inconsistent for ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Corollary 3

Let KÂ be a conditional knowledge base and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â a conditional assertion. The assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is preferentially entailed by KÂ iff the assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false is preferentially entailed by ğŠâˆª{Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â¬â¢Î²}ğŠsimilar-toğ›¼Â ğ›½{\bf K}\cup\{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\beta\}bold_K âˆª { italic_Î± âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î² }.

Proof: The only if part follows immediately from the soundness of the And rule. The if part, follows immediately from TheoremÂ 3. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

2.6 The rank of a formula

In this section, we introduce a powerful tool for studying preferential entailment. Given a knowledge base, we shall attach an ordinal, its rank, to every formula. We shall prove an important result concerning those ranks, and, in particular, show that a knowledge base KÂ and its preferential closure ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTÂ define the same ranks.

Definition 10

Let KÂ be a conditional knowledge base (i.e., a set of conditional assertions) and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â a formula. The formula Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is said to be exceptional for KÂ iff KÂ preferentially entails the assertion true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î±ğ›¼\neg\alphaÂ¬ italic_Î±. The conditional assertion ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A=defsuperscriptnormal-def\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² is said to be exceptional for KÂ iff its antecedent Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is exceptional for K.

The set of all assertions of KÂ that are exceptional for KÂ will be denoted by Eâ¢(ğŠ)ğ¸ğŠE({\bf K})italic_E ( bold_K ). Notice that Eâ¢(ğŠ)âŠ†ğŠğ¸ğŠğŠE({\bf K})\subseteq{\bf K}italic_E ( bold_K ) âŠ† bold_K. If all assertions of KÂ are exceptional for K, i.e., if KÂ is equal to Eâ¢(ğŠ)ğ¸ğŠE({\bf K})italic_E ( bold_K ), we shall say that KÂ is completely exceptional. The empty knowledge base is completely exceptional. Notice that, in the definition above, KÂ may be replaced by its preferential closure ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Given a conditional knowledge base KÂ (not necessarily finite), we shall now define by ordinal induction an infinite non-increasing sequence of subsets of K. Let C0subscriptğ¶0C_{0}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be equal to K. For any successor ordinal Ï„+1ğœ1\tau+1italic_Ï„ + 1, CÏ„+1subscriptğ¶ğœ1C_{\tau+1}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be Eâ¢(CÏ„)ğ¸subscriptğ¶ğœE(C_{\tau})italic_E ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and for any limit ordinal Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the intersection of all CÏsubscriptğ¶ğœŒC_{\rho}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for Ï<Ï„ğœŒğœ\rho<\tauitalic_Ï < italic_Ï„. It is clear that, after some point on, all Cğ¶Citalic_Câ€™s are equal and completely exceptional (they may be empty, but need not be so). We shall say that a formula Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â has rank Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ (for K) iff Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ is the least ordinal for which Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is not exceptional for CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A formula that is exceptional for all CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s is said to have no rank. Notice that such a formula is exceptional for a totally exceptional knowledge base. The following is a fundamental lemma on preferential entailment. It says that, as far as preferential entailment is concerned, non-exceptional assertions cannot help deriving exceptional assertions. The notion of rank defined above proves to be a powerful tool for studying preferential entailment.

Lemma 5

Let Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ be an ordinal. Let KÂ be a conditional knowledge base and ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_AÂ a conditional assertion whose antecedent has rank larger or equal to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ (or has no rank). Then ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_AÂ is preferentially entailed by C0subscriptğ¶0C_{0}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT iff it is preferentially entailed by CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof: The if part follows from the fact that CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a subset of C0subscriptğ¶0C_{0}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The only if part is proved by induction on the length of the proof of ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_AÂ from C0subscriptğ¶0C_{0}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If the proof has length one, i.e., ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_AÂ is obtained by Reflexivity or is an assertion of C0subscriptğ¶0C_{0}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then the result is obvious. If the last step of the proof is obtained by Right Weakening or And, the result follows from a trivial use of the induction hypothesis. If the last step of the proof is obtained by Left Logical Equivalence, the result follows from the induction hypothesis and the fact that, if Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â and Î±â€²superscriptğ›¼â€²\alpha^{\prime}italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are logically equivalent then Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â and Î±â€²superscriptğ›¼â€²\alpha^{\prime}italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have the same rank. If the last step is a use of Or, and ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_AÂ is of the form Î±âˆ¨Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\vee\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ then just remark that the rank of the disjunction Î±âˆ¨Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\vee\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² is the smaller of the ranks of Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â and Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². Both Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â and Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â have therefore a rank larger or equal to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ and one concludes by the induction hypothesis. If the last step is a use of Cautious Monotonicity, and ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_AÂ is of the form Î±âˆ§Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, where Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ are preferentially entailed (with short proofs) by C0subscriptğ¶0C_{0}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, let Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ be the rank of Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. By the induction hypothesis CÏƒsubscriptğ¶ğœC_{\sigma}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT preferentially entails Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². Since Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is not exceptional for CÏƒsubscriptğ¶ğœC_{\sigma}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we conclude that Î±âˆ§Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² is not exceptional for CÏƒsubscriptğ¶ğœC_{\sigma}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and therefore has rank Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ. But Î±âˆ§Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² has rank larger or equal to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. Therefore Ï„â‰¤Ïƒğœğœ\tau\leq\sigmaitalic_Ï„ â‰¤ italic_Ïƒ. The formula Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â has rank larger or equal to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ and we may apply the induction hypothesis to conclude that both Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ are preferentially entailed by CÏsubscriptğ¶ğœŒC_{\rho}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Lemma 6

Let KÂ and ğŠâ€²superscriptğŠnormal-â€²{\bf K}^{\prime}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be knowledge bases such that ğŠâŠ†ğŠâ€²âŠ†ğŠpğŠsuperscriptğŠnormal-â€²superscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}\subseteq{\bf K}^{\prime}\subseteq{\bf K}^{p}bold_K âŠ† bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ† bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For any formula, the rank it is given by ğŠâ€²superscriptğŠnormal-â€²{\bf K}^{\prime}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is equal to the rank it is given by K.

Proof: Using LemmaÂ 5, one shows by ordinal induction that CÏ„âŠ†CÏ„â€²âŠ†(CÏ„)psubscriptğ¶ğœsubscriptsuperscriptğ¶â€²ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ¶ğœğ‘C_{\tau}\subseteq C^{\prime}_{\tau}\subseteq(C_{\tau})^{p}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

The following definition will be useful in SectionÂ 5.6.

Definition 11

A knowledge base KÂ is said to be admissible iff all formulas that have no rank for KÂ are inconsistent for K.

We shall immediately show that many knowledge bases are admissible.

Lemma 7

If the preferential closure of KÂ is defined by some well-founded preferential model, then KÂ is admissible. In particular, any finite knowledge base is admissible.

Proof: We have noticed, in LemmaÂ 6 that ranks are stable under the the replacement of a knowledge base by its preferential closure. Let Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P be the preferential closure of K. Suppose Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P is defined by some well-founded preferential model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W. Suppose Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â has no rank. We must show that no state of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. As noticed above, there is an ordinal Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ such that CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is completely exceptional and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is exceptional for CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We shall show that no state of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W satisfies a formula that is exceptional for CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Indeed, if there were such a state, there would be such a minimal state, sğ‘ sitalic_s, since Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is well-founded. But Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is a model of CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and no state below sğ‘ sitalic_s satisfy any antecedent of CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, since CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is totally exceptional. Therefore the preferential model consisting of sğ‘ sitalic_s alone is a model of CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. But, in a model of CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, no minimal state satisfy a formula that is exceptional for CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A contradiction. It follows now from LemmaÂ 3 that any finite knowledge base is admissible. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

2.7 Computing preferential entailment

This section is devoted to the study of the computational complexity of preferential entailment. It is not needed in the sequel. We shall explain in SectionÂ 3.5 why preferential entailment is not the right notion of entailment to answer the question of the title, nevertheless preferential entailment is a central concept and it is therefore worthwhile studying its computational complexity. The results here are quite encouraging: the problem is in co-NP, i.e., in the same polynomial class as the problem of deciding whether a propositional formula is valid.

Lemma 8

Let KÂ be a finite conditional knowledge base and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â a conditional assertion that is not preferentially entailed by K. There is a finite totally (i.e., linearly) ordered preferential model of Kâ€‰ no state of which satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â except the top state. This top state satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â and does not satisfy Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î².

Proof: Let â„’â€²âŠ†â„’superscriptâ„’â€²â„’{\cal L^{\prime}}\subseteq{\cal L}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ† caligraphic_L be a logically finite language, large enough to contain Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â and all the assertions of K. Let us now consider â„’â€²superscriptâ„’â€²{\cal L^{\prime}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be our language of reference. Clearly, Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is not preferentially entailed by K, since a proof over the smaller language is a proof over the larger language. By TheoremÂ 1, there is a finite preferential model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W (over â„’â€²superscriptâ„’â€²{\cal L^{\prime}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) of KÂ that does not satisfy Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². In Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, there is therefore a state sğ‘ sitalic_s, minimal in Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG, that satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â but does not satisfy Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². Consider the submodel Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT obtained by deleting all states of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W that are not below or equal to sğ‘ sitalic_s. It is clearly a finite preferential model of K, with a top state that satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â but not Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². Let Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V be obtained by imposing on the states of Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT any total ordering that respects the partial ordering of Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Since there are only finitely many states in Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V, the smoothness condition is verified and Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V is a preferential model (on â„’â€²superscriptâ„’â€²{\cal L^{\prime}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). It is a model of KÂ but not of ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A. Now we may extend the labeling function of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V to the propositional variables of â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L that are not in â„’â€²superscriptâ„’â€²{\cal L^{\prime}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT any way we want, to get the model requested. Notice that the model obtained satisfies the smoothness condition because it is finite. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Theorem 4

There is a non-deterministic algorithm that, given a finite set K of conditional assertions and a conditional assertion ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A, checks that ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A is not preferentially entailed by K. The running time of this algorithm is polynomial in the size of K (sum of the sizes of its elements) and ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A.

Proof: Let K be {Î³iâ¢Â âˆ¼Î´i}i=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsimilar-tosubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–Â subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘{\{\gamma_{i}\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\delta_{i}\}}_{i=1}^{N}{ italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let IâŠ†{1,â€¦,N}ğ¼1â€¦ğ‘I\subseteq\{1,\ldots,N\}italic_I âŠ† { 1 , â€¦ , italic_N } be a set of indices. We shall define: Ï†I=defâ‹iâˆˆIÎ³isuperscriptdefsubscriptğœ‘ğ¼subscriptğ‘–ğ¼subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\varphi_{I}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\bigvee_{i\in I}\gamma_{i}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP â‹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ÏˆI=defâ‹€iâˆˆI(Î³iâ†’Î´i)superscriptdefsubscriptğœ“ğ¼subscriptğ‘–ğ¼â†’subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–\psi_{I}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\bigwedge_{i\in I}\left(\gamma_{i}\rightarrow\delta_{i}\right)italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP â‹€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). A sequence is a sequence of pairs (Ii,fi)subscriptğ¼ğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\left(I_{i},f_{i}\right)( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for i=0,â€¦,nğ‘–0â€¦ğ‘›i=0,\ldots,nitalic_i = 0 , â€¦ , italic_n, where IiâŠ†Isubscriptğ¼ğ‘–ğ¼I_{i}\subseteq Iitalic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† italic_I and fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a world. Let Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± and Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² be in â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L.

    fkâŠ§ÏˆIkmodelssubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜subscriptğœ“subscriptğ¼ğ‘˜f_{k}\models\psi_{I_{k}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ§ italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Â âˆ€k=0,â€¦,nfor-allğ‘˜0normal-â€¦ğ‘›\forall k=0,\ldots,nâˆ€ italic_k = 0 , â€¦ , italic_n

    Ik+1=Ikâ¢â‹‚{jâˆ£fkâŠ§Ì¸Î³j}subscriptğ¼ğ‘˜1subscriptğ¼ğ‘˜conditional-setğ‘—not-modelssubscriptğ‘“ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¾ğ‘—I_{k+1}=I_{k}\bigcap\{j\mid f_{k}\not\models\gamma_{j}\}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹‚ { italic_j âˆ£ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ§Ì¸ italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, Â âˆ€k=0,â€¦,nâˆ’1for-allğ‘˜0normal-â€¦ğ‘›1\forall k=0,\ldots,n-1âˆ€ italic_k = 0 , â€¦ , italic_n - 1

We must check that: witnesses are short and a conditional assertion has a witness iff it is not preferentially entailed by K. For the first point, just remark that, for k=0,â€¦,nâˆ’1ğ‘˜0â€¦ğ‘›1k=0,\ldots,n-1italic_k = 0 , â€¦ , italic_n - 1 the inclusion IkâŠƒIk+1subscriptğ¼ğ‘˜1subscriptğ¼ğ‘˜I_{k}\supset I_{k+1}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠƒ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is strict because of itemsÂ 3 and 2. The length of the sequence is therefore bounded by the number of assertions in K. But, each pair has a short description. Let us check that Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W satisfies Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î´isubscriptğ›¿ğ‘–\delta_{i}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Suppose therefore that jğ‘—jitalic_j is the smallest kğ‘˜kitalic_k for which fjâŠ§Î³imodelssubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–f_{j}\models\gamma_{i}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ§ italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We must show that fjâŠ§Î´imodelssubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–f_{j}\models\delta_{i}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ§ italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. But, by itemsÂ 4 and 3 iâˆˆIjğ‘–subscriptğ¼ğ‘—i\in I_{j}italic_i âˆˆ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and by itemÂ 1, fiâŠ§Î´imodelssubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–f_{i}\models\delta_{i}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ§ italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Suppose now that Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² is not preferentially entailed by some given finite K. By LemmaÂ 8, there is a finite linearly ordered model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W of K, no state of which satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, except the top state that is labeled by a world mğ‘šmitalic_m that satisfies Î±âˆ§Â¬â¢Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î². Let I0=def{1,â€¦,N}superscriptdefsubscriptğ¼01â€¦ğ‘I_{0}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\{1,\ldots,N\}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP { 1 , â€¦ , italic_N }. It is easy to see that (remark 1): if Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V is any preferential model of K, for any set IâŠ†I0ğ¼subscriptğ¼0I\subseteq I_{0}italic_I âŠ† italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V satisfies Ï†Iâ¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢ÏˆIsubscriptğœ‘ğ¼Â âˆ¼Â subscriptğœ“ğ¼\varphi_{I}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\psi_{I}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Ïˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let us now consider first the set Î±âˆ¨Ï†I0^^ğ›¼subscriptğœ‘subscriptğ¼0\widehat{\alpha\vee\varphi_{I_{0}}}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. It cannot be empty, therefore it has a unique minimal state. Let f0subscriptğ‘“0f_{0}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the label of this state. We must consider two cases. First suppose that f0âŠ§Î±modelssubscriptğ‘“0ğ›¼f_{0}\models\alphaitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ§ italic_Î±. Then f0subscriptğ‘“0f_{0}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is minimal in Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG and therefore must be mğ‘šmitalic_m. In such a case (I0,m)subscriptğ¼0ğ‘š\left(I_{0},m\right)( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m ) is a witness. The only thing to check is that itemÂ 1 is satisfied. Indeed either mâŠ§Ï†I0modelsğ‘šsubscriptğœ‘subscriptğ¼0m\models\varphi_{I_{0}}italic_m âŠ§ italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and we conclude by remarkÂ 1 or Ï†I0^=âˆ…^subscriptğœ‘subscriptğ¼0\widehat{\varphi_{I_{0}}}=\emptysetover^ start_ARG italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = âˆ… and mğ‘šmitalic_m satisfies none of the Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s. Let us deal now with the case f0âŠ§Ì¸Î±not-modelssubscriptğ‘“0ğ›¼f_{0}\not\models\alphaitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ§Ì¸ italic_Î±. We shall build a sequence beginning by (I0,m)subscriptğ¼0ğ‘š\left(I_{0},m\right)( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m ). Since mğ‘šmitalic_m does not satisfy Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, it must satisfy Ï†I0subscriptğœ‘subscriptğ¼0\varphi_{I_{0}}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which takes care of itemÂ 2. RemarkÂ 1 takes care of itemÂ 1. Let us now define I1=I0â¢â‹‚{jâˆ£f0âŠ§Ì¸Î³j}subscriptğ¼1subscriptğ¼0conditional-setğ‘—not-modelssubscriptğ‘“0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘—I_{1}=I_{0}\bigcap\{j\mid f_{0}\not\models\gamma_{j}\}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹‚ { italic_j âˆ£ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ§Ì¸ italic_Î³ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. I1subscriptğ¼1I_{1}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is strictly smaller than I0subscriptğ¼0I_{0}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We may now consider the set Î±âˆ¨Ï†I1^^ğ›¼subscriptğœ‘subscriptğ¼1\widehat{\alpha\vee\varphi_{I_{1}}}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. It is not empty and therefore has a unique minimal element and we may, in this way, go on and build a proof for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Since it is clear that preferential non-entailment is at least as hard as satisfiability (consider assertions with antecedent true), we conclude that it is an NP-complete problem, i.e., that preferential entailment is co-NP-complete. A remark of J.Â Dix that will be explained at the end of SectionÂ 5.8 shows that preferential entailment is reducible to the computation of rational closure and that this reduction, when applied to Horn formulas, requires only the consideration of Horn formulas. It follows that, if we restrict ourselves to Horn assertions, computing preferential entailment has only polynomial complexity.

3 Rationality

3.1 Introduction

In this section we explain why not all preferential relations represent reasonable nonmonotonic inference procedures. We present some additional principles of nonmonotonic reasoning and discuss them. Those principles are structurally different from the rules of preferential reasoning, since they are not of the type: deduce some assertion from some other assertions. SectionsÂ 3.2 andÂ 3.3 present weak principles. Some results are proven concerning those principles. Deeper results on those principles, found after a first version of this paper had been circulated, appear inÂ [11]. Our central principle is presented in SectionÂ 3.4. Those principles were first described inÂ [17] but the technical results presented here are new. InÂ 3.5, the value of preferential entailment as an answer to the question of the title is discussed. Our conclusion is that it is not a satisfactory answer, since it does not provide us with a rational relation. Then, in SectionÂ 3.6, a restricted family of preferential models, the family of ranked models, is presented and a representation theorem is proved. The result is central to this paper but the proof of the representation theorem may be skipped on a first reading. The representation theorem appeared inÂ [19]. The family of ranked models is closely related to, but different from, a family studied inÂ [7] and SectionÂ 3.7 explains the differences.

3.2 Negation Rationality

InÂ [17, Section 5.4], it was argued that not all preferential consequence relations represented reasonable inference operations. Three rationality properties were discussed there, and it was argued that all three were desirable. Those properties do not lend themselves to be presented as Horn rules (deduce the presence of an assertion in a relation from the presence of other assertions) but have the form: deduce the absence of an assertion from the absence of other assertions. All of them are implied by Monotonicity. The reader may find the discussion ofÂ [17] useful. Here technical results will be described. The first property considered is the following.

Î±âˆ§Î³â¢Â âˆ¼Ì¸Î²,Î±âˆ§Â¬â¢Î³â¢Â âˆ¼Ì¸Î²Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Ì¸Î²(ğğğ ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§â¢ğ‘ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ğšğ¥ğ¢ğ­ğ²)formulae-sequencenot-similar-toğ›¼ğ›¾Â ğ›½not-similar-toğ›¼ğ›¾Â ğ›½not-similar-toğ›¼Â ğ›½ğğğ ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ğ‘ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ğšğ¥ğ¢ğ­ğ²{{\alpha\wedge\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\beta\ ,\ \alpha\wedge\neg\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\beta}\over{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\beta}}\hskip 45.52458pt{\rm({\bf Negation\ Rationality})}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î³ âˆ¼Ì¸ italic_Î² , italic_Î± âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ¼Ì¸ italic_Î² end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¼Ì¸ italic_Î² end_ARG ( bold_Negation bold_Rationality ) (10)
Lemma 9

There is a preferential relation that does not satisfy Negation Rationality.

Proof: Take a preferential model containing four states: si,i=0,â€¦â¢3formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘–0â€¦3s_{i},i=0,\ldots 3italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i = 0 , â€¦ 3, with s0â‰ºs1precedessubscriptğ‘ 0subscriptğ‘ 1s_{0}\prec s_{1}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰º italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and s2â‰ºs3precedessubscriptğ‘ 2subscriptğ‘ 3s_{2}\prec s_{3}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰º italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let the even states be the only states satisfying qğ‘qitalic_q and s0subscriptğ‘ 0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and s3subscriptğ‘ 3s_{3}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the only states satisfying pğ‘pitalic_p. One easily verifies that the consequence relation defined by this model is such that true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ qğ‘qitalic_q, but pğ‘pitalic_p Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ qğ‘qitalic_q and Â¬â¢pğ‘\neg pÂ¬ italic_p Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ qğ‘qitalic_q. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

No semantic characterization of relations satisfying Negation Rationality is known. It has been shown inÂ [17] that the consequence relation defined by Circumscription does not always satisfy Negation Rationality.

3.3 Disjunctive Rationality

The next property is the following.

Î±Â âˆ¼Ì¸Î³,Î²Â âˆ¼Ì¸Î³Î±âˆ¨Î²â¢Â âˆ¼Ì¸Î³(ğƒğ¢ğ¬ğ£ğ®ğ§ğœğ­ğ¢ğ¯ğâ¢ğ‘ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ğšğ¥ğ¢ğ­ğ²){{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\gamma\ \ ,\ \ \beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\gamma}\over{\alpha\vee\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\gamma}}\hskip 85.35826pt{\rm({\bf Disjunctive\ Rationality})}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¼Ì¸ italic_Î³ , italic_Î² âˆ¼Ì¸ italic_Î³ end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² âˆ¼Ì¸ italic_Î³ end_ARG ( bold_Disjunctive bold_Rationality ) (11)

We may prove the following.

Lemma 10

Any preferential relation that satisfies Disjunctive Rationality satisfies Negation Rationality.

Proof: Suppose Î±âˆ§Î³ğ›¼ğ›¾\alpha\wedge\gammaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î³ Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² and Î±âˆ§Â¬â¢Î³ğ›¼ğ›¾\alpha\wedge\neg\gammaitalic_Î± âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î³ Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². By Disjunctive Rationality, we conclude that Î±âˆ§Î³âˆ¨Î±âˆ§Â¬â¢Î³ğ›¼ğ›¾ğ›¼ğ›¾\alpha\wedge\gamma\vee\alpha\wedge\neg\gammaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î³ âˆ¨ italic_Î± âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î³ Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². We conclude by Left Logical Equivalence. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Lemma 11

There is a preferential relation that satisfies Negation Rationality but does not satisfy Disjunctive Rationality.

Proof: Let us consider the following preferential model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W. The model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W has four states: a0,a1,b0,b1subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1a_{0},a_{1},b_{0},b_{1}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The ordering is: a0â‰ºa1precedessubscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1a_{0}\prec a_{1}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰º italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and b0â‰ºb1precedessubscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1b_{0}\prec b_{1}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰º italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The language has three propositional variables: pğ‘pitalic_p, qğ‘qitalic_q and rğ‘Ÿritalic_r.
