The two states a1subscriptğ‘1a_{1}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and b1subscriptğ‘1b_{1}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (the top states) are labeled with the same world that satisfies only pğ‘pitalic_p and qğ‘qitalic_q. State a0subscriptğ‘0a_{0}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is labeled with the world that satisfies only pğ‘pitalic_p and rğ‘Ÿritalic_r and the state b0subscriptğ‘0b_{0}italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the world that satisfies only qğ‘qitalic_q and rğ‘Ÿritalic_r. The preferential relation defined by Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W does not satisfy Disjunctive Rationality but satisfies Weak Rationality. For the first claim, notice that: pâˆ¨qğ‘ğ‘p\vee qitalic_p âˆ¨ italic_q Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT rğ‘Ÿritalic_r but pğ‘pitalic_p Â âˆ¼Ì¸Wsubscriptnot-similar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}âˆ¼Ì¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT rğ‘Ÿritalic_r and qğ‘qitalic_q Â âˆ¼Ì¸Wsubscriptnot-similar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}âˆ¼Ì¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT rğ‘Ÿritalic_r. For the second claim, suppose Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, but Î±âˆ§Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² Â âˆ¼Ì¸Wsubscriptnot-similar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}âˆ¼Ì¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. Then it must be the case that there is a minimal state of Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG that does not satisfy Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â and, above it, a state that is minimal in Î±âˆ§Î²^^ğ›¼ğ›½\widehat{\alpha\wedge\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² end_ARG. This last state must be labeled by a world that is the label of no minimal state of Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG. Therefore, Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG must contain all four states of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, and Î±âˆ§Î²^^ğ›¼ğ›½\widehat{\alpha\wedge\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² end_ARG must contain either the two top states alone or the two top states and one of the bottom states. In each case it is easy to see that Î±âˆ§Â¬â¢Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î² Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ since the minimal states of Î±âˆ§Â¬â¢Î²^^ğ›¼ğ›½\widehat{\alpha\wedge\neg\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î² end_ARG are all also minimal in Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

No semantic characterization of relations satisfying Disjunctive Rationality was known at the time this paper was elaborated. M.Â FreundÂ [10] has now provided a very elegant such characterization together with an alternative proof of our TheoremÂ 5; the canonical model he builds is essentially the same as ours.

3.4 Rational Monotonicity

The last property is the following.

Î±âˆ§Î²Â âˆ¼Ì¸Î³,Î±Â âˆ¼Ì¸Â¬Î²Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Ì¸Î³(ğ‘ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ğšğ¥â¢ğŒğ¨ğ§ğ¨ğ­ğ¨ğ§ğ¢ğœğ¢ğ­ğ²){{\alpha\wedge\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\gamma\ \ ,\ \ \alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\neg\beta}\over{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\gamma}}\hskip 56.9055pt{\rm({\bf Rational\ Monotonicity})}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² âˆ¼Ì¸ italic_Î³ , italic_Î± âˆ¼Ì¸ Â¬ italic_Î² end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¼Ì¸ italic_Î³ end_ARG ( bold_Rational bold_Monotonicity ) (12)

This rule is similar to the thesis CV of conditional logic (seeÂ [25]). The reader is referred toÂ [17, Section 5.4] for a discussion of our claim that reasonable consequence relations should satisfy Rational Monotonicity. Some researchers in Conditional Logic (J.Â Pollock in particular) have objected to CV as a valid thesis for (mainly subjunctive) conditionals. Echoes of this debate may be found inÂ [12, end of Section 4.4]. The objections to CV that hold in the conditional logic framework do not hold for us, though their consideration is recommended to the reader. The most attractive feature of Rational Monotonicity is probably that it says that an agent should not have to retract any previous defeasible conclusion when learning about a new fact the negation of which was not previously derivable. InÂ [32], K.Â Satoh aptly decided to call nonmonotonic reasoning that validates Rational Monotonicity lazy. The rule of Rational Monotonicity should be distinguished from the following rule, which is satisfied by any preferential relation.

Î±âˆ§Î²Â âˆ¼Â¬Î³,Î±Â âˆ¼Ì¸Â¬Î²Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Ì¸Î³{{\alpha\wedge\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\gamma\ \ ,\ \ \alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\neg\beta}\over{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\gamma}}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î³ , italic_Î± âˆ¼Ì¸ Â¬ italic_Î² end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¼Ì¸ italic_Î³ end_ARG (13)
Definition 13

A rational consequence relation is a preferential relation that satisfies Rational Monotonicity.

Two different representation theorems will be proved about rational relations, in SectionsÂ 3.6 and in AppendixÂ B. The last one seems to provide evidence that reasonable inference procedures validate Rational Monotonicity and that all rational relations represent reasonable inference procedures.

Lemma 12

A rational relation satisfies Disjunctive Rationality.

Proof: Suppose Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. By Left Logical Equivalence we have (Î±âˆ¨Î²)âˆ§Î±ğ›¼ğ›½ğ›¼(\alpha\vee\beta)\wedge\alpha( italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² ) âˆ§ italic_Î± Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. If we have Î±âˆ¨Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\vee\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ Â¬â¢Î±ğ›¼\neg\alphaÂ¬ italic_Î±, then we could conclude by Rational Monotonicity that Î±âˆ¨Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\vee\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. Suppose then that Î±âˆ¨Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\vee\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î±ğ›¼\neg\alphaÂ¬ italic_Î±. If we had Î±âˆ¨Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\vee\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, we would conclude by preferential reasoning that Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Lemma 13 (David Makinson)

There is a preferential relation satisfying Disjunctive Rationality that is not rational.

Proof: We shall build a preferential model that defines a consequence relation satisfying Disjunctive Rationality but not Rational Monotonicity. Let â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L be the propositional calculus on the three variables: p0subscriptğ‘0p_{0}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, p1subscriptğ‘1p_{1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, p2subscriptğ‘2p_{2}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let ğ’°ğ’°{\cal U}caligraphic_U contain all propositional worlds on those variables. Let Sğ‘†Sitalic_S contain three elements: sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for i=0,1,2ğ‘–012i=0,1,2italic_i = 0 , 1 , 2 and lâ¢(si)ğ‘™subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–l(s_{i})italic_l ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) satisfy only pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The partial order â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º is such that s1â‰ºs2precedessubscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ 2s_{1}\prec s_{2}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰º italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and no other pair satisfies the relation. This defines a preferential model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W. First we shall show that the consequence relation defined by Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W does not satisfy Rational Monotonicity. Indeed, we have both p0âˆ¨p1âˆ¨p2subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2p_{0}\vee p_{1}\vee p_{2}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â¬â¢p2subscriptğ‘2\neg p_{2}Â¬ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and p0âˆ¨p1âˆ¨p2subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2p_{0}\vee p_{1}\vee p_{2}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â âˆ¼Ì¸Wsubscriptnot-similar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}âˆ¼Ì¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT p1subscriptğ‘1p_{1}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Nevertheless, we also have Â¬â¢p1âˆ§(p0âˆ¨p1âˆ¨p2)subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘0subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2\neg p_{1}\wedge(p_{0}\vee p_{1}\vee p_{2})Â¬ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ§ ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¨ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) Â âˆ¼Ì¸Wsubscriptnot-similar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}âˆ¼Ì¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â¬â¢p2subscriptğ‘2\neg p_{2}Â¬ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let us show now that any preferential model that does not satisfy Disjunctive Rationality must have at least 4444 states. Suppose Î±âˆ¨Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\vee\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, but Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³. The last two assumptions imply the existence of states ağ‘aitalic_a and bğ‘bitalic_b, minimal in Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG and Î²^^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG respectively and that do not satisfy Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, and therefore are not minimal in Î±âˆ¨Î²^^ğ›¼ğ›½\widehat{\alpha\vee\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² end_ARG. Those states are different, since any state minimal in both Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG and Î²^^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG would be minimal in Î±âˆ¨Î²^^ğ›¼ğ›½\widehat{\alpha\vee\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² end_ARG. By the smoothness condition there must be a state aâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²a^{\prime}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT minimal in Î±âˆ¨Î²^^ğ›¼ğ›½\widehat{\alpha\vee\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² end_ARG and such that aâ€²â‰ºaprecedessuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘a^{\prime}\prec aitalic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰º italic_a. Clearly aâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²a^{\prime}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and does not satisfy Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± (since ağ‘aitalic_a is minimal in Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG) but satisfies Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². Similarly there must be a state bâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²b^{\prime}italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT minimal in Î±âˆ¨Î²^^ğ›¼ğ›½\widehat{\alpha\vee\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² end_ARG and such that bâ€²â‰ºbprecedessuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘b^{\prime}\prec bitalic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰º italic_b and bâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²b^{\prime}italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and does not satisfy Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², but satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. It is left to show that all four states are different. We have already noticed that aâ‰ bğ‘ğ‘a\not=bitalic_a â‰  italic_b. The states aâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²a^{\prime}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and bâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²b^{\prime}italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfy Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and are therefore different from ağ‘aitalic_a and bğ‘bitalic_b. But bâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²b^{\prime}italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± and aâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²a^{\prime}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT does not and therefore aâ€²â‰ bâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²superscriptğ‘â€²a^{\prime}\not=b^{\prime}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

3.5 Discussion of Preferential Entailment

We may now assess preferential entailment as a possible answer to the question of the title. CorollaryÂ 2 explains why the notion of preferential entailment cannot be the one we are looking for: the relation ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be any preferential relation and is not in general rational. For typical Kâ€™s, ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT fails to satisfy a large number of instances of Rational Monotonicity and is therefore highly unsuitable. One particularly annoying instance of this is the following. Suppose a conditional knowledge base K contains one single assertion pğ‘pitalic_p Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ qğ‘qitalic_q where pğ‘pitalic_p and qğ‘qitalic_q are different propositional variables. Let rğ‘Ÿritalic_r be a propositional variable, different from pğ‘pitalic_p and qğ‘qitalic_q. We intuitively expect the assertion pâˆ§rğ‘ğ‘Ÿp\wedge ritalic_p âˆ§ italic_r Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ qğ‘qitalic_q to follow from K. The rationale for that has been discussed extensively in the literature and boils down to this: since we have no information whatsoever about the influence of rğ‘Ÿritalic_r on objects satisfying pğ‘pitalic_p it is sensible to assume that it has no influence and that there are normal pğ‘pitalic_p-objects that satisfy rğ‘Ÿritalic_r. The normal pâˆ§rğ‘ğ‘Ÿp\wedge ritalic_p âˆ§ italic_r-objects are therefore normal pğ‘pitalic_p-objects and have all the properties enjoyed by normal pğ‘pitalic_p-objects. Nevertheless it is easy to check that pâˆ§rğ‘ğ‘Ÿp\wedge ritalic_p âˆ§ italic_r Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ qğ‘qitalic_q is not in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The problem lies, at least in part, with the fact that ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not rational, since any rational relation containing pğ‘pitalic_p Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ qğ‘qitalic_q , must contain pâˆ§rğ‘ğ‘Ÿp\wedge ritalic_p âˆ§ italic_r Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ qğ‘qitalic_q unless it contains pğ‘pitalic_p Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢rğ‘Ÿ\neg rÂ¬ italic_r.

In conclusion, it seems that the set of conditional assertions entailed by K should be larger and more monotonic than the set ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. It should also be rational. This question will be brought up again in SectionÂ 5 and a solution will be proposed.

3.6 Ranked models and a representation theorem for rational relations

In this section a family of preferential models will be defined and it will be shown that the relations defined by models of this family are exactly the rational relations.

Lemma 14

If â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º is a partial order on a set Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V, the following conditions are equivalent.

  1. 1.

    for any x,y,zâˆˆVğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘‰x,y,z\in Vitalic_x , italic_y , italic_z âˆˆ italic_V if xâŠ€ynot-precedesğ‘¥ğ‘¦x\not\prec yitalic_x âŠ€ italic_y, yâŠ€xnot-precedesğ‘¦ğ‘¥y\not\prec xitalic_y âŠ€ italic_x and zâ‰ºxprecedesğ‘§ğ‘¥z\prec xitalic_z â‰º italic_x, then zâ‰ºyprecedesğ‘§ğ‘¦z\prec yitalic_z â‰º italic_y

  2. 2.

    for any x,y,zâˆˆVğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘‰x,y,z\in Vitalic_x , italic_y , italic_z âˆˆ italic_V if xâ‰ºyprecedesğ‘¥ğ‘¦x\prec yitalic_x â‰º italic_y, then, either zâ‰ºyprecedesğ‘§ğ‘¦z\prec yitalic_z â‰º italic_y or xâ‰ºzprecedesğ‘¥ğ‘§x\prec zitalic_x â‰º italic_z

  3. 3.

    for any x,y,zâˆˆVğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘‰x,y,z\in Vitalic_x , italic_y , italic_z âˆˆ italic_V if xâŠ€ynot-precedesğ‘¥ğ‘¦x\not\prec yitalic_x âŠ€ italic_y and yâŠ€znot-precedesğ‘¦ğ‘§y\not\prec zitalic_y âŠ€ italic_z, then xâŠ€znot-precedesğ‘¥ğ‘§x\not\prec zitalic_x âŠ€ italic_z

  4. 4.

    there is a totally ordered set Î©Î©\Omegaroman_Î© (the strict order on Î©Î©\Omegaroman_Î© will be denoted by <<<) and a function r:Vâ†¦Î©normal-:ğ‘Ÿmaps-toğ‘‰normal-Î©r:V\mapsto\Omegaitalic_r : italic_V â†¦ roman_Î© (the ranking function) such that sâ‰ºtprecedesğ‘ ğ‘¡s\prec titalic_s â‰º italic_t iff râ¢(s)<râ¢(t)ğ‘Ÿğ‘ ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡r(s)<r(t)italic_r ( italic_s ) < italic_r ( italic_t ).

The proof is simple and will not be given. A partial order satisfying any of the conditions of LemmaÂ 14 will be called modular (this terminology is proposed inÂ [12] as an extension of the notion of modular lattice ofÂ [13]).

Definition 14

A ranked model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is a preferential model âŸ¨V,l,â‰ºâŸ©ğ‘‰ğ‘™precedes\langle V,l,\prec\rangleâŸ¨ italic_V , italic_l , â‰º âŸ© for which the strict partial order â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º is modular.

Those models are called ranked since the effect of function rğ‘Ÿritalic_r of propertyÂ 4 of LemmaÂ 14 is to rank the states: a state of smaller rank being more normal than a state of higher rank. We shall always suppose that a ranked model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W comes equipped with a totally ordered set Î©Î©\Omegaroman_Î© and a ranking function rğ‘Ÿritalic_r. Notice that we still require Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W to satisfy the smoothness condition. It is easy to see that for any subset Tğ‘‡Titalic_T of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V and any tâˆˆTğ‘¡ğ‘‡t\in Titalic_t âˆˆ italic_T, tğ‘¡titalic_t is minimal in Tğ‘‡Titalic_T iff râ¢(t)ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡r(t)italic_r ( italic_t ) is the minimum of the set râ¢(T)ğ‘Ÿğ‘‡r(T)italic_r ( italic_T ). It follows that all minimal elements of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T have the same image by rğ‘Ÿritalic_r. The smoothness condition is then equivalent to the following: for any formula Î±âˆˆLğ›¼ğ¿\alpha\in Litalic_Î± âˆˆ italic_L, if Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG is not empty, the set râ¢(Î±^)ğ‘Ÿ^ğ›¼r(\widehat{\alpha})italic_r ( over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG ) has a minimum. The smoothness condition is always verified if Î©Î©\Omegaroman_Î© is a well-ordered set. The reader may check that the preferential model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W defined in the proof of LemmaÂ 1 is ranked (it is even totally ordered). It follows that there are rational relations that are defined by no well-founded ranked model. The following is a soundness result.

Lemma 15

If Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is a ranked model, the consequence relation Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT it defines is rational.

Proof: It is enough to show that Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies Rational Monotonicity. For this, the smoothness condition is not needed; it is needed, though, for the soundness of Cautious Monotonicity. Suppose Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is a ranked model. We shall use the notations of DefinitionÂ 14. Suppose also that Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼Ì¸Wsubscriptnot-similar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}âˆ¼Ì¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â¬â¢Î²ğ›½\neg\betaÂ¬ italic_Î². From this last assumption we conclude that there is a minimal element of Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG that satisfies Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². Let tâˆˆVğ‘¡ğ‘‰t\in Vitalic_t âˆˆ italic_V be such a state. Let sâˆˆVğ‘ ğ‘‰s\in Vitalic_s âˆˆ italic_V be a minimal element of Î±âˆ§Î²^^ğ›¼ğ›½\widehat{\alpha\wedge\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² end_ARG. Since tâˆˆÎ±âˆ§Î²^ğ‘¡^ğ›¼ğ›½t\in\widehat{\alpha\wedge\beta}italic_t âˆˆ over^ start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² end_ARG, tâŠ€snot-precedesğ‘¡ğ‘ t\not\prec sitalic_t âŠ€ italic_s and râ¢(s)â‰¤râ¢(t)ğ‘Ÿğ‘ ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡r(s)\leq r(t)italic_r ( italic_s ) â‰¤ italic_r ( italic_t ). But this implies that sğ‘ sitalic_s is minimal in Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG: any state uğ‘¢uitalic_u such that uâ‰ºsprecedesğ‘¢ğ‘ u\prec sitalic_u â‰º italic_s satisfies râ¢(u)<râ¢(s)ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘Ÿğ‘ r(u)<r(s)italic_r ( italic_u ) < italic_r ( italic_s ) and therefore râ¢(u)<râ¢(t)ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡r(u)<r(t)italic_r ( italic_u ) < italic_r ( italic_t ) and uâ‰ºtprecedesğ‘¢ğ‘¡u\prec titalic_u â‰º italic_t. Since Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, sâ¢Â â‰¡Î³ğ‘ Â ğ›¾s\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv\gammaitalic_s â‰¡ italic_Î³. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

We shall show now that the converse of LemmaÂ 15 holds. We shall first mention four derived rules of preferential logic. In fact the first three of these rules are even valid in cumulative logic (seeÂ [17, Section 3]). Their proof (either proof-theoretic or model-theoretic) is straightforward and is omitted.

Lemma 16

The following rules are derived rules of preferential logic:

Î±â¢Â âˆ¼ğŸğšğ¥ğ¬ğÎ±âˆ§Î²â¢Â âˆ¼ğŸğšğ¥ğ¬ğsimilar-toğ›¼Â ğŸğšğ¥ğ¬ğsimilar-toğ›¼ğ›½Â ğŸğšğ¥ğ¬ğ{{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim{\bf false}}\over{\alpha\wedge\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim{\bf false}}}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¼ bold_false end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² âˆ¼ bold_false end_ARG (14)
Î±âˆ¨Î²â¢Â âˆ¼Â¬â¢Î²Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â¬â¢Î²similar-toğ›¼ğ›½Â ğ›½similar-toğ›¼Â ğ›½{{\alpha\vee\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\beta}\over{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\beta}}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î² end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î² end_ARG (15)
Î±âˆ¨Î²âˆ¨Î³â¢Â âˆ¼Â¬â¢Î±âˆ§Â¬â¢Î²Î²âˆ¨Î³â¢Â âˆ¼Â¬â¢Î²similar-toğ›¼ğ›½ğ›¾Â ğ›¼ğ›½similar-toğ›½ğ›¾Â ğ›½{{\alpha\vee\beta\vee\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\alpha\wedge\neg\beta}\over{\beta\vee\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\beta}}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² âˆ¨ italic_Î³ âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î± âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î² end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î² âˆ¨ italic_Î³ âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î² end_ARG (16)
Î±âˆ¨Î²â¢Â âˆ¼Â¬â¢Î±Î±âˆ¨Î²âˆ¨Î³â¢Â âˆ¼Â¬â¢Î±similar-toğ›¼ğ›½Â ğ›¼similar-toğ›¼ğ›½ğ›¾Â ğ›¼{{\alpha\vee\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\alpha}\over{\alpha\vee\beta\vee\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\alpha}}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î± end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² âˆ¨ italic_Î³ âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î± end_ARG (17)

We shall now derive a property of rational relations.

Lemma 17

If Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ is a rational relation, then the following rule is valid:

Î±âˆ¨Î³Â âˆ¼Â¬Î±,Î²âˆ¨Î³Â âˆ¼Ì¸Â¬Î²Î±âˆ¨Î²â¢Â âˆ¼Â¬â¢Î±{{\alpha\vee\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\alpha\ \ ,\ \ \beta\vee\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\sim\neg\beta}\over{\alpha\vee\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\alpha}}divide start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î³ âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î± , italic_Î² âˆ¨ italic_Î³ âˆ¼Ì¸ Â¬ italic_Î² end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î± end_ARG (18)

Proof: From the first hypothesis, by RuleÂ 17 one deduces Î±âˆ¨Î²âˆ¨Î³ğ›¼ğ›½ğ›¾\alpha\vee\beta\vee\gammaitalic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² âˆ¨ italic_Î³ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î±ğ›¼\neg\alphaÂ¬ italic_Î±. From the second hypothesis, by RuleÂ 16 one deduces Î±âˆ¨Î²âˆ¨Î³ğ›¼ğ›½ğ›¾\alpha\vee\beta\vee\gammaitalic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² âˆ¨ italic_Î³ Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ Â¬â¡(Î±âˆ¨Î²)ğ›¼ğ›½\neg(\alpha\vee\beta)Â¬ ( italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² ). If one applies now Rational Monotonicity, one gets the desired conclusion. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

For the completeness result, we proceed in the style of L.Â Henkin. Completeness proofs in this style have been used in conditional logics sinceÂ [34]. Since a number of technical lemmas are needed, we have relegated them to AppendixÂ A and state here the characterization theorem.

Theorem 5

A binary relation Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ on â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is a rational consequence relation iff it is the consequence relation defined by some ranked model. If the language â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is logically finite, then every rational consequence relation is defined by some finite ranked model.

Proof: The if part is LemmaÂ 15. For the only if part, let Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ be a consequence relation satisfying the rules of R. The relation Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ defines a structure Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W as described in AppendixÂ A. By LemmasÂ 41 and 36, Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is a ranked model. We claim that, for any Î±,Î²âˆˆLğ›¼ğ›½ğ¿\alpha,\beta\in Litalic_Î± , italic_Î² âˆˆ italic_L, Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² iff Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². Suppose first Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². By LemmaÂ 42, if <m,Î²><m,\beta>< italic_m , italic_Î² > is minimal in Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG, then mğ‘šmitalic_m is normal for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. We conclude that mâŠ§Î²modelsğ‘šğ›½m\models\betaitalic_m âŠ§ italic_Î² and <m,Î²>Â â‰¡Î²formulae-sequenceabsentğ‘šğ›½Â ğ›½<m,\beta>\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv\beta< italic_m , italic_Î² > â‰¡ italic_Î². Therefore Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². Suppose now that Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². Let mğ‘šmitalic_m be a normal world for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. By CorollaryÂ 7, the pair <m,Î±><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_Î± > is minimal in Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG and therefore mâŠ§Î²modelsğ‘šğ›½m\models\betaitalic_m âŠ§ italic_Î². All normal worlds for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± therefore satisfy Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² and LemmaÂ 8 of [17] implies that Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². For the last sentence of the theorem, notice that, if the language â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is logically finite, the model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is finite. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

As we remarked just prior to LemmaÂ 15, the theorem would not hold had we required models to be well-founded.

3.7 Comparison with Delgrandeâ€™s work

The system of proof-rules and the models presented above may be compared with the results of J. Delgrande inÂ [7, 8]. The general thrust is very similar but differences are worth noticing. A first difference is in the language used. Delgrandeâ€™s language differs from this paperâ€™s in three respects: his work is specifically tailored to first-order predicate calculus, whereas this work deals with propositional calculus; he allows negation and disjunction of conditional assertions, which are not allowed in this paper; he allows nesting of conditional operators in the language, though his completeness result is formulated only for unnested formulas. Therefore Delgrandeâ€™s central completeness result in [7], only shows that any proposition in which there is no nesting of conditional operators (let us call those propositions flat) that is valid has a proof from the axioms and rules of his system. But this proof may use propositions that are not flat. The completeness results reported here show that valid assertions have proofs that contain only flat assertions.

A second difference is that Delgrandeâ€™s logical system is different from ours: Delgrandeâ€™s logic N does not contain Cautious Monotonicity. Our class of ranked models is more restricted than his class of models: our models are required to obey the smoothness condition and Delgrandeâ€™s are not. One may also notice that our logic enjoys the finite model property, but Delgrandeâ€™s does not. This difference between our two logical systems may sound insignificant when one remarks that many instances of the rule of Cautious Monotonicity may be derived from Rational Monotonicity, and are therefore valid in Delgrandeâ€™s system N. What we mean is that if Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ then, if Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ Â¬â¢Î²ğ›½\neg\betaÂ¬ italic_Î² one may conclude Î±âˆ§Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ by Rational Monotonicity rather than by Cautious Monotonicity. But if Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î²ğ›½\neg\betaÂ¬ italic_Î², and therefore Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false one cannot conclude. The RuleÂ 14 is sound in preferential logic but not in Delgrandeâ€™s logic. A proof will soon be given. We want to remark here that RuleÂ (14) is very natural, since the meaning of Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false is that if Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is true than anything may be true. It therefore means that it is absolutely unthinkable that Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± be true. In such a case we would expect Î±âˆ§Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² to be also absolutely unthinkable.

Let us show now that RuleÂ (14) is not valid for Delgrandeâ€™s structures. Consider the following structure. Let the set Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V consists of one infinite descending chain: â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º is a total ordering. Suppose now that the top element of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V is the only state that satisfies the propositional variable pğ‘pitalic_p. In this structure ğ­ğ«ğ®ğ^^ğ­ğ«ğ®ğ\widehat{\bf true}over^ start_ARG bold_true end_ARG is Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V and has no minimal element, therefore ğ­ğ«ğ®ğâ¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢ğŸğšğ¥ğ¬ğğ­ğ«ğ®ğÂ âˆ¼Â ğŸğšğ¥ğ¬ğ{\bf true}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }{\bf false}bold_true âˆ¼ bold_false. But p^^ğ‘\widehat{p}over^ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG consists only of the top element and has a minimal point and therefore pğ‘pitalic_p Â âˆ¼Ì¸not-similar-toÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\not\simâˆ¼Ì¸ false. We have shown that the RuleÂ 14 is not valid for Delgrandeâ€™s structures. This example also shows that Delgrandeâ€™s logic does not posses the finite model property.

A third difference is that his definition of the set of conditional assertions entailed by a conditional knowledge base is different from the one presented here, at least at first sight.

4 Ranked entailment

4.1 Introduction

After having defined the family of relations and the family of models we are interested in, we proceed to study the notion of entailment provided by those models. Our main result is presented inÂ 4.2. It is negative, in the sense that this entailment is equivalent to preferential entailment. A preliminary version of this result may be found inÂ [19]. The collapsing of the two notions of entailment, as opposed to the two different classes of relations represented, sheds a new light on the results ofÂ [1]. SectionÂ 4.3 describes the probabilistic semantics given to preferential entailment by E.Â Adams inÂ [1] and shows how the result of SectionÂ 4.2 provides an alternative proof for Adamsâ€™ results. The results of this section were contained inÂ [19].

4.2 Ranked entailment is preferential entailment

In the discussion of SectionÂ 3.5, we expressed the wish that the set of assertions entailed by a conditional knowledge base KÂ be rational and larger than ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A natural candidate would be the set of all assertions that are satisfied in all ranked models that satisfy the assertions of K. This is an intersection of rational relations. This proposal fails in a spectacular way. Problems with this proposal have been noted inÂ [8, Section 4]. It is also easy to see that the intersection of rational relations may fail to be rational. TheoremÂ 6 shows this failure to be total.

Lemma 18

Let â„°â„°{\cal E}caligraphic_EÂ be any preferential relation. There exists a rational extension of â„°â„°{\cal E}caligraphic_EÂ for which a formula is inconsistent only if it is inconsistent for â„°â„°{\cal E}caligraphic_E.

Proof: Let us choose some enumeration of triples of formulas Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â and Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â in which every triple appears an unbounded number of times. Let K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be equal to â„°â„°{\cal E}caligraphic_E. At every step iğ‘–iitalic_i we define Ki+1subscriptğ¾ğ‘–1K_{i+1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the following way. Let Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â and Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â be the triple enumerated at step iğ‘–iitalic_i. Unless Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains the pair Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ but contains neither Î±âˆ§Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ nor Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î²ğ›½\neg\betaÂ¬ italic_Î², we shall take Ki+1subscriptğ¾ğ‘–1K_{i+1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be equal to Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies the condition above, we shall take Ki+1subscriptğ¾ğ‘–1K_{i+1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be the preferential closure of Kiâˆª{Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î²}subscriptğ¾ğ‘–Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î²K_{i}\cup\{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}\}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆª { roman_Î± âˆ¼ roman_Î² }. Notice that, by Cautious Monotonicity, Î±âˆ§Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ will enter Ki+1subscriptğ¾ğ‘–1K_{i+1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It is clear that the Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s provide an increasing sequence of preferential extensions of â„°â„°{\cal E}caligraphic_E. Let Kâˆsubscriptğ¾K_{\infty}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the union of all the Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s. Clearly Kâˆsubscriptğ¾K_{\infty}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a preferential extension of â„°â„°{\cal E}caligraphic_E. By construction, and since we took care of removing all counter-examples to the rule of Rational Monotonicity, Kâˆsubscriptğ¾K_{\infty}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a rational consequence relation. We claim that a formula Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is inconsistent for Kâˆsubscriptğ¾K_{\infty}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false is in Kâˆsubscriptğ¾K_{\infty}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) only if it is inconsistent already for â„°â„°{\cal E}caligraphic_E. Indeed, if Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is inconsistent for Kâˆsubscriptğ¾K_{\infty}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT it must be inconsistent for some Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but TheoremÂ 3 shows that, by construction, all Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s have the same inconsistent formulas. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Theorem 6

If the assertion ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_AÂ is satisfied by all ranked models that satisfy all the assertions of K, then it is satisfied by all preferential such models.

Proof: Let ğ’œ=defÎ´â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Îµsuperscriptdefğ’œğ›¿Â âˆ¼Â ğœ€{\cal A}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\delta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\varepsiloncaligraphic_A start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP italic_Î´ âˆ¼ italic_Îµ be as in the hypotheses. Let â„°â„°{\cal E}caligraphic_EÂ be the rational extension of the preferential closure of ğŠâˆª{Î´â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Â¬â¢Îµ}ğŠğ›¿Â âˆ¼Â ğœ€{\bf K}\cup\{\delta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\neg\varepsilon\}bold_K âˆª { italic_Î´ âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Îµ }, whose existence is asserted by LemmaÂ 18. The assertion Î´â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Îµğ›¿Â âˆ¼Â ğœ€\delta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\varepsilonitalic_Î´ âˆ¼ italic_Îµ is in â„°â„°{\cal E}caligraphic_EÂ since it is in any rational relation that extends K, by TheoremÂ 5. Since Î´â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Â¬â¢Îµğ›¿Â âˆ¼Â ğœ€\delta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\neg\varepsilonitalic_Î´ âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Îµ is obviously in â„°â„°{\cal E}caligraphic_E, we conclude that Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ is inconsistent for â„°â„°{\cal E}caligraphic_EÂ and therefore inconsistent for the preferential closure of ğŠâˆª{Î´â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Â¬â¢Îµ}ğŠğ›¿Â âˆ¼Â ğœ€{\bf K}\cup\{\delta\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\neg\varepsilon\}bold_K âˆª { italic_Î´ âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Îµ }. By CorollaryÂ 3, ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_AÂ is preferentially entailed by K. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

4.3 Comparison with Adamsâ€™ probabilistic entailment

In this section we shall show that ranked models are closely related to Adamsâ€™ probabilistic entailment described inÂ [1]. TheoremÂ 6, then, provides an alternative proof of Adamsâ€™ axiomatic characterization of probabilistic entailment. There are some technical differences between Adamsâ€™ framework and ours since Adams insists on allowing formulas as conditional assertions: for him the formula Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is a synonym for true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. We also insist on studying infinite knowledge bases whenever possible, where Adams restricts himself to finite knowledge bases.

A probability assignment for the language â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is a probability measure on â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L yielded by some probability measure given on ğ’°ğ’°{\cal U}caligraphic_U. E.Â Adams proposed the following definitions.

Definition 15 (Adams)

A probability assignment pğ‘pitalic_p for the language â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is said to be proper for a conditional assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² iff pâ¢(Î±)>0ğ‘ğ›¼0p(\alpha)>0italic_p ( italic_Î± ) > 0. It is proper for a set of conditional assertions iff it is proper for each element. If pğ‘pitalic_p is proper for ğ’œ=defÎ±superscriptnormal-defğ’œğ›¼{\cal A}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\alphacaligraphic_A start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP italic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², we shall use pâ¢(ğ’œ)ğ‘ğ’œp({\cal A})italic_p ( caligraphic_A ) to denote the conditional probability pâ¢(Î²âˆ£Î±)ğ‘conditionalğ›½ğ›¼p(\beta\mid\alpha)italic_p ( italic_Î² âˆ£ italic_Î± ).

Definition 16 (Adams)

Let K be a set of conditional assertions. We shall say that K is probabilistically consistent if and only if for any real number Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0 there exists a probability assignment pğ‘pitalic_p for â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L that is proper for K and such that, for all ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A in K, one has pâ¢(ğ’œ)â‰¥1âˆ’Ïµğ‘ğ’œ1italic-Ïµp({\cal A})\geq 1-\epsilonitalic_p ( caligraphic_A ) â‰¥ 1 - italic_Ïµ.

Definition 17

Let K be a set of conditional assertions and ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A a conditional assertion. We shall say that K probabilistically entails ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A iff for all Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0 there exists Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0italic_Î´ > 0 such that for all probability assignments pğ‘pitalic_p for â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L which are proper for K and ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A, if pâ¢(â„¬)â‰¥1âˆ’Î´ğ‘â„¬1ğ›¿p({\cal B})\geq 1-\deltaitalic_p ( caligraphic_B ) â‰¥ 1 - italic_Î´ for all â„¬â„¬{\cal B}caligraphic_B in K, then pâ¢(ğ’œ)â‰¥1âˆ’Ïµğ‘ğ’œ1italic-Ïµp({\cal A})\geq 1-\epsilonitalic_p ( caligraphic_A ) â‰¥ 1 - italic_Ïµ.

In [1], Adams studies extensively the relations between the two notions of probabilistic consistency and probabilistic entailment, at least for finite sets of conditional assertions. Here we shall only show the fundamental relation that exists between Adamsâ€™ notions and ours. First, we shall make three easy remarks. The first one concerns only probabilistic notions and was claimed by Adams for finite knowledge bases but is true in general.

Lemma 19

A set K of conditional assertions is probabilistically inconsistent iff it probabilistically entails any conditional assertion.

Our second remark provides a first link between probabilistic notions and the notions introduced in this paper. It is essentially the soundness part of Adamsâ€™ soundness and completeness result (see beginning of proof of 4.2 at page 62 ofÂ [1]). This is the easy direction.

Lemma 20

Any conditional assertion preferentially entailed by K is probabilistically entailed by K.

Our third remark is the following.

Lemma 21

If the conditional assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² is in K and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false is preferentially entailed by K then K is probabilistically inconsistent.

Proof: Under the assumptions of the lemma, LemmaÂ 20 shows that Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false is probabilistically entailed by K. But for any probability assignment pğ‘pitalic_p that is proper for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², pâ¢(Î±â¢Â âˆ¼ğŸğšğ¥ğ¬ğ)ğ‘similar-toğ›¼Â ğŸğšğ¥ğ¬ğp(\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim{\bf false})italic_p ( italic_Î± âˆ¼ bold_false ) is defined and equal to 00. Since K probabilistically entails Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false we conclude that there is an Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0 such that no probability assignment that is proper for K and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² gives probabilities larger than 1âˆ’Ïµ1italic-Ïµ1-\epsilon1 - italic_Ïµ to all assertions of K. Since any probability assignment that is proper for K is also proper for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² the conclusion is proved. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

We shall now prove the converse of LemmaÂ 20 in the case K is finite and probabilistically consistent. The basic remark is the following. Suppose Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is a finite (i.e., the set Sğ‘†Sitalic_S of states is finite) ranked model. Let Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0 be some real number. We shall describe a probability measure pÏµsubscriptğ‘italic-Ïµp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on Sğ‘†Sitalic_S. The first principle that will be used in defining pÏµsubscriptğ‘italic-Ïµp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is that all states of the same rank will have equal probabilities. The second principle is that the weight of the set of all states of rank nğ‘›nitalic_n, wnsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›w_{n}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will be such that wn+1wn=Ïµsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘›italic-Ïµ{w_{n+1}\over w_{n}}=\epsilondivide start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = italic_Ïµ. The intuitive meaning of this choice (since Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ will approach zero) is that normal states are more probable than exceptional states. There is clearly exactly one probability measure satisfying both principles above, for any given finite ranked model. The probability measure pÏµsubscriptğ‘italic-Ïµp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, defined on states, yields a probability measure on formulas. It is clear that a formula Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± has probability zero under pÏµsubscriptğ‘italic-Ïµp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT iff Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is inconsistent in Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, i.e., Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT false. Suppose Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is consistent. Let us consider the conditional probability of Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² given Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, which is well defined. If Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼Wsubscriptsimilar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim_{W}âˆ¼ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² then this conditional probability is larger than 1âˆ’Ïµâˆ’Ïµ2âˆ’Ïµ3âˆ’â€¦1italic-Ïµsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ2superscriptitalic-Ïµ3â€¦1-\epsilon-\epsilon^{2}-\epsilon^{3}-\dots1 - italic_Ïµ - italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - â€¦ and therefore approaches one when Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ approaches zero. On the other hand, if Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼Ì¸Wsubscriptnot-similar-toğ‘ŠÂ absent\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}{\not\sim}_{W}âˆ¼Ì¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², then this conditional probability cannot exceed 1âˆ’1m11ğ‘š1-{1\over m}1 - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG where mğ‘šmitalic_m is the number of states at the rank which is minimal for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. It is therefore bounded away from 1111 when Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ approaches 00.

Lemma 22

Let a finite probabilistically consistent knowledge base K be given and suppose ğ’œ=defÎ±superscriptnormal-defğ’œğ›¼{\cal A}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\alphacaligraphic_A start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP italic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² is not preferentially entailed by K. Then, K does not probabilistically entail ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A.

Proof: Let K and ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A be as described in the lemma. Let â„’â€²superscriptâ„’â€²{\cal L^{\prime}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be some logically finite sublanguage of â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L that contains Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² and all propositions appearing in K. Relative to â„’â€²superscriptâ„’â€²{\cal L^{\prime}}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the hypotheses of the lemma are still true. By LemmasÂ 18 and TheoremÂ 3, there is a rational relation â„°â„°{\cal E}caligraphic_EÂ that contains KÂ and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î²ğ›½\neg\betaÂ¬ italic_Î² and for which a formula is inconsistent only if it is inconsistent for ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. By TheoremÂ 5, there is a finite ranked model, Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W that satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î²ğ›½\neg\betaÂ¬ italic_Î² and all assertions of K but whose inconsistent formulas are exactly those of ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Since Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is not inconsistent for ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W does not satisfy Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². Let Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the model obtained by extending the labeling function of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W to the full language â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L in an arbitrary way. We shall now apply the construction of pÏµsubscriptğ‘italic-Ïµp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT described above on the model Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Using the model Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and a sequence of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµâ€™s approaching zero, we define a sequence of probability measures pÏµsubscriptğ‘italic-Ïµp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let us show that all assignments pÏµsubscriptğ‘italic-Ïµp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are proper for K and ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A. If Î³âˆˆLâ€²ğ›¾superscriptğ¿â€²\gamma\in L^{\prime}italic_Î³ âˆˆ italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the assignment pÏµsubscriptğ‘italic-Ïµp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT gives zero probability to Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ iff Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ is inconsistent in Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, i.e., inconsistent for ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. But K is probabilistically consistent and, by LemmaÂ 21, pÏµsubscriptğ‘italic-Ïµp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is proper for K. Since Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT does not satisfy ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A, its antecedent cannot be inconsistent in Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and pÏµsubscriptğ‘italic-Ïµp_{\epsilon}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is proper for ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A too. When Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ approaches zero, the conditional probabilities corresponding to each assertion of K approach 1111 and the conditional probability corresponding to A is bounded away from 1111. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

That the result cannot be extended to infinite sets of conditional assertions follows from Adamsâ€™ remark that his notion of probabilistic consistency does not enjoy the compactness property and from CorollaryÂ 1. Adamsâ€™ exampleÂ [1, pages 51â€“52] is closely related to the construction of LemmaÂ 1. The results of Adams presented in this section have been interpreted, in particular byÂ [26], to mean that probabilistic semantics validate preferential reasoning. We certainly agree. But the results that will be presented now show, in our opinion, that probabilistic semantics support the claim that inference procedures should not only be preferential but also rational. Indeed we show, in AppendixÂ B, that some very natural probabilistic models always define rational relations and that, when the language â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is countable, all rational relations may be defined by such models. Those models are non-standard probability spaces, in the sense of A.Â Robinson. Since no use of those models will be made in the paper, their treatment has been relegated to an appendix.

5 The rational closure of a conditional knowledge base

5.1 Introduction

So far, we have argued for ThesisÂ 1 and gathered much knowledge about rational relations, showing in particular that there is no obvious way to define a notion of closure satisfying ThesisÂ 1. In this section we shall show that there is a natural notion of closure (called rational closure) that satisfies ThesisÂ 1. We shall study it and prove that it possesses many very elegant mathematical properties. We shall, then, evaluate the value of rational closure as an answer to the question of the title. In conclusion, we shall propose ThesisÂ 2, that claims that any satisfactory answer is a superset of rational closure. In other terms we think that any reasonable system should endorse any assertion contained in the rational closure, but it may also endorse some additional assertions. At present, we do not know of any natural construction satisfying ThesisÂ 1 other than rational closure.

A first possible answer is rejected inÂ 5.2. This result appeared inÂ [18]. The remainder of the paper describes rational closure. InÂ 5.3 a partial ordering between rational relations is defined, which captures the notion of a relation being preferable to (i.e., smaller, less adventurous, more reasonable than) another one. The rational closure of a knowledge base is then defined inÂ 5.4 as the rational extension of a knowledge base that is preferable in the ordering defined in SectionÂ 5.3 to all other rational extensions. Not every knowledge base has a rational closure, but in SectionÂ 5.6 it will be shown that any admissible (see DefinitionÂ 11) knowledge base has a rational closure. By LemmaÂ 7, then, any finite knowledge base has a rational closure. We claim that the rational closure of a knowledge base, when it exists, provides a reasonable answer to the question of the title. Global properties of the operation of rational closure are described inÂ 5.5. These results, concerning the global behavior of a nonmonotonic inference operation, are the first of their kind. InÂ 5.6 an algorithmic construction of the rational closure of an admissible knowledge base is described. This algorithmic description essentially replaces and improves upon the proof-theoretic description ofÂ [18]. A corrected and generalized model-theoretic construction, first described inÂ [18] is proposed inÂ 5.7. SectionÂ 5.8 presents an algorithm to compute the rational closure of a finite knowledge base and discusses complexity issues. SectionÂ 5.9 discusses the appeal of rational closure and provides some examples. SectionÂ 6 concludes by considering topics for further research. InÂ [27] J.Â Pearl proposes his own version of the rational closure construction that had been described inÂ [18].

5.2 Perfect extensions

All that has been done so far does not allow us to give a satisfactory answer to the question of the title. Let KÂ be a set of conditional assertions. We would like to define a consequence relation ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG, the rational closure of K, that contains all the conditional assertions that we intuitively expect to follow from K. At this point the reader should be convinced that ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARGÂ should be a rational consequence relation that extends K. Any such relation obviously also extends ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. It seems that we would also like this rational extension of KÂ to be as small as possible. Unfortunately TheoremÂ 6 shows that the intersection of all rational extensions of KÂ is exactly ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTÂ and therefore not in general rational and highly unsuitable as shown in SectionÂ 3.5. There is obviously a maximal such extension: the full consequence relation, (i.e., Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² for all Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² in â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L) but this is certainly not the one we are looking for. Can we find out a number of properties that we would like ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG to possess, in order to, at least, narrow the field of possibilities? We shall look both for local properties of ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARGÂ with respect to KÂ and for global properties of the mapping ğŠâ†¦ğŠÂ¯maps-toğŠÂ¯ğŠ{\bf K}\mapsto\overline{\bf K}bold_K â†¦ overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG. The sequel will present a proposal for the definition of ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARGÂ and proofs that it enjoys both local and global (in particular a strong form of cumulativity) properties.

If ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTÂ happens to be rational, then we probably have no reason to look further and should take ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARGÂ to be equal to ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. If ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTÂ is not rational, then there is an assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and a formula Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â such that neither Î±âˆ§Î³ğ›¼ğ›¾\alpha\wedge\gammaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î³ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² nor Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î³ğ›¾\neg\gammaÂ¬ italic_Î³ are in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. It seems that the right thing to do, in most such cases, is to introduce Î±âˆ§Î³ğ›¼ğ›¾\alpha\wedge\gammaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î³ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² in ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG. One may try to require that any assertion in ğŠÂ¯âˆ’ğŠpÂ¯ğŠsuperscriptğŠğ‘\overline{\bf K}-{\bf K}^{p}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG - bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be of the form Î±âˆ§Î³ğ›¼ğ›¾\alpha\wedge\gammaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î³ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² where Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e., that any assertion in ğŠÂ¯âˆ’ğŠpÂ¯ğŠsuperscriptğŠğ‘\overline{\bf K}-{\bf K}^{p}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG - bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have support in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. It will be shown that this may well be impossible. Let us encapsulate this idea in definitions.

Definition 18

An assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² is said to be supported by (or in) ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iff there is a formula Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â such that Î±âŠ§Î³modelsğ›¼ğ›¾\alpha\models\gammaitalic_Î± âŠ§ italic_Î³ and Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² is in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Definition 19

A rational extension ğŠâ€²superscriptğŠnormal-â€²{\bf K}^{\prime}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of K is called perfect iff every assertion of ğŠâ€²superscriptğŠnormal-â€²{\bf K}^{\prime}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is supported by ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

We may present the following disappointing result.

Lemma 23

There is a finite conditional knowledge base that has no rational perfect extension.

Proof: Let â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L be the set of all propositional formulas built out of the set of four propositional variables: {a,b,c,d}ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘\{a,b,c,d\}{ italic_a , italic_b , italic_c , italic_d }. Let Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W be the preferential model with three states: {s,t,u}ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘¢\{s,t,u\}{ italic_s , italic_t , italic_u }, in which sâ‰ºtprecedesğ‘ ğ‘¡s\prec titalic_s â‰º italic_t (and this is the only pair in the relation â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º) and sğ‘ sitalic_s satisfies only ağ‘aitalic_a, tğ‘¡titalic_t satisfies only bğ‘bitalic_b and uğ‘¢uitalic_u satisfies only cğ‘citalic_c and dğ‘‘ditalic_d. Let K be the set of all conditional assertions satisfied in Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W. We claim that K has no rational perfect extension. Notice, first, that Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W satisfies aâˆ¨bğ‘ğ‘a\vee bitalic_a âˆ¨ italic_b Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢bğ‘\neg bÂ¬ italic_b. This assertion is therefore in K. Any ranked model satisfying aâˆ¨bğ‘ğ‘a\vee bitalic_a âˆ¨ italic_b Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢bğ‘\neg bÂ¬ italic_b must satisfy at least one of the following two assertions: aâˆ¨cğ‘ğ‘a\vee citalic_a âˆ¨ italic_c Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢cğ‘\neg cÂ¬ italic_c or bâˆ¨cğ‘ğ‘b\vee citalic_b âˆ¨ italic_c Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢bğ‘\neg bÂ¬ italic_b. Any rational extension of K must therefore contain one of the two assertions above. But aâˆ¨cğ‘ğ‘a\vee citalic_a âˆ¨ italic_c Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢cğ‘\neg cÂ¬ italic_c has clearly no support in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and therefore any perfect rational extension of K must contain: bâˆ¨cğ‘ğ‘b\vee citalic_b âˆ¨ italic_c Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢bğ‘\neg bÂ¬ italic_b. But Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W satisfies cğ‘citalic_c Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ dğ‘‘ditalic_d and any ranked model satisfying both bâˆ¨cğ‘ğ‘b\vee citalic_b âˆ¨ italic_c Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢bğ‘\neg bÂ¬ italic_b and cğ‘citalic_c Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ dğ‘‘ditalic_d must also satisfy bâˆ¨cğ‘ğ‘b\vee citalic_b âˆ¨ italic_c Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ dğ‘‘ditalic_d. Any perfect rational extension of K must therefore contain this last formula but it clearly lacks support in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We conclude that K has no perfect rational extension. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

It is therefore reasonable to look for less than perfect extensions. Let us first examine perfection concerning two special kinds of formulas. The following is easily proved.

Lemma 24

An assertion of the form Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false is supported by ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iff it is in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. An assertion of the form true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is supported by ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iff it is in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

We shall propose a construction of ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARGÂ such that ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARGÂ does not contain any formula of the form Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false or of the form true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± that is not in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

5.3 Ordering rational relations

In this section we shall define a strict partial ordering between rational relations. This ordering captures the notion of a relation being preferable to, i.e., less adventurous than another one. An intuitive explanation will be given immediately after the definition. For the rest of this section we shall write Î±<Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha<\betaitalic_Î± < italic_Î² for ( or in) K to mean the assertion Î±âˆ¨Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\vee\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î²ğ›½\neg\betaÂ¬ italic_Î² is in Kğ¾Kitalic_K. We shall write Î±â‰¤Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\leq\betaitalic_Î± â‰¤ italic_Î² for ( or in) Kğ¾Kitalic_K when it is not the case that Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²<<<Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± in Kğ¾Kitalic_K.

Definition 20

Let K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be two rational consequence relations. We shall say that K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is preferable to K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and write K0â‰ºK1precedessubscriptğ¾0subscriptğ¾1K_{0}\prec K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰º italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT iff:

  1. 1.

    there exists an assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â in K1âˆ’K0subscriptğ¾1subscriptğ¾0K_{1}-K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that for all Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â such that Î³<Î±ğ›¾ğ›¼\gamma<\alphaitalic_Î³ < italic_Î± for K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and for all Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´Â such that Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ is in K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we also have Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ in K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and

  2. 2.

    for any Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´â€‰ if Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ is in K0âˆ’K1subscriptğ¾0subscriptğ¾1K_{0}-K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT there is an assertion Ïâ¢Â âˆ¼Î·similar-toğœŒÂ ğœ‚\rho\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\etaitalic_Ï âˆ¼ italic_Î· in K1âˆ’K0subscriptğ¾1subscriptğ¾0K_{1}-K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that Ï<Î³ğœŒğ›¾\rho<\gammaitalic_Ï < italic_Î³ for K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The intuitive explanation behind DefinitionÂ 20 is the following. Suppose two agents, who agree on a common knowledge base, are discussing the respective merits of two rational relations K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A typical attack would be: your relation contains an assertion, Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², that mine does not contain (and therefore contains unsupported assertions). A possible defense against such an attack could be: yes, but your relation contains an assertion Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ that mine does not, and you yourself think that Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â refers to a situation that is more usual than the one refered to by Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. Such a defense must be accepted as valid. DefinitionÂ 20 exactly says that the proponent of K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has an attack that the proponent of K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot defend against (this is partÂ 1) but that he (i.e., the proponent of K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) may find a defense against any attack from the proponent of K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (this is partÂ 2 of the definition).

Lemma 25

The relation â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º between rational consequence relations is irreflexive and transitive.

Proof: Irreflexivity follows immediately from ConditionÂ 1. For transitivity, let us suppose that K0â‰ºK1precedessubscriptğ¾0subscriptğ¾1K_{0}\prec K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰º italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â the witness promised by ConditionÂ 1 and that K1â‰ºK2precedessubscriptğ¾1subscriptğ¾2K_{1}\prec K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰º italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´Â as a witness. Our first step will be to show that there exists an assertion Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_ÎµÂ âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶Â in K2âˆ’K0subscriptğ¾2subscriptğ¾0K_{2}-K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that Îµâ‰¤Î±ğœ€ğ›¼\varepsilon\leq\alphaitalic_Îµ â‰¤ italic_Î± in K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Îµâ‰¤Î³ğœ€ğ›¾\varepsilon\leq\gammaitalic_Îµ â‰¤ italic_Î³ in K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We shall have to consider many different cases.

  1. 1.

    Suppose Î³<Î±ğ›¾ğ›¼\gamma<\alphaitalic_Î³ < italic_Î± in K2subscriptğ¾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

    1. (a)

      If Î³<Î±ğ›¾ğ›¼\gamma<\alphaitalic_Î³ < italic_Î± is not in K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then Î³<Î±ğ›¾ğ›¼\gamma<\alphaitalic_Î³ < italic_Î± is a suitable Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_ÎµÂ âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶.

    2. (b)

      If Î³<Î±ğ›¾ğ›¼\gamma<\alphaitalic_Î³ < italic_Î± is in K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´Â is a suitable Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_ÎµÂ âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶, since if it were in K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT it would be in K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Suppose therefore that Î³<Î±ğ›¾ğ›¼\gamma<\alphaitalic_Î³ < italic_Î± is not in K2subscriptğ¾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., for K2subscriptğ¾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Î±â‰¤Î³ğ›¼ğ›¾\alpha\leq\gammaitalic_Î± â‰¤ italic_Î³.

    1. (a)

      If Î³<Î±ğ›¾ğ›¼\gamma<\alphaitalic_Î³ < italic_Î± is in K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it is in K1âˆ’K2subscriptğ¾1subscriptğ¾2K_{1}-K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and there is an assertion Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·Â in K2âˆ’K1subscriptğ¾2subscriptğ¾1K_{2}-K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that Î¾<Î³âˆ¨Î±ğœ‰ğ›¾ğ›¼\xi<\gamma\vee\alphaitalic_Î¾ < italic_Î³ âˆ¨ italic_Î± in K2subscriptğ¾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

      1. i.

        If Î¾<Î³âˆ¨Î±ğœ‰ğ›¾ğ›¼\xi<\gamma\vee\alphaitalic_Î¾ < italic_Î³ âˆ¨ italic_Î± is not in K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it is a suitable Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_ÎµÂ âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶.

      2. ii.

        If Î¾<Î³âˆ¨Î±ğœ‰ğ›¾ğ›¼\xi<\gamma\vee\alphaitalic_Î¾ < italic_Î³ âˆ¨ italic_Î± is in K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then Î¾<Î±ğœ‰ğ›¼\xi<\alphaitalic_Î¾ < italic_Î± in K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and we have both that Î¾<Î³âˆ¨Î±ğœ‰ğ›¾ğ›¼\xi<\gamma\vee\alphaitalic_Î¾ < italic_Î³ âˆ¨ italic_Î± in K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and that Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·Â cannot be in K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, otherwise it would be in K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We conclude that Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·Â is a suitable Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_ÎµÂ âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶.

    2. (b)

      Suppose therefore that Î³<Î±ğ›¾ğ›¼\gamma<\alphaitalic_Î³ < italic_Î± is not in K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., for K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, like for K2subscriptğ¾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Î±â‰¤Î³ğ›¼ğ›¾\alpha\leq\gammaitalic_Î± â‰¤ italic_Î³.

      1. i.

        If Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is in K2subscriptğ¾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it is a suitable Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_ÎµÂ âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶.

      2. ii.

        If Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is not in K2subscriptğ¾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it is in K1âˆ’K2subscriptğ¾1subscriptğ¾2K_{1}-K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and there is a Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·Â in K2âˆ’K1subscriptğ¾2subscriptğ¾1K_{2}-K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that Î¾<Î±ğœ‰ğ›¼\xi<\alphaitalic_Î¾ < italic_Î± in K2subscriptğ¾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

        1. A.

          If Î¾<Î±ğœ‰ğ›¼\xi<\alphaitalic_Î¾ < italic_Î± is not in K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it is a suitable Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_ÎµÂ âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶Â since, in K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Î¾âˆ¨Î±â‰¤Î±â‰¤Î³ğœ‰ğ›¼ğ›¼ğ›¾\xi\vee\alpha\leq\alpha\leq\gammaitalic_Î¾ âˆ¨ italic_Î± â‰¤ italic_Î± â‰¤ italic_Î³.

        2. B.

          If Î¾<Î±ğœ‰ğ›¼\xi<\alphaitalic_Î¾ < italic_Î± is in K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT then Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·Â is a suitable Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_ÎµÂ âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶Â since Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·Â cannot be in K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, otherwise it would be in K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We have now proved the existence of an assertion Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_ÎµÂ âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶Â with the desired properties. Let us proceed to the proof that K0â‰ºK2precedessubscriptğ¾0subscriptğ¾2K_{0}\prec K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰º italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For propertyÂ 1, we claim that Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_ÎµÂ âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î¶ğœ\zetaitalic_Î¶Â provides a suitable witness. This concludes the verification of ConditionÂ 1.

For ConditionÂ 2, suppose that Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï† Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸Â is in K0âˆ’K2subscriptğ¾0subscriptğ¾2K_{0}-K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
