      2. ii.

        Suppose, then that, on the contrary, Îµ<Ï†ğœ€ğœ‘\varepsilon<\varphiitalic_Îµ < italic_Ï† is not in K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., Ï†â‰¤Îµğœ‘ğœ€\varphi\leq\varepsilonitalic_Ï† â‰¤ italic_Îµ in K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as in K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and K2subscriptğ¾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

â€†Â â€†

5.4 Definition of rational closure

We may now define the rational closure of a knowledge base.

Definition 21

Let KÂ be an arbitrary knowledge base. If there is a rational extension ğŠÂ¯normal-Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARGÂ of KÂ that is preferable to all other rational extensions of K, then ğŠÂ¯normal-Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARGÂ will be called the rational closure of K.

Notice first that the rational closure of a knowledge base is unique, if it exists, since preference is a partial ordering. Notice then that there are knowledge bases that do not have a rational closure. ExampleÂ 1 will show this. In SectionÂ 5.6 we shall show that admissible knowledge bases, including all finite knowledge bases, have a rational closure.

Example 1

Let â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L be the propositional calculus built upon the variables pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where nğ‘›nitalic_n is an arbitrary integer (i.e., positive or negative). Let Nğ‘Nitalic_N be the knowledge base that contains all assertions of the form pnâ¢Â âˆ¼pn+2similar-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘›Â subscriptğ‘ğ‘›2p_{n}\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim p_{n+2}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and of the form pnâ¢Â âˆ¼Â¬â¢pnâˆ’2similar-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘›Â subscriptğ‘ğ‘›2p_{n}\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg p_{n-2}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all integers nğ‘›nitalic_n. We shall show that Nğ‘Nitalic_N has no rational closure.

We shall first prove a lemma about invariance of the operation of rational closure under renaming of the proposional variables. This lemma is of independent interest.

Definition 22
  1. 1.

    A renaming of the propositional calculus â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is a bijection of the propositional variables.

  2. 2.

    Let fğ‘“fitalic_f be a renaming of â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L. The formula obtained from Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â by substituting fâ¢(p)ğ‘“ğ‘f(p)italic_f ( italic_p ) for the propositional variable pğ‘pitalic_p will be denoted by fâ¢(Î±)ğ‘“ğ›¼f(\mbox{$\alpha$})italic_f ( italic_Î± ).

  3. 3.

    Let fğ‘“fitalic_f be as above and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â a conditional assertion. The assertion fâ¢(Î±)â¢Â âˆ¼fâ¢(Î²)similar-toğ‘“ğ›¼Â ğ‘“ğ›½f(\mbox{$\alpha$})\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim f(\mbox{$\beta$})italic_f ( italic_Î± ) âˆ¼ italic_f ( italic_Î² ) will be denoted by fâ¢(Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Î²)ğ‘“similar-toğ›¼Â ğ›½f(\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\beta)italic_f ( italic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î² ).

  4. 4.

    Let fğ‘“fitalic_f be as above and Kğ¾Kitalic_K a consequence relation. The relation fâ¢(K)ğ‘“ğ¾f(K)italic_f ( italic_K ) will be defined by fâ¢(K)={fâ¢(Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î²)âˆ£Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î²âˆˆK}ğ‘“ğ¾conditional-setğ‘“Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î²Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î²ğ¾f(K)=\{f(\mbox{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}})\mid\mbox{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}}\in K\}italic_f ( italic_K ) = { italic_f ( italic_Î± italic_âˆ¼ italic_Î² ) âˆ£ italic_Î± italic_âˆ¼ italic_Î² âˆˆ italic_K }.

Lemma 26 (Invariance under renaming)

Let fğ‘“fitalic_f be a renaming of â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L.

  1. 1.

    Let K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be rational consequence relations. Then K0â‰ºK1precedessubscriptğ¾0subscriptğ¾1K_{0}\prec K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰º italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT iff fâ¢(K0)â‰ºfâ¢(K1)precedesğ‘“subscriptğ¾0ğ‘“subscriptğ¾1f(K_{0})\prec f(K_{1})italic_f ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰º italic_f ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

  2. 2.

    Let Kğ¾Kitalic_K be a consequence relation and KÂ¯Â¯ğ¾\overline{K}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_K end_ARG its rational closure ,then fâ¢(KÂ¯)ğ‘“Â¯ğ¾f(\overline{K})italic_f ( overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ) is the rational closure of fâ¢(K)ğ‘“ğ¾f(K)italic_f ( italic_K )

  3. 3.

    Let Kğ¾Kitalic_K be a consequence relation which is invariant under fğ‘“fitalic_f, namely fâ¢(K)=Kğ‘“ğ¾ğ¾f(K)=Kitalic_f ( italic_K ) = italic_K,then its rational closure (if it exists) is invariant under fğ‘“fitalic_f.

Proof: The proof is immediate from the definitions, noting that fğ‘“fitalic_f is also a bijection of the set of all consequence relations. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Lemma 27

The knowledge base Nğ‘Nitalic_N defined above has no rational closure.

Proof: We shall reason by contradiction. Suppose Rğ‘…Ritalic_R is the rational closure of Nğ‘Nitalic_N. From LemmaÂ 30 in the sequel (the proof of which does not depend on the present lemma), we know that there is no assertion of the form Î±Â âˆ¼Â â¢ğŸğšğ¥ğ¬ğÎ±Â âˆ¼Â ğŸğšğ¥ğ¬ğ\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }{\bf false}roman_Î± âˆ¼ bold_false in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R that is not in Npsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘N^{p}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Using a construction very similar to the one used in the proof of LemmaÂ 1, one may build, for any integer nğ‘›nitalic_n, a preferential model of Nğ‘Nitalic_N, containing a top state that satisfies pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, for any nğ‘›nitalic_n, pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is consistent for Rğ‘…Ritalic_R.

Remember that a<bğ‘ğ‘a<bitalic_a < italic_b is the assertion aâˆ¨bğ‘ğ‘a\vee bitalic_a âˆ¨ italic_b Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢bğ‘\neg bÂ¬ italic_b. We shall write a<bğ‘ğ‘a<bitalic_a < italic_b to mean that aâˆ¨bğ‘ğ‘a\vee bitalic_a âˆ¨ italic_b Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢bğ‘\neg bÂ¬ italic_b is in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. If follows from results of SectionÂ 3.6 that, on formulas that are consistent for Rğ‘…Ritalic_R, the relation <<< is a strict modular ordering. Notice, also, that, for any nğ‘›nitalic_n, the assertion pn+2<pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›2subscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n+2}<p_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT belongs to Npsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘N^{p}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, since both pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ pn+2subscriptğ‘ğ‘›2p_{n+2}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pn+2subscriptğ‘ğ‘›2p_{n+2}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›\neg p_{n}Â¬ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are in Npsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘N^{p}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore pn+2<pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›2subscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n+2}<p_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. There are, in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R, two infinite (in both directions) chains (for <<<), one containing the variables of odd index, the other one containing those of even index. Since <<< is modular, we may consider only four cases:

  1. 1.

    For every even nğ‘›nitalic_n and odd kğ‘˜kitalic_k, pn>pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{n}>p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let fğ‘“fitalic_f be the renaming of â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L given by fâ¢(m)=m+1ğ‘“ğ‘šğ‘š1f(m)=m+1italic_f ( italic_m ) = italic_m + 1. Clearly fâ¢(N)=Nğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘f(N)=Nitalic_f ( italic_N ) = italic_N. Hence, by Lemma Â 26 we must have fâ¢(R)=Rğ‘“ğ‘…ğ‘…f(R)=Ritalic_f ( italic_R ) = italic_R. But this last statement implies pn>pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{n}>p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for even nğ‘›nitalic_n and odd kğ‘˜kitalic_k, and therefore implies that all pnsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›p_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s are inconsistent for Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. A contradiction.

  2. 2.

    For every even nğ‘›nitalic_n and odd kğ‘˜kitalic_k, pn<pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{n}<p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The argument is exactly as in caseÂ 1, systematically interchanging â€˜oddâ€™ and â€˜evenâ€™.

  3. 3.

    There is an odd kğ‘˜kitalic_k ,and there are even mğ‘šmitalic_m and nğ‘›nitalic_n such that pn<pk<pmsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘šp_{n}<p_{k}<p_{m}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In this case, define a renaming fğ‘“fitalic_f by fâ¢(l)=lğ‘“ğ‘™ğ‘™f(l)=litalic_f ( italic_l ) = italic_l for odd lğ‘™litalic_l and fâ¢(l)=l+mâˆ’nğ‘“ğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘šğ‘›f(l)=l+m-nitalic_f ( italic_l ) = italic_l + italic_m - italic_n for even lğ‘™litalic_l. The contradiction is as above by noting that fğ‘“fitalic_f transforms pn<pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{n}<p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into pm<pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{m}<p_{k}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  4. 4.

    None of the above is true. In such a case one may see that there must exist an even mğ‘šmitalic_m ,and odd iğ‘–iitalic_i and jğ‘—jitalic_j such that pi<pm<pjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—p_{i}<p_{m}<p_{j}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The argument is exactly as in caseÂ 3, systematically interchanging â€˜oddâ€™ and â€˜evenâ€™.

â€†Â â€†

5.5 Global properties of the operation of rational closure

First, we show that rational closure possesses a loop property analogous to the property discussed inÂ [17, Section 4]. This is a powerful property that one is happy to have.

Lemma 28 (Loop property)

Let Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for i=0,â€¦,nâˆ’1ğ‘–0normal-â€¦ğ‘›1i=0,\ldots,n-1italic_i = 0 , â€¦ , italic_n - 1 be knowledge bases such that, for any iğ‘–iitalic_i, Ki+1âŠ†KiÂ¯subscriptğ¾ğ‘–1normal-Â¯subscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i+1}\subseteq\overline{K_{i}}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, where addition is understood modulo nğ‘›nitalic_n. Then for any i,jğ‘–ğ‘—i,jitalic_i , italic_j, one has KiÂ¯=KjÂ¯normal-Â¯subscriptğ¾ğ‘–normal-Â¯subscriptğ¾ğ‘—\overline{K_{i}}=\overline{K_{j}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG.

Proof: Let Kâª¯Kâ€²precedes-or-equalsğ¾superscriptğ¾â€²K\preceq K^{\prime}italic_K âª¯ italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT mean that either Kâ‰ºKâ€²precedesğ¾superscriptğ¾â€²K\prec K^{\prime}italic_K â‰º italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or K=Kâ€²ğ¾superscriptğ¾â€²K=K^{\prime}italic_K = italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Since KiÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ¾ğ‘–\overline{K_{i}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG is a rational extension of Ki+1subscriptğ¾ğ‘–1K_{i+1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have Ki+1Â¯âª¯KiÂ¯precedes-or-equalsÂ¯subscriptğ¾ğ‘–1Â¯subscriptğ¾ğ‘–\overline{K_{i+1}}\preceq\overline{K_{i}}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âª¯ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, for all iğ‘–iitalic_iâ€™s (modulo nğ‘›nitalic_n). We conclude that the rational closures of all the ğŠisubscriptğŠğ‘–{\bf K}_{i}bold_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s are equal. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

The following property of reciprocity is the special case n=2ğ‘›2n=2italic_n = 2.

Corollary 4

If XâŠ†YÂ¯ğ‘‹normal-Â¯ğ‘ŒX\subseteq\overline{Y}italic_X âŠ† overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG and YâŠ†XÂ¯ğ‘Œnormal-Â¯ğ‘‹Y\subseteq\overline{X}italic_Y âŠ† overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_X end_ARG, then XÂ¯=YÂ¯normal-Â¯ğ‘‹normal-Â¯ğ‘Œ\overline{X}=\overline{Y}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_X end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG.

The following property of cumulativity is equivalent to reciprocity in the presence of inclusion (i.e., KâŠ†KÂ¯ğ¾Â¯ğ¾K\subseteq\overline{K}italic_K âŠ† overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_K end_ARG).

Corollary 5

If XâŠ†YâŠ†XÂ¯ğ‘‹ğ‘Œnormal-Â¯ğ‘‹X\subseteq Y\subseteq\overline{X}italic_X âŠ† italic_Y âŠ† overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_X end_ARG then XÂ¯=YÂ¯normal-Â¯ğ‘‹normal-Â¯ğ‘Œ\overline{X}=\overline{Y}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_X end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Y end_ARG.

The meaning of CorollaryÂ 5 is that one may add to a knowledge base anything that is in its rational closure without changing this closure. We may now show that, in two different respects, rational closure is close to being perfect.

Lemma 29

The consequence relation ğŠÂ¯normal-Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG, if it exists, contains an assertion of the form true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± only if this assertion is in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof: Suppose an assertion of the form above is in ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG. We shall show that it must be in any rational extension of KÂ and will conclude by TheoremÂ 6. Suppose Kâ€²superscriptğ¾â€²K^{\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a rational extension of KÂ and true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is in ğŠÂ¯âˆ’Kâ€²Â¯ğŠsuperscriptğ¾â€²\overline{\bf K}-K^{\prime}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG - italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Since ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARGâ‰ºKâ€²precedesabsentsuperscriptğ¾â€²\prec K^{\prime}â‰º italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we know there is an assertion Î³â¢Â âˆ¼Î´similar-toğ›¾Â ğ›¿\gamma\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\deltaitalic_Î³ âˆ¼ italic_Î´ in Kâ€²âˆ’ğŠÂ¯superscriptğ¾â€²Â¯ğŠK^{\prime}-\overline{\bf K}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG such that Î³<ğ›¾absent\gamma<italic_Î³ < true in Kâ€²superscriptğ¾â€²K^{\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. But this means true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false is in Kâ€²superscriptğ¾â€²K^{\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and contradicts the fact that true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is not in Kâ€²superscriptğ¾â€²K^{\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Lemma 30

The consequence relation ğŠÂ¯normal-Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG, if it exists, contains an assertion of the form Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false only if this assertion is in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof: Let Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V and Tğ‘‡Titalic_T be preferential models defining the relations ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARGÂ and ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTÂ respectively. Such models exist by TheoremÂ 1. Let Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U be the model obtained by putting Tğ‘‡Titalic_T on top of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V, i.e., every state of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V is less than every state of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. One easily sees that Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U satisfies the smoothness property and is therefore a preferential model. It defines a preferential relation Sğ‘†Sitalic_S. An assertion of the form Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false is in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S only if it is in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, since Tğ‘‡Titalic_T is a submodel of Uğ‘ˆUitalic_U. If Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is not inconsistent in ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARGâ€‰ then for any Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S iff it is in ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG. By LemmaÂ 18, there is a rational extension Rğ‘…Ritalic_R of Sğ‘†Sitalic_S with the same set of inconsistent formulas. If one looks at the construction described in the proof of this lemma, one sees that it will add to Sğ‘†Sitalic_S only assertions with antecedent inconsistent in ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG. Therefore, if Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is not inconsistent in ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG, for any Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R iff it is in ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG. Now, Rğ‘…Ritalic_R is a rational extension of K. If Rğ‘…Ritalic_R is equal to ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG, we are through. Suppose not. Then we have ğŠÂ¯â‰ºRprecedesÂ¯ğŠğ‘…\overline{\bf K}\prec RoverÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG â‰º italic_R. Suppose now that Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false is in ğŠÂ¯âˆ’RÂ¯ğŠğ‘…\overline{\bf K}-RoverÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG - italic_R. There must be an assertion Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´Â in Râˆ’ğŠÂ¯ğ‘…Â¯ğŠR-\overline{\bf K}italic_R - overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG such that Î³<Î±ğ›¾ğ›¼\gamma<\alphaitalic_Î³ < italic_Î± in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. But Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´Â in Râˆ’ğŠÂ¯ğ‘…Â¯ğŠR-\overline{\bf K}italic_R - overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG implies that Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false is in ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARGÂ and Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´Â is in ğŠÂ¯Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG. A contradiction. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

5.6 Admissible knowledge bases and their rational closure

In this section, we show that an admissible (see DefinitionÂ 11) knowledge base has a rational closure and that this rational closure may be defined in terms of the ranks of the formulas, as defined in SectionÂ 2.6. This provides a useful and elegant characterization of the rational closure of an admissible knowledge base.

Theorem 7

Let KÂ be an admissible conditional knowledge base. The rational closure ğŠÂ¯normal-Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARGÂ of KÂ exists and is the set Sğ‘†Sitalic_S of all assertions Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â such that either

  1. 1.

    the rank of Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is strictly less than the rank of Î±âˆ§Â¬â¢Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î² (this includes the case Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â has a rank and Î±âˆ§Â¬â¢Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î² has none), or

  2. 2.

    Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â has no rank (In this case Î±âˆ§Â¬â¢Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î² has no rank either).

Proof: Suppose indeed that every formula consistent with ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTÂ has a rank. We have many things to check. First let us prove that Sğ‘†Sitalic_S contains K. If Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is in KÂ and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â has rank Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, then CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â and entails true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î±â†’Î²â†’ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\rightarrow\betaitalic_Î± â†’ italic_Î². Therefore Î±âˆ§Â¬â¢Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î² is exceptional for CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and has rank strictly larger than Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„.

We should now check that Sğ‘†Sitalic_S is rational. For Left Logical Equivalence, Right Weakening and Reflexivity the proof is easy. For Cautious Monotonicity, notice that if Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, then Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â and Î±âˆ§Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² have the same rank. For And and Or, notice that the rank of a disjunction is the smaller of the ranks of its components. For Rational Monotonicity, notice that if Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â¬â¢Î²similar-toğ›¼Â ğ›½\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î² is not in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, then Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â and Î±âˆ§Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² have the same rank.

We must now check that if Rğ‘…Ritalic_R is a rational extension of KÂ that is different from Sğ‘†Sitalic_S then Sâ‰ºRprecedesğ‘†ğ‘…S\prec Ritalic_S â‰º italic_R. Let Rğ‘…Ritalic_R be such an extension. We shall first show that Sğ‘†Sitalic_S and Rğ‘…Ritalic_R must agree on all assertions whose antecedents have no rank (the notion of rank is always defined by reference to K). Indeed, by construction, any such assertion is in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, and it is preferentially entailed by KÂ since KÂ is admissible. It is therefore in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. We conclude that Sğ‘†Sitalic_S and Rğ‘…Ritalic_R must differ for some assertion that has rank. Let Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ be the smallest rank at which Sğ‘†Sitalic_S and Rğ‘…Ritalic_R differ, i.e., the smallest rank of an Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â such that there is a Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â such that Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Î²âˆˆ(Sâˆ’R)âˆª(Râˆ’S)similar-toğ›¼Â ğ›½ğ‘†ğ‘…ğ‘…ğ‘†\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\beta\in(S-R)\cup(R-S)italic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î² âˆˆ ( italic_S - italic_R ) âˆª ( italic_R - italic_S ). We have two cases to consider, either there is a formula Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â of rank greater or equal to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ such that, for all formulas Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â of rank greater or equal to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, Î±â‰¤Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\leq\betaitalic_Î± â‰¤ italic_Î² in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R, or there is no such formula.

Suppose there is such an Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. Our first claim is that, for any Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â of rank greater than Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, the assertion Î±<Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha<\betaitalic_Î± < italic_Î² is in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. Consider indeed a ranked model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W that defines Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. Let Wâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²â€²W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the supermodel obtained from Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W by adding to Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, at each level lğ‘™litalic_l a state labeled with world wğ‘¤witalic_w for all worlds wğ‘¤witalic_w that label a state of rank less than lğ‘™litalic_l in Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W. It is clear that Wâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²â€²W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is ranked and defines the same relation as Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, and, in Wâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²â€²W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, every label that appears at some level lğ‘™litalic_l also appears at all greater levels. Let Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the submodel of Wâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²â€²W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that contains all those states of level (rank in Wâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²â€²W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) greater or equal to the minimal level lğ‘™litalic_l at which some state satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. It clearly satisfies the smoothness property (for this we needed to go through the construction of Wâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²â€²W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). Since a formula is satisfied in Wâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²â€²W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT at some level less than lğ‘™litalic_l iff it is of rank less than Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, no antecedent of an assertion of CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is satisfied at any level less than lğ‘™litalic_l. But Wâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²â€²W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a model of KÂ and therefore Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a model of CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. But CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT preferentially entails true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î²ğ›½\neg\betaÂ¬ italic_Î². The model Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT therefore satisfies true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î²ğ›½\neg\betaÂ¬ italic_Î² but not true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î±ğ›¼\neg\alphaÂ¬ italic_Î±. It therefore also satisfies Î±<Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha<\betaitalic_Î± < italic_Î². But the antecedent of this last assertion has rank greater or equal to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, and therefore no state of Wâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²â€²W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that is not in Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies it. Therefore Î±<Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha<\betaitalic_Î± < italic_Î² is satisfied by Wâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²â€²W^{\prime\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and is an element of Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. satisfies Our second claim is that there is an assertion Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´Â in Râˆ’Sğ‘…ğ‘†R-Sitalic_R - italic_S, such that Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â is of rank Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ and Î³â‰¤Î±ğ›¾ğ›¼\gamma\leq\alphaitalic_Î³ â‰¤ italic_Î± in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. We consider two cases.

  1. 1.

    There is an assertion Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·Â in Sâˆ’Rğ‘†ğ‘…S-Ritalic_S - italic_R with Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ of rank Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. But Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·Â is not in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R, and therefore we must have Î±<Î¾ğ›¼ğœ‰\alpha<\xiitalic_Î± < italic_Î¾ for Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. The assertion Î±<Î¾ğ›¼ğœ‰\alpha<\xiitalic_Î± < italic_Î¾ is a suitable Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´.

  2. 2.

    There is an assertion Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·Â in Râˆ’Sğ‘…ğ‘†R-Sitalic_R - italic_S with Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ of rank Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. If Î¾â‰¤Î±ğœ‰ğ›¼\xi\leq\alphaitalic_Î¾ â‰¤ italic_Î± in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R, then Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·Â is a suitable Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´. Suppose, then, that Î±<Î¾ğ›¼ğœ‰\alpha<\xiitalic_Î± < italic_Î¾ in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. We may now conclude that Sâ‰ºRprecedesğ‘†ğ‘…S\prec Ritalic_S â‰º italic_R. The assertion Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´Â fulfills the requirements of ConditionÂ 1 of DefinitionÂ 20, since Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â has rank Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. For ConditionÂ 2, suppose Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·Â is in Sâˆ’Rğ‘†ğ‘…S-Ritalic_S - italic_R, then Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ must be of rank greater or equal to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ and Î¾âˆ§Â¬â¢Î·ğœ‰ğœ‚\xi\wedge\neg\etaitalic_Î¾ âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î· is of rank greater than Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. By our first remark we conclude that Î±<Î¾âˆ§Â¬â¢Î·ğ›¼ğœ‰ğœ‚\alpha<\xi\wedge\neg\etaitalic_Î± < italic_Î¾ âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î· for Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. It is a matter of elementary properties of rational relations to check that if Î±<Î¾âˆ§Â¬â¢Î·ğ›¼ğœ‰ğœ‚\alpha<\xi\wedge\neg\etaitalic_Î± < italic_Î¾ âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î· is in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R, but Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·Â is not, then Î±<Î¾ğ›¼ğœ‰\alpha<\xiitalic_Î± < italic_Î¾ for Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. Since Î³â‰¤Î±ğ›¾ğ›¼\gamma\leq\alphaitalic_Î³ â‰¤ italic_Î± in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R, we conclude that Î³<Î¾ğ›¾ğœ‰\gamma<\xiitalic_Î³ < italic_Î¾ for Rğ‘…Ritalic_R.

Suppose now that there is no such Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. Take any formula Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³Â of rank Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. There is a formula Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´Â of rank greater or equal to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ such that Î´<Î³ğ›¿ğ›¾\delta<\gammaitalic_Î´ < italic_Î³ for Rğ‘…Ritalic_R. But this assertion is then in Râˆ’Sğ‘…ğ‘†R-Sitalic_R - italic_S. It satisfies ConditionÂ 1 of DefinitionÂ 20, since its antecedent has rank Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. Suppose now Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï† Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸Â is in Sâˆ’Rğ‘†ğ‘…S-Ritalic_S - italic_R. Then Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï† is of rank at least Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. If it is of rank Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, there is a formula Ï€ğœ‹\piitalic_Ï€ of rank at least Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ such that Ï€<Ï†ğœ‹ğœ‘\pi<\varphiitalic_Ï€ < italic_Ï† is in Rğ‘…Ritalic_R, but not in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S and this provides the witness requested by ConditionÂ 2. If it is of rank greater than Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, then the assertion Î´<Î³ğ›¿ğ›¾\delta<\gammaitalic_Î´ < italic_Î³ defined just above will do. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

5.7 A model-theoretic description of rational closure

We shall describe here a model-theoretic construction that transforms a preferential model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W into a ranked model Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by letting all states of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W sink as low as they can respecting the order of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, i.e., ranks the states of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W by their height in Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W. We shall show that, under certain conditions, the model Wâ€²superscriptğ‘Šâ€²W^{\prime}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT defines the rational closure of the relation defined by Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W. This construction is clearly interesting only when the model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is well-founded. We know that, in this case, the relation defined by Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W indeed possesses a rational closure (TheoremÂ 7 and LemmaÂ 7). It would have been pleasant to be able to prove the validity of such a construction on an arbitrary well-founded preferential model. Unfortunately we are not able to show this in general, but need to suppose, in addition, that the preferential relation defined by Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is well-founded (see DefinitionÂ 8). This is quite a severe restriction, since we have seen at the end of SectionÂ 2.3 that finitely-generated relations on arbitrary languages â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L are not always well-founded. When the language â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is logically finite, we know all preferential relations are well-founded. Given a well-founded preferential relation, the construction may be applied to any of its well-founded models.

Let Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P be a well-founded preferential relation and W=âŸ¨S,l,â‰ºâŸ©ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ‘™precedesW=\langle S,l,\prec\rangleitalic_W = âŸ¨ italic_S , italic_l , â‰º âŸ© any well-founded preferential model that defines Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. We shall define, for any ordinal Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, two sets of states: UÏ„subscriptğ‘ˆğœU_{\tau}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and VÏ„subscriptğ‘‰ğœV_{\tau}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Those sets satisfy, for any Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, UÏ„âŠ†VÏ„âŠ†UÏ„+1subscriptğ‘ˆğœsubscriptğ‘‰ğœsubscriptğ‘ˆğœ1U_{\tau}\subseteq V_{\tau}\subseteq U_{\tau+1}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The set UÏ„subscriptğ‘ˆğœU_{\tau}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains, in addition to the elements of previous Vğ‘‰Vitalic_Vâ€™s, the states that are minimal among those states not previously added. The set VÏ„subscriptğ‘‰ğœV_{\tau}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains, in addition to the states of UÏ„subscriptğ‘ˆğœU_{\tau}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, all states that satisfy only formulas already satisfied by states previously considered.

UÏ„=defâ‹ƒÏ<Ï„VÏsuperscriptdefsubscriptğ‘ˆğœsubscriptğœŒğœsubscriptğ‘‰ğœŒU_{\tau}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\bigcup_{\rho<\tau}{V_{\rho}}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï < italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
âˆª{sâˆˆSâˆ£âˆ€tâˆˆSâ¢suchâ¢thatâ¢tâ‰ºs,thereâ¢isâ¢aâ¢Ï<Ï„â¢suchâ¢thatâ¢tâˆˆVÏ}conditional-setğ‘ ğ‘†formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘¡ğ‘†suchthatğ‘¡precedesğ‘ thereisağœŒğœsuchthatğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‰ğœŒ\cup\{s\in S\mid\forall t\in S{\rm\ such\ that\ }t\prec s,{\rm there\ is\ a\ }\rho<\tau{\rm\ such\ that\ }t\in V_{\rho}\}âˆª { italic_s âˆˆ italic_S âˆ£ âˆ€ italic_t âˆˆ italic_S roman_such roman_that italic_t â‰º italic_s , roman_there roman_is roman_a italic_Ï < italic_Ï„ roman_such roman_that italic_t âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } (19)
VÏ„=def{sâˆˆSâˆ£âˆ€Î±âˆˆâ„’â¢suchâ¢thatâ¢sâ¢Â â‰¡Î±,âˆƒtâˆˆUÏ„â¢suchâ¢thatâ¢tâ¢Â â‰¡Î±}superscriptdefsubscriptğ‘‰ğœconditional-setğ‘ ğ‘†formulae-sequencefor-allğ›¼â„’suchthatğ‘ Â ğ›¼ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ˆğœsuchthatğ‘¡Â ğ›¼V_{\tau}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}\{s\in S\mid\forall\alpha\in{\cal L}{\rm\ such\ that\ }s\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv\alpha,\exists t\in U_{\tau}{\rm\ such\ that\ }t\hskip 2.27621pt\rule[-2.84526pt]{0.28453pt}{11.38109pt}\equiv\alpha\}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_RELOP SUPERSCRIPTOP start_ARG = end_ARG start_ARG roman_def end_ARG end_RELOP { italic_s âˆˆ italic_S âˆ£ âˆ€ italic_Î± âˆˆ caligraphic_L roman_such roman_that italic_s â‰¡ italic_Î± , âˆƒ italic_t âˆˆ italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_such roman_that italic_t â‰¡ italic_Î± } (20)

Since the model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is well-founded, every state sâˆˆSğ‘ ğ‘†s\in Sitalic_s âˆˆ italic_S is in some VÏ„subscriptğ‘‰ğœV_{\tau}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let the height of a state sâˆˆSğ‘ ğ‘†s\in Sitalic_s âˆˆ italic_S (in Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W) be the least ordinal Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ for which sâˆˆVÏ„ğ‘ subscriptğ‘‰ğœs\in V_{\tau}italic_s âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We shall now show that there is a close relationship between the rank of a formula Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â in Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P (see definition following DefinitionÂ 10) and the height in Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W of the states that satisfy Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. For any ordinal Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, we shall denote by WÏ„subscriptğ‘ŠğœW_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the substructure of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W consisting of all states of height larger or equal to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. Notice that, since Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is well-founded, WÏ„subscriptğ‘ŠğœW_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a preferential model. Notice also that all elements of UÏ„âˆ’â‹ƒÏ<Ï„VÏsubscriptğ‘ˆğœsubscriptğœŒğœsubscriptğ‘‰ğœŒU_{\tau}-\bigcup_{\rho<\tau}{V_{\rho}}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï < italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are minimal elements of WÏ„subscriptğ‘ŠğœW_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Lemma 31

Let Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ be an ordinal. Let Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â be a formula of rank at least Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ and Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â be any formula.

  1. 1.

    No state of height less than Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±.

  2. 2.

    The model WÏ„subscriptğ‘ŠğœW_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â iff Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is preferentially entailed by CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In particular, if Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â has no rank, no state in Sğ‘†Sitalic_S satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±.

Proof: It proceeds by simultaneous ordinal induction on Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. Suppose both claims have been proved for all ordinals Ï<Ï„ğœŒğœ\rho<\tauitalic_Ï < italic_Ï„. Let us prove our first claim. Since Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â has rank at least Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, for any ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï, Ï<Ï„ğœŒğœ\rho<\tauitalic_Ï < italic_Ï„, CÏsubscriptğ¶ğœŒC_{\rho}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT preferentially entails true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î±ğ›¼\neg\alphaÂ¬ italic_Î±. By the induction hypothesis (item 2), WÏsubscriptğ‘ŠğœŒW_{\rho}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î±ğ›¼\neg\alphaÂ¬ italic_Î±. Therefore no state of UÏâˆ’â‹ƒÏƒ<ÏVÏƒsubscriptğ‘ˆğœŒsubscriptğœğœŒsubscriptğ‘‰ğœU_{\rho}-\bigcup_{\sigma<\rho}{V_{\sigma}}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ < italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. If there were a state sğ‘ sitalic_s of height Ï<Ï„ğœŒğœ\rho<\tauitalic_Ï < italic_Ï„ satisfying Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, there would be a state tğ‘¡titalic_t of UÏâˆ’â‹ƒÏƒ<ÏVÏƒsubscriptğ‘ˆğœŒsubscriptğœğœŒsubscriptğ‘‰ğœU_{\rho}-\bigcup_{\sigma<\rho}{V_{\sigma}}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ < italic_Ï end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïƒ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfying Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. We conclude that no state of height less than Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±.

For the second claim, by LemmaÂ 5, Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is preferentially entailed by C0subscriptğ¶0C_{0}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (i.e., in Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P, i.e., satisfied by Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W) iff it is preferentially entailed by CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By the first claim, Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is satisfied by Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W iff it is satisfied by WÏ„subscriptğ‘ŠğœW_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Lemma 32

A formula Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â has rank Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ in Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P iff there is a state sâˆˆSğ‘ ğ‘†s\in Sitalic_s âˆˆ italic_S of height Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ that satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â  and there is no such state of height less than Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„.

Proof: We shall prove the only if part. The if part is then obvious. First, remark that if Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ is a preferential relation that contains the assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±âˆ¨\veeâˆ¨Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± , then it contains the assertion true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. This is easily shown by preferential reasoning. Suppose now that Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â has rank Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. LemmaÂ 31 shows that no state of height less than Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. We must show that there is a state of height Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ satisfying Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. Let Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â be any formula of rank larger or equal to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ that is minimal with respect to <<< among those formulas. There is such a formula since the set is not empty (Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is there) and <<< is well-founded. Since Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is not exceptional for CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the assertion true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is not preferentially entailed by CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and therefore the assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±âˆ¨\veeâˆ¨Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is not preferentially entailed by CÏ„subscriptğ¶ğœC_{\tau}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. But Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±âˆ¨\veeâˆ¨Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² has rank Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ and, by LemmaÂ 31, WÏ„subscriptğ‘ŠğœW_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not satisfy Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±âˆ¨\veeâˆ¨Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. There is, therefore, in WÏ„subscriptğ‘ŠğœW_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT a state sğ‘ sitalic_s satisfying Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â such that no state tğ‘¡titalic_t in WÏ„subscriptğ‘ŠğœW_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, tâ‰ºsprecedesğ‘¡ğ‘ t\prec sitalic_t â‰º italic_s, satisfies Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². We shall show that sğ‘ sitalic_s is minimal in WÏ„subscriptğ‘ŠğœW_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and has therefore height Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. Suppose sğ‘ sitalic_s is not minimal in WÏ„subscriptğ‘ŠğœW_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. There would be a state tğ‘¡titalic_t minimal in WÏ„subscriptğ‘ŠğœW_{\tau}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï„ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that tâ‰ºsprecedesğ‘¡ğ‘ t\prec sitalic_t â‰º italic_s. This state tğ‘¡titalic_t has height Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ and, by construction, it satisfies some formula Î²â€²superscriptğ›½â€²\beta^{\prime}italic_Î² start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that is not satisfied at any smaller height. By LemmaÂ 31, Î²â€²superscriptğ›½â€²\beta^{\prime}italic_Î² start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has rank larger or equal to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, and the formula Î²âˆ¨Î²â€²ğ›½superscriptğ›½â€²\beta\vee\beta^{\prime}italic_Î² âˆ¨ italic_Î² start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has rank larger or equal to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„. Since Î²âˆ¨Î²â€²â‰¤Î²ğ›½superscriptğ›½â€²ğ›½\beta\vee\beta^{\prime}\leq\betaitalic_Î² âˆ¨ italic_Î² start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_Î², the minimality of Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â implies that Î²â‰¤Î²âˆ¨Î²â€²ğ›½ğ›½superscriptğ›½â€²\beta\leq\beta\vee\beta^{\prime}italic_Î² â‰¤ italic_Î² âˆ¨ italic_Î² start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In other terms, Î²âˆ¨Î²â€²â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î²ğ›½superscriptğ›½â€²Â âˆ¼Â ğ›½\beta\vee\beta^{\prime}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_Î² âˆ¨ italic_Î² start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¼ italic_Î². But the state tğ‘¡titalic_t, in Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, satisfies Î²â€²superscriptğ›½â€²\beta^{\prime}italic_Î² start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and is minimal among states satisfying Î²âˆ¨Î²â€²ğ›½superscriptğ›½â€²\beta\vee\beta^{\prime}italic_Î² âˆ¨ italic_Î² start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore tğ‘¡titalic_t satisfies Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². A contradiction. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

LemmaÂ 32 shows that, given a well-founded preferential relation (resp. a finite knowledge base), and a well-founded preferential model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W for it (resp. for its preferential closure), one may build a ranked model for its rational closure by ranking the states of Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W by their depth.

5.8 Computing rational closure

We shall now provide an algorithm for deciding whether an assertion is in the rational closure of a finite knowledge base. The notation Eâ¢(C)ğ¸ğ¶E(C)italic_E ( italic_C ) has been defined following DefinitionÂ 10. LemmaÂ 7 and TheoremÂ 7 show that, given a finite knowledge base KÂ and an assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²â€‰ the following algorithm is adequate.

C=ğŠğ¶ğŠC={\bf K}italic_C = bold_K;
while Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is exceptional for Cğ¶Citalic_C and Eâ¢(C)â‰ Cğ¸ğ¶ğ¶E(C)\neq Citalic_E ( italic_C ) â‰  italic_C, C:=Eâ¢(C)assignğ¶ğ¸ğ¶C:=E(C)italic_C := italic_E ( italic_C );
if Î±âˆ§Â¬â¢Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\wedge\neg\betaitalic_Î± âˆ§ Â¬ italic_Î² is exceptional for Cğ¶Citalic_C then answer yes else answer no.

The only thing left for us to implement is checking whether a formula is exceptional for a given finite knowledge base. The next lemma shows this is easily done.

Definition 23

Let ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_AÂ be the conditional assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². The material counterpart of ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_A, denoted by ğ’œ~normal-~ğ’œ\tilde{\cal A}over~ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG, is the formula Î±â†’Î²normal-â†’ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha\rightarrow\betaitalic_Î± â†’ italic_Î², where â†’normal-â†’\rightarrowâ†’, as usual, denotes material implication. If KÂ is a set of assertions, its material counterpart ğŠ~normal-~ğŠ\tilde{\bf K}over~ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG is the set of material counterparts of K.

Lemma 33

Let KÂ be a conditional knowledge base and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â a formula. Then ğŠ~âŠ§Î±modelsnormal-~ğŠğ›¼\tilde{\bf K}\models\alphaover~ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG âŠ§ italic_Î± iff KÂ preferentially entails true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±.

Proof: The if part follows from the fact that any world satisfying ğŠ~~ğŠ\tilde{\bf K}over~ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG and not Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â provides a one state preferential model satisfying KÂ and not satisfying true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. For the only if part suppose ğŠ~âŠ§Î±models~ğŠğ›¼\tilde{\bf K}\models\alphaover~ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG âŠ§ italic_Î±. By compactness, there is a finite subset of ğŠ~~ğŠ\tilde{\bf K}over~ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG that entails Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. By rules S, And and Right Weakening we conclude that KÂ preferentially entails true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Corollary 6

Let KÂ be a conditional knowledge base and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â a formula. The formula Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is exceptional for KÂ iff ğŠ~âŠ§Â¬â¢Î±modelsnormal-~ğŠğ›¼\tilde{\bf K}\models\neg\alphaover~ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG âŠ§ Â¬ italic_Î±.

We see that, if KÂ contains nğ‘›nitalic_n assertions, in the previous algorithm, we may go over the while loop at most Oâ¢(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n)italic_O ( italic_n ) times. Each time we shall have to consider at most n+1ğ‘›1n+1italic_n + 1 formulas and decide whether they are exceptional or not. The whole algorithm needs at most Oâ¢(n2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2O(n^{2})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) such decisions. In the most general case all such decisions are instances of the satisfiability problem for propositional calculus, therefore solvable in non-deterministic polynomial time (in the size of the knowledge base KÂ times the size of the formulas involved). Therefore, even in the most general case, the problem is not much more complex than the satisfiability problem for propositional calculus. These results may be improved if we restrict ourselves to assertions of a restricted type. For example, if the assertions of KÂ are of the Horn type (we mean their material counterpart is a Horn formula), and the assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is of the same type, then, since each decision may be taken in polynomial deterministic time, the whole algorithm runs in deterministic polynomial time. The complexity discussion above is mainly of theoretical interest. The important practical question is: given a fixed large knowledge base, what information, of reasonable size, should be precomputed to allow efficient answers to queries of the type: is an ğ’œğ’œ{\cal A}caligraphic_AÂ in the rational closure? The pre-computation of the different Cnsubscriptğ¶ğ‘›C_{n}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sub-bases would already reduce the exponent of nğ‘›nitalic_n in the complexity of the algorithm by one.

J.Â Dix noticed that the algorithm just presented for computing the rational closure of a finite knowledge base may be used to compute the preferential closure of such a knowledge base, since, by CorollaryÂ 3 and LemmasÂ 7 andÂ 30, the assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is in ğŠpsuperscriptğŠğ‘{\bf K}^{p}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTÂ iff the assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ false is in the rational closure of the knowledge base Kâ€‰âˆª{Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â¬â¢Î²}similar-toğ›¼Â ğ›½\cup\,\{\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\beta\}âˆª { italic_Î± âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î² }.

5.9 A discussion of rational closure

We have so far shown that rational closure provides a mathematically elegant and effective answer to the question of the title that satisfies ThesisÂ 1. It is now time to evaluate whether it provides an answer that matches our intuitions. We shall first present two now classical knowledge bases, describe their rational closure and examine whether they fit our intuitions. Then, we shall discuss the way rational closure treats inheritance of generic properties to abnormal individuals. Finally, we shall try to address the question of whether our formalism is suitable to describe domain knowledge.

Example 2 (Nixon diamond)

Let our knowledge base consist of the following two assertions.

  1. 1.

    republican Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬pacifist

  2. 2.

    quaker Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ pacifist

It is easy to see that none of the assertions of the base is exceptional, but that the formula republicanâˆ§\wedgeâˆ§quaker is exceptional. From this we deduce that neither the assertion republicanâˆ§\wedgeâˆ§quaker Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ pacifist nor the assertion republicanâˆ§\wedgeâˆ§quaker Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬pacifist is in the rational closure. This seems the intuitively correct decision in the presence of contradictory information. In fact, if we know somebody to be both a Quaker and a Republican, we (i.e., rational closure) shall draw about him only conclusions that are logically implied by our information. Rational closure endorses worker âˆ§\wedgeâˆ§ republican Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬pacifist, meaning that, since we have no information on the pacifism of workers, we shall assume that Republican workers behave as Republicans in this respect. We (i.e., rational closure) also endorse pacifist Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬republican, meaning we are ready to use contraposition in many circumstances. We do not have Â¬\negÂ¬pacifist Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ republican, though, and quite rightly, since Republicans may well be a small minority among non-pacifists. We have true Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬ (republican âˆ§\wedgeâˆ§ quaker), meaning we think being both a Republican and a Quaker is exceptional. We endorse republican Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬quaker and quaker Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬republican, that are also intuitively correct conclusions. If we add to our knowledge base the fact that rich people are typically Republicans, we shall deduce that rich people are typically not pacifists, meaning we endorse a restricted form of transitivity. We shall also deduce that Quakers are typically not rich, which is perhaps more debatable. We shall not conclude anything about the pacifism of rich Quakers though, since rich Quakers are exceptional. We shall not conclude anything either concerning rich Quakers that are not Republicans, which is more debatable. If we want to conclude that rich non-Republican Quakers are pacifists, we should add this assertion explicitly to the knowledge base. The addition will not interfere with previously discussed assertions.

Example 3 (Penguin triangle)

Let our knowledge base consist of the following three assertions.

  1. 1.

    penguin Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ bird

  2. 2.

    penguin Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬fly

  3. 3.

    bird Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ fly

The first two assertions are exceptional, the last one is not. It follows that we (i.e., rational closure) endorse the following assertions: fly Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬penguin (a case of contraposition), Â¬\negÂ¬fly Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬bird (another case of contraposition), Â¬\negÂ¬fly Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬penguin (penguins are exceptional, even among non-flying objects), bird Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬penguin (penguins are exceptional birds), Â¬\negÂ¬bird Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬penguin (penguins are exceptional also among non-birds), birdâˆ§\wedgeâˆ§penguin Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬fly (this is an intuitively correct preemption: we prefer specific information to non-specific information), penguinâˆ§\wedgeâˆ§black Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬fly (black penguins donâ€™t fly either, since they are normal penguins), birdâˆ§\wedgeâˆ§green Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ fly (green birds are normal birds).

The following assertions are not endorsed: bâ¢iâ¢râ¢dâˆ§Â¬â¢fâ¢lâ¢ynormal-bnormal-inormal-rnormal-dnormal-fnormal-lnormal-y{\em bird}\wedge\neg{\em fly}normal_b normal_i normal_r normal_d âˆ§ Â¬ normal_f normal_l normal_y Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ penguin (there could be non-flying birds other than penguins), bâ¢iâ¢râ¢dâˆ§Â¬â¢fâ¢lâ¢ynormal-bnormal-inormal-rnormal-dnormal-fnormal-lnormal-y{\em bird}\wedge\neg{\em fly}normal_b normal_i normal_r normal_d âˆ§ Â¬ normal_f normal_l normal_y Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬\negÂ¬penguin (seems intuitively clear), penguin Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ fly (obviously).

A more general reflexion suggests the following. TheoremÂ 7 shows that, in the rational closure, no information about normal cases may be relevant to abnormal cases. It is a very intriguing question whether human beings obey this rule of reasoning or not. A specific example has been discussed by J.Â Pearl in a personal communication. It probably goes back to A.Â Baker. Suppose we know that most Swedes are blond and tall. If we are going to meet Jon, whom we know to be short and to come from Sweden, should we necessarily expect him to be fair? The answer endorsed by rational closure is not necessarily, since short Swedes are exceptional and we have no specific information about such cases. We do not know how people generally handle this and, even if we knew, it is not clear that AI systems should react in exactly the same way: people are, after all, notoriously bad with statistical information. The answer to the question how should people behave in this case, if they were smart and had all the relevant information, depends on the sociobiology of the Swedish population and is not relevant either. There is very solid ground, though, to claim that, in the framework described here, in which a knowledge base contains only positive conditional assertions, the only sensible way to handle this problem is not to expect anything about the color of Jonâ€™s hair. The reason is that, if we ever find out that most short Swedes are blond (or dark, for that matter) it will be easy enough to add this information to our knowledge base. On the contrary, had we chosen to infer that Jon is expected to be blond, and had we found out that half of the short Swedes only are fair, we would not have been able to correct our knowledge base to remove the unwanted inference: adding the fact that most short Swedes are not blond being obviously incorrect.

Since, by looking at a number of examples, we have gathered some experience on the behavior of rational closure, we would like to propose the following strengthening of ThesisÂ 1.

Thesis 2

The set of assertions entailed by any set of assertions KÂ is a rational superset of Â ğŠÂ¯normal-Â¯ğŠ\overline{\bf K}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_K end_ARG.

ThesisÂ 2 means that a reasonable system should endorse any assertion contained in the rational closure, but it may also endorse some additional assertions, as long as it defines a rational relation. The search for natural constructions satisfying ThesisÂ 2, but providing more inheritance than rational closure is open.

The main question that has not been addressed yet is whether conditional knowledge bases are suitable to describe domain knowledge. Undoubtedly much work still has to be done before we may answer this question satisfactorily. We shall only try to express here why we think the answer may well be positive. Representing common sense knowledge is far from trivial in any one of the existing formalisms, such as Circumscription or Default Logic. Indeed to represent any substantive piece of common sense knowledge in one of those formalisms, one needs to be an expert at the mechanics of the formalism used, and they differ greatly from one formalism to the next. Deciding on the different abnormality predicates in Circumscription and the relations between them, or working out the default rules in Default Logic so as to ensure the correct precedence of defaults needs the hand of an expert. In the formalism proposed here, conditional knowledge bases, the treatment is much simpler since abnormality predicates do not appear explicitely and the default information is described in a much poorer language than Default Logic. We rely on the general algorithm for computing rational closure (or some other algorithm that will be found suitable) to deal in a mechanical, uniform and tractable manner with the interactions between different pieces of default information. The fact that our language of assertions is much poorer than other formalisms seems to us to be a great asset.

Nevertheless, it is probable that the size of useful conditional knowledge bases will be very large. Indeed, in our approach, adding new assertions to the knowledge base may solve almost any problem. Two main topics for further research may then be delineated. The first one is to find practical ways to avoid having to look at the whole knowledge base before answering any query. The set of assertions constituting a knowledge base will have to be structured (off-line, once and for all) in such a way that irrelevant assertions do not have to be looked at. The second one is to find lucid and compact descriptions of large conditional knowledge bases. This will involve looking seriously into the question: where does the conditional knowledge come from? Different answers may be appropriate in different domains: it may well be that conditional knowledge is derived from causal knowledge in ways that are different from those in which it is derived from conventions of speech or statistical information.

6 Conclusion

We have presented a mathematically tractable framework for nonmonotonic reasoning that can be proved to possess many pragmatically attractive features. Its computational complexity compares favorably with that of most well-established systems. In many cases the intuitively correct answer is obtained. In others, the answer given and the way it was obtained provide an interesting point of view on the knowledge base. Much more practical experience is needed before one may assess the pragmatic value of the approach. The task of extending the results presented here to first-order languages is not an easy one. First steps towards this goal are described inÂ [20].

7 Acknowledgements

David Makinson suggested importing the thesis CV of conditional logic into the study of nonmonotonic consequence relations, i.e., suggested to consider what is called here rational relations. He conjectured that the corresponding family of models was that of ranked models. He was also instrumental in stressing the importance of studying global properties of nonmonotonic inference operations. Discussions with the following people helped us to disprove hasty conjectures, putting this work in perspective, and improve the presentation of this paper: Johan van Benthem, Michael Freund, Haim Gaifman, Hector Geffner, Matthew Ginsberg, David Israel, Sarit Kraus, John McCarthy and Judea Pearl. Karl Schlechtaâ€™s suggestions and JÃ¼rgen Dixâ€™s remarks on a previous draft have been very useful. Finally, this paper has been fortunate to receive attention and care of a rare quality from two anonymous referees. We want to thank them.

Lemma 34

A formula is consistent iff there is a normal world for it.

The following will be useful in the sequel.

Definition 26

Let Î±,Î²âˆˆSğ›¼ğ›½ğ‘†\alpha,\beta\in Sitalic_Î± , italic_Î² âˆˆ italic_S. Since â„›â„›\cal Rcaligraphic_R is reflexive and transitive, the relation âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼ is an equivalence relation. The equivalence class of a formula Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± will be denoted by Î±Â¯Â¯ğ›¼\overline{\alpha}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG and Eğ¸Eitalic_E will denote the set of equivalence classes of formulas of Sğ‘†Sitalic_S under âˆ¼similar-to\simâˆ¼. This notation should cause no confusion with a similar notation used with a different meaning, in the context of preferential relations, inÂ [17] and in SectionÂ 2.4. By LemmasÂ 35 and 36, the relation <<< is a strict total order on the set Eğ¸Eitalic_E.

Lemma 38

Let Î±,Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha,\betaitalic_Î± , italic_Î² be consistent formulas. If Î²Â¯<Î±Â¯normal-Â¯ğ›½normal-Â¯ğ›¼\overline{\beta}<\overline{\alpha}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG < overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG then Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î±ğ›¼\neg\alphaÂ¬ italic_Î±.

Lemma 39

Let Î±,Î²ğ›¼ğ›½\alpha,\betaitalic_Î± , italic_Î² be consistent formulas. If there is a normal world for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± that satisfies Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², then Î²Â¯â‰¤Î±Â¯normal-Â¯ğ›½normal-Â¯ğ›¼\overline{\beta}\leq\overline{\alpha}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG â‰¤ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG.
