Let Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W be the ranked model âŸ¨V,l,â‰ºâŸ©ğ‘‰ğ‘™precedes\langle V,l,\prec\rangleâŸ¨ italic_V , italic_l , â‰º âŸ©, where VâŠ†ğ’°Ã—Sğ‘‰ğ’°ğ‘†V\subseteq{\cal U}\times Sitalic_V âŠ† caligraphic_U Ã— italic_S is the set of all pairs <m,Î±><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_Î± > such that mğ‘šmitalic_m is a normal world for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, l(<m,Î±>)l(<m,\alpha>)italic_l ( < italic_m , italic_Î± > ) is defined to be mğ‘šmitalic_m and â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º is defined as <m,Î±>â‰º<n,Î²><m,\alpha>\prec<n,\beta>< italic_m , italic_Î± > â‰º < italic_n , italic_Î² > iff Î±Â¯<Î²Â¯Â¯ğ›¼Â¯ğ›½\overline{\alpha}<\overline{\beta}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG < overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG. To show that Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is a ranked model, we must prove that it satisfies the smoothness condition.

Lemma 40

In Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, the state <m,Î±><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_Î± > is minimal in Î²^normal-^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG iff mâŠ§Î²modelsğ‘šğ›½m\models\betaitalic_m âŠ§ italic_Î² and Î²Â¯=Î±Â¯normal-Â¯ğ›½normal-Â¯ğ›¼\overline{\beta}=\overline{\alpha}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG

Proof: First notice that <m,Î±>âˆˆÎ²^<m,\alpha>\in\widehat{\beta}< italic_m , italic_Î± > âˆˆ over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG iff mâŠ§Î²modelsğ‘šğ›½m\models\betaitalic_m âŠ§ italic_Î². For the only if part, suppose that <m,Î±><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_Î± > is minimal in Î²^^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG. The world mğ‘šmitalic_m is normal for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± and satisfies Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². By LemmaÂ 39 we conclude that Î²Â¯â‰¤Î±Â¯Â¯ğ›½Â¯ğ›¼\overline{\beta}\leq\overline{\alpha}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG â‰¤ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG. But, since Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² is consistent, by LemmaÂ 34 there is a normal world nğ‘›nitalic_n for Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². The pair <n,Î²><n,\beta>< italic_n , italic_Î² > is an element of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V that satisfies Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² and, by the minimality of <m,Î±><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_Î± > in Î²^^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG, <n,Î²>âŠ€<m,Î±><n,\beta>\not\prec<m,\alpha>< italic_n , italic_Î² > âŠ€ < italic_m , italic_Î± >, i.e., Î²Â¯â‰®Î±Â¯not-less-thanÂ¯ğ›½Â¯ğ›¼\overline{\beta}\not<\overline{\alpha}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG â‰® overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG, i.e., Î±Â¯â‰¤Î²Â¯Â¯ğ›¼Â¯ğ›½\overline{\alpha}\leq\overline{\beta}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG â‰¤ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG. We conclude Î²Â¯=Î±Â¯Â¯ğ›½Â¯ğ›¼\overline{\beta}=\overline{\alpha}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG. For the if part, suppose that mğ‘šmitalic_m is a normal world for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± that satisfies Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² and that Î²Â¯=Î±Â¯Â¯ğ›½Â¯ğ›¼\overline{\beta}=\overline{\alpha}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG. If nğ‘›nitalic_n is normal for Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ and <n,Î³>â‰º<m,Î±><n,\gamma>\prec<m,\alpha>< italic_n , italic_Î³ > â‰º < italic_m , italic_Î± > then Î³Â¯<Î±Â¯Â¯ğ›¾Â¯ğ›¼\overline{\gamma}<\overline{\alpha}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG < overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG and therefore Î³Â¯<Î²Â¯Â¯ğ›¾Â¯ğ›½\overline{\gamma}<\overline{\beta}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG < overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG. By LemmaÂ 38 Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â¬â¢Î²ğ›½\neg\betaÂ¬ italic_Î² and nğ‘›nitalic_n, which is normal for Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³, cannot satisfy Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². The state <m,Î±><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_Î± > is then minimal in Î²^^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

The following is an immediate corollary of LemmaÂ 40.

Corollary 7

If mğ‘šmitalic_m is a normal world for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± the pair <m,Î±><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_Î± > is a state of Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V and is minimal in Î±^normal-^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG.

Proof: Suppose mğ‘šmitalic_m is normal for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. First, since there is a normal world for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, Î±âˆˆSğ›¼ğ‘†\alpha\in Sitalic_Î± âˆˆ italic_S and the pair <m,Î±><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_Î± > is in Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V. Since mğ‘šmitalic_m is normal for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± it satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

We may now prove that the model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W satisfies the smoothness property and defines the consequence relation Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ .

Lemma 41

Let Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± be a consistent formula. The set Î±^âŠ†Vnormal-^ğ›¼ğ‘‰\widehat{\alpha}\subseteq Vover^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG âŠ† italic_V is smooth.

Proof: Suppose <m,Î²>âˆˆÎ±^<m,\beta>\in\widehat{\alpha}< italic_m , italic_Î² > âˆˆ over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG. Then, mğ‘šmitalic_m is a normal world for Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² that satisfies Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± and, by LemmaÂ 39, Î±Â¯â‰¤Î²Â¯Â¯ğ›¼Â¯ğ›½\overline{\alpha}\leq\overline{\beta}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG â‰¤ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG. If Î±Â¯=Î²Â¯Â¯ğ›¼Â¯ğ›½\overline{\alpha}=\overline{\beta}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG, then, by LemmaÂ 40, <m,Î²><m,\beta>< italic_m , italic_Î² > is minimal in Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG. Otherwise, Î±Â¯<Î²Â¯Â¯ğ›¼Â¯ğ›½\overline{\alpha}<\overline{\beta}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG < overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG. In this case, let nğ‘›nitalic_n be any world normal for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± (there is such a world since Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is consistent). The pair <n,Î±><n,\alpha>< italic_n , italic_Î± > is minimal in Î±^^ğ›¼\widehat{\alpha}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG by LemmaÂ 40 and <n,Î±>â‰º<m,Î²><n,\alpha>\prec<m,\beta>< italic_n , italic_Î± > â‰º < italic_m , italic_Î² >. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Lemma 42

If <m,Î±><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_Î± > is minimal in Î²^normal-^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG, then mğ‘šmitalic_m is normal for Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î².

Proof: Suppose <m,Î±><m,\alpha>< italic_m , italic_Î± > is minimal in Î²^^ğ›½\widehat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG. By LemmaÂ 40 Î±Â¯=Î²Â¯Â¯ğ›¼Â¯ğ›½\overline{\alpha}=\overline{\beta}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG = overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_Î² end_ARG. Therefore Î±â¢â„›â¢Î²ğ›¼â„›ğ›½\alpha\cal R\betaitalic_Î± caligraphic_R italic_Î². But mğ‘šmitalic_m is normal for Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± and satisfies Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², and LemmaÂ 37 implies that mğ‘šmitalic_m is normal for Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î². â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Appendix B Non-standard probabilistic semantics

B.1 Introduction

We shall describe now, in DefinitionÂ 33 another family of probabilistic models, they provide much more direct semantics for nonmonotonic reasoning than Adamsâ€™, at the price of using the language of non-standard (in the sense of A.Â Robinson) probability theory. The purpose of this section is to provide additional evidence in support of ThesisÂ 1. We shall show that rational relations are exactly those that may be defined by non-standard probabilistic models. In other terms, if, given a probability distribution, we decide to accept the assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â iff the conditional probability of Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â given Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is very close to one, then the consequence relation we define is rational. On the other hand, any rational relation may be defined, in such a way, by some probability distribution. The results presented in the appendix are not used in the body of the paper. A different representation theorem for rational relations, also based on TheoremÂ 5, in terms of one-parameter families of standard probabilistic models has been proved recently by K.Â SatohÂ [32]. Results relating the semantics of conditionals and non-Archimedean probabilities seem to have been obtained by R.Â Giles around 1980.

There is a school of thought in Artificial Intelligence, represented in particular byÂ [3, 2], that denies the validity of the logical approach to modeling common-sense reasoning. The alternative suggested is the Bayesian probabilistic approach. Namely, the only way in which we should make sensible inferences from our knowledge Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is by estimating the conditional probability of the required conclusion Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â given our knowledge Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, and then adopting Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â if we are satisfied that this conditional probability is close enough to 1111. We believe that this approach may run into considerable practical difficulties, the choice being between keeping an explicit data base of these many conditional probabilities or estimating them from a small sample. The chief source of difficulty here is that knowing the probability of Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â and Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â tells you very little about the probability of their intersection.

But we shall not argue the matter in detail here. The main purpose of this section is to show that rational knowledge bases may be considered to come from such a probabilistic model, if we let the cut-off point of how close the conditional probability of Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â given Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â has to be before we are ready to adopt Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â as a sensible consequence of Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, approach 1111 as a limit. Namely, Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â is a sensible consequence of Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, iff the conditional probability is infinitesimally close to 1111. In order to have an interesting theory, there must be probabilities that are not standard real numbers, but belong to a richer system of numbers, containing some infinitesimally small numbers.

We shall show that this approach allows one to keep a probabilistic intuition while thinking about common-sense reasoning, namely think about Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î²ğ›¼Â âˆ¼Â ğ›½\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î² as meaning that the conditional probability of Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â given Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â is large, and still defines a well-behaved consequence relation that is not necessarily monotonic. Note that if one considers a standard probabilistic model and accepts Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î²ğ›¼Â âˆ¼Â ğ›½\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î² as satisfied by the model iff the conditional probability Pâ¢râ¢(Î±/Î²)>1âˆ’Ïµğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼ğ›½1italic-ÏµPr(\alpha/\beta)>1-\epsilonitalic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± / italic_Î² ) > 1 - italic_Ïµ, for some choice of a positive Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ one obtains a consequence relation that is not well-behaved. For instance, one may have Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î²ğ›¼Â âˆ¼Â ğ›½\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î² and Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î³ğ›¼Â âˆ¼Â ğ›¾\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\gammaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î³ satisfied by the model, while Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â â¢Î²âˆ§Î³ğ›¼Â âˆ¼Â ğ›½ğ›¾\alpha\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\ \beta\wedge\gammaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î² âˆ§ italic_Î³ is not satisfied. If, on the other one hand, one chooses Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ to be 00, one obtains a well-behaved consequence relation, but this relation is always monotonic, and the entailment defined is classical entailment (read Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Â as material implication). J.Â McCarthy told us he suggested considering non-standard probabilistic models long ago, but, as far as we know, this suggestion has not been systematically pursued.

The structure of this section is as follows: first we shall, briefly, survey the basic notions of non-standard analysis. We shall also introduce non-standard probability spaces. Then we shall introduce non-standard probabilistic models for non-monotonic reasoning, define the consequence relation given by such a model and prove that any consequence relation given by a non-standard probability model is rational. Lastly we shall show that the axioms are complete for this interpretation, i.e., any rational consequence relation can be represented as the consequence relation given by some non-standard probability model, at least in the case the language â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is countable. If â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is not countable, an easy counter-example shows the result does not hold, but we shall not elaborate in this paper.

B.2 Non-Standard Analysis

Non-standard analysis was invented by Abraham Robinson in order to give a rigorous development of analysis in which limiting processes are replaced by behaviour at the infinitesimally small, e.g., the derivative becomes a quotient of the change in the function divided by the change in the argument, when the argument is infinitesimally increased. In this section we shall give a very brief introduction to the basic ideas. The reader interested in a full treatment can consult A.Â Robinsonâ€™sÂ [31] or Keislerâ€™sÂ [16] books on the topic. More advanced topics related to non-standard probability theory are surveyed inÂ [6].

The basic idea of non-standard analysis is to extend the real numbers to a larger ordered field while preserving many of the basic properties of the reals. Therefore, we consider a structure of the form

â„›*=âŸ¨R*,+*,Ã—*,<*,0,1âŸ©superscriptâ„›superscriptğ‘…superscriptsuperscriptsuperscript01{\cal R}^{*}=\langle R^{*},+^{*},\times^{*},<^{*},0,1\ranglecaligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = âŸ¨ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , + start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , Ã— start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , < start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 0 , 1 âŸ©

such that â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an elementary extension of the standard real numbers, namely ğ‘âŠ‚R*ğ‘superscriptğ‘…{\bf R}\subset R^{*}bold_R âŠ‚ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the operations and the order relation of â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTÂ extend those of R and for every first order formula Î¦Î¦\Phiroman_Î¦

â„›*âŠ§Î¦â¢(x1,â€¦,xn)â¢iffâ¢ğ‘âŠ§Î¦â¢(x1,â€¦,xn)modelssuperscriptâ„›Î¦subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›iffğ‘modelsÎ¦subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›\mbox{${\cal R}^{*}$}\models\Phi(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})\ \mbox{iff}\ {\bf R}\models\Phi(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ§ roman_Î¦ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) iff bold_R âŠ§ roman_Î¦ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

for x1,â€¦,xnâˆˆğ‘subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›ğ‘x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\in{\bf R}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ bold_R. Since we would like to consider not only properties of the real numbers, but real valued functions, functions from real valued functions into reals, and so on, we shall consider a richer structure: the superstructure of the real numbers.

Definition 27

The superstructure of the set Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X is Vâˆâ¢(X)=â‹ƒn=0âˆVnsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘‹superscriptsubscriptğ‘›0subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›V_{\infty}(X)=\bigcup_{n=0}^{\infty}V_{n}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) = â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where Vnsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›V_{n}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are defined by induction:

  • â€¢

    V0=Xsubscriptğ‘‰0ğ‘‹V_{0}=Xitalic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_X

  • â€¢

    Vn+1=ğ’«â¢(Vn)âˆªVnsubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›1ğ’«subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘›V_{n+1}={\cal P}(V_{n})\cup V_{n}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = caligraphic_P ( italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆª italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where ğ’«â¢(Y)ğ’«ğ‘Œ{\cal P}(Y)caligraphic_P ( italic_Y ) is the power set of Y.

Note that the superstructure of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X contains all the relations on Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X, all nğ‘›nitalic_n-valued functions from Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X into Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X, etc. In a non-standard model of the real numbers we would like to have a non-standard counterpart to any standard member of the superstructure of the real numbers. Note that the set theoretical relation âˆˆ\inâˆˆ makes sense in the superstructure of Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X. Recall that a formula of the first order language having only âˆˆ\inâˆˆ as a non logical constant is called bounded if is constructed by the usual connectives and bounded Â quantifiers, namely (âˆ€xâˆˆy)for-allğ‘¥ğ‘¦(\forall x\in y)( âˆ€ italic_x âˆˆ italic_y ) and (âˆƒxâˆˆy)ğ‘¥ğ‘¦(\exists x\in y)( âˆƒ italic_x âˆˆ italic_y ) meaning respectively: âˆ€xâ¢ğ‘–ğ‘“â¢xâˆˆyâ¢ğ‘¡â„ğ‘’ğ‘›â¢â€¦for-allğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘¡â„ğ‘’ğ‘›â€¦\forall x\ \mbox{\em if}\ x\in y\ \mbox{\em then}\ldotsâˆ€ italic_x if italic_x âˆˆ italic_y then â€¦ and âˆƒxâ¢xâˆˆyâˆ§â€¦ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘¦â€¦\exists x\ x\in y\wedge\ldotsâˆƒ italic_x italic_x âˆˆ italic_y âˆ§ â€¦.

Definition 28

A non-standard model of analysis is an ordered field â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTthat is a proper extension of the ordered field of the reals, together with a map *{}^{*}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT * end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT from the superstructure of R into the superstructure of â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, such that for every bounded formula Î¦â¢(x1â¢â€¦â¢xn)normal-Î¦subscriptğ‘¥1normal-â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›\Phi(x_{1}\ldots x_{n})roman_Î¦ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â€¦ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ):

Vâˆâ¢(ğ‘)âŠ§Î¦â¢(a1â¢â€¦â¢an)â¢ğ‘–ğ‘“ğ‘“â¢Vâˆâ¢(â„›*)âŠ§Î¦â¢(a1*â¢â€¦â¢an*)â¢(ğ‹ğğ¢ğ›ğ§ğ¢ğ³â¢ğğ«ğ¢ğ§ğœğ¢ğ©ğ¥ğ)modelssubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘Î¦subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘“ğ‘“subscriptğ‘‰superscriptâ„›modelsÎ¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‹ğğ¢ğ›ğ§ğ¢ğ³ğğ«ğ¢ğ§ğœğ¢ğ©ğ¥ğV_{\infty}({\bf R})\models\Phi(a_{1}\ldots a_{n})\ \mbox{iff}\ V_{\infty}(\mbox{${\cal R}^{*}$})\models\Phi(a_{1}^{*}\ldots a_{n}^{*})\ {\bf(Leibniz\ Principle)}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ) âŠ§ roman_Î¦ ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â€¦ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) iff italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âŠ§ roman_Î¦ ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€¦ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( bold_Leibniz bold_Principle )

and such that for xâˆˆğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘x\in{\bf R}italic_x âˆˆ bold_R x*=xsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¥x^{*}=xitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x (we assume that *{}^{*}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT * end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT transforms the standard operations of R into those of â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT).

The Leibniz principle guarantees that the non-standard counterpart of any standard notion (namely its *{}^{*}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT * end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT) preserves many of the properties of the standard object. In particular it is an object of the same kind: for example if A is a set of functions from R to R, then A*superscriptğ´A^{*}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a set of functions from â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT into â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As another example consider the absolute value as a function from R to R. In R it has the property

(âˆ€xâˆˆğ‘)(âˆ£xâˆ£â‰¥0âˆ§(âˆ£xâˆ£=0â†”x=0))\left(\forall x\in{\bf R})(\mid x\mid\geq 0\wedge\left(\mid x\mid=0\leftrightarrow x=0\right)\right)( âˆ€ italic_x âˆˆ bold_R ) ( âˆ£ italic_x âˆ£ â‰¥ 0 âˆ§ ( âˆ£ italic_x âˆ£ = 0 â†” italic_x = 0 ) )

Then by the Leibniz principle

(âˆ€xâˆˆâ„›*)(âˆ£xâˆ£*â‰¥*0âˆ§(âˆ£xâˆ£*=0â†”x=0))(\forall x\in\mbox{${\cal R}^{*}$})\left(\mid x\mid^{*}\geq^{*}0\wedge\left(\mid x\mid^{*}=0\leftrightarrow x=0\right)\right)( âˆ€ italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( âˆ£ italic_x âˆ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 âˆ§ ( âˆ£ italic_x âˆ£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 â†” italic_x = 0 ) )

In fact since the *{}^{*}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT * end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT versions of the standard arithmetic operations and relations (like â‰¤\leqâ‰¤, â‰¥,>,<\geq,>,<â‰¥ , > , <) are so similar to the standard ones (they extend them) we shall simplify the notation by dropping the *{}^{*}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT * end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT, letting the context determine whether we mean the standard operation on R, or its extension to â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The next theorem shows that this is not a formal game:

Theorem 8 (Robinson)

There exists a non-standard model for analysis.

The proof is an application of the compactness theorem. The extension of R, â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, is not unique but nothing in the following arguments depends on the particular choice of the non-standard extension of R. So fix one such extension â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Definition 29
  1. 1.

    xâˆˆâ„›*ğ‘¥superscriptâ„›x\in\mbox{${\cal R}^{*}$}italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, xâ‰ 0ğ‘¥0x\neq 0italic_x â‰  0, is called finite if âˆ£xâˆ£<ydelimited-âˆ£âˆ£ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\mid x\mid<yâˆ£ italic_x âˆ£ < italic_y for some yâˆˆğ‘ğ‘¦ğ‘y\in{\bf R}italic_y âˆˆ bold_R, or, equivalently, if âˆ£xâˆ£<ndelimited-âˆ£âˆ£ğ‘¥ğ‘›\mid x\mid<nâˆ£ italic_x âˆ£ < italic_n for some natural number nğ‘›nitalic_n.

  2. 2.

    xâˆˆâ„›*ğ‘¥superscriptâ„›x\in\mbox{${\cal R}^{*}$}italic_x âˆˆ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is called infinitesimal if for all Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ in R, Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0, âˆ£xâˆ£<Ïµdelimited-âˆ£âˆ£ğ‘¥italic-Ïµ\mid x\mid<\epsilonâˆ£ italic_x âˆ£ < italic_Ïµ. Following our definition 00 is infinitesimal.

  3. 3.

    xâˆˆVâˆâ¢(â„›*)ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘‰superscriptâ„›x\in V_{\infty}(\mbox{${\cal R}^{*}$})italic_x âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is called internal if xâˆˆy*ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦x\in y^{*}italic_x âˆˆ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some yâˆˆVâˆâ¢(ğ‘)ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘y\in V_{\infty}({\bf R})italic_y âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ). The set of internal objects is denoted by Vâˆ*superscriptsubscriptğ‘‰V_{\infty}^{*}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  4. 4.

    xâˆˆVâˆâ¢(â„›*)ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘‰superscriptâ„›x\in V_{\infty}(\mbox{${\cal R}^{*}$})italic_x âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is standard if x=y*ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¦x=y^{*}italic_x = italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some yâˆˆVâˆâ¢(ğ‘)ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘y\in V_{\infty}({\bf R})italic_y âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ).

It follows easily, from the fact that â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a proper extension of R, that there are infinitesimal, as well as infinite, members of â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In fact xğ‘¥xitalic_x is infinitesimal iff 1/x1ğ‘¥1/x1 / italic_x is infinite. If N is the set of natural numbers, one can show that N is a proper subset of ğ*superscriptğ{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and every member of ğ*âˆ’ğsuperscriptğğ{\bf N}^{*}-{\bf N}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_N is called a non-standard natural number.

Lemma 43
  1. 1.

    The sum, product and difference of two infinitesimals is infinitesimal.

  2. 2.

    The product of an infinitesimal and a finite member of â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is infinitesimal.

Theorem 9 (Robinsonâ€™s Overspill Principle)

Let âŸ¨Anâˆ£nâˆˆğâŸ©inner-productsubscriptğ´ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ\langle A_{n}\mid n\in{\bf N}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ italic_n âˆˆ bold_N âŸ© be a sequence of members of Vkâ¢(ğ‘)subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜ğ‘V_{k}({\bf R})italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ) for some kâˆˆğğ‘˜ğk\in{\bf N}italic_k âˆˆ bold_N. Assume also that, for all nâˆˆğğ‘›ğn\in{\bf N}italic_n âˆˆ bold_N, Anâ‰ âˆ…subscriptğ´ğ‘›A_{n}\neq\emptysetitalic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  âˆ… and An+1âŠ†Ansubscriptğ´ğ‘›1subscriptğ´ğ‘›A_{n+1}\subseteq A_{n}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then â‹‚nâˆˆğAn*subscriptğ‘›ğsuperscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘›\bigcap_{n\in{\bf N}}A_{n}^{*}â‹‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n âˆˆ bold_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not empty.

Sketch of proof : Note that a sequence of elements of Vkâ¢(ğ‘)subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜ğ‘V_{k}({\bf R})italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ) can be considered to be a function from N into Vkâ¢(ğ‘)subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜ğ‘V_{k}({\bf R})italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ), and therefore it is a member of Vâˆâ¢(ğ‘)subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘V_{\infty}({\bf R})italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ). Hence âŸ¨Anâˆ£nâˆˆğâŸ©*superscriptinner-productsubscriptğ´ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ\langle A_{n}\mid n\in{\bf N}\rangle^{*}âŸ¨ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ italic_n âˆˆ bold_N âŸ© start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT makes sense and it is a function from ğ*superscriptğ{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT into Vkâ¢(ğ‘)*subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘V_{k}({\bf R})^{*}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Its value at hâˆˆğ*â„superscriptğh\in{\bf N}^{*}italic_h âˆˆ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will be denoted by (A)h*subscriptsuperscriptğ´â„(A)^{*}_{h}( italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that (A)n*=An*subscriptsuperscriptğ´ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘›(A)^{*}_{n}=A_{n}^{*}( italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for nâˆˆğğ‘›ğn\in{\bf N}italic_n âˆˆ bold_N. Let hâˆˆğ*âˆ’ğâ„superscriptğğh\in{\bf N}^{*}-{\bf N}italic_h âˆˆ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_N. One can easily check, using the Leibniz principle, that (A)h*subscriptsuperscriptğ´â„(A)^{*}_{h}( italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not empty and that for nâˆˆğğ‘›ğn\in{\bf N}italic_n âˆˆ bold_N (A)h*âŠ†An*subscriptsuperscriptğ´â„subscriptsuperscriptğ´ğ‘›(A)^{*}_{h}\subseteq A^{*}_{n}( italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, hence â‹‚nâˆˆğAn*subscriptğ‘›ğsuperscriptsubscriptğ´ğ‘›\bigcap_{n\in{\bf N}}A_{n}^{*}â‹‚ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n âˆˆ bold_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is not empty. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

We can now define the notion of non-standard probability space, which is like a standard (finitely additive) probability space, except that the values of the probability function are in â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Definition 30

An â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-probability space is a triple âŸ¨X,â„±,Pâ¢râŸ©ğ‘‹â„±ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿ\langle X,{\cal F},Pr\rangleâŸ¨ italic_X , caligraphic_F , italic_P italic_r âŸ© where X is a non-empty set , â„±â„±\cal Fcaligraphic_F is a Boolean subalgebra of ğ’«â¢(X)ğ’«ğ‘‹{\cal P}(X)caligraphic_P ( italic_X ), (namely Xâˆˆâ„±ğ‘‹â„±X\in\cal Fitalic_X âˆˆ caligraphic_F, âˆ…âˆˆâ„±â„±\emptyset\in\cal Fâˆ… âˆˆ caligraphic_F, and â„±â„±\cal Fcaligraphic_F is closed under finite unions, intersections and differences) and Pâ¢rğ‘ƒğ‘ŸPritalic_P italic_r is a function from â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F into â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that

  1. 1.

    Pâ¢râ¢(A)â‰¥0ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ´0Pr(A)\geq 0italic_P italic_r ( italic_A ) â‰¥ 0 for Aâˆˆâ„±ğ´â„±A\in\cal Fitalic_A âˆˆ caligraphic_F.

  2. 2.

    Pâ¢râ¢(X)=1ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ‘‹1Pr(X)=1italic_P italic_r ( italic_X ) = 1

  3. 3.

    Pâ¢râ¢(AâˆªB)=Pâ¢râ¢(A)+Pâ¢râ¢(B)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ´ğµğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ´ğ‘ƒğ‘ŸğµPr(A\cup B)=Pr(A)+Pr(B)italic_P italic_r ( italic_A âˆª italic_B ) = italic_P italic_r ( italic_A ) + italic_P italic_r ( italic_B ) for A,Bâˆˆâ„±ğ´ğµâ„±A,B\in\cal Fitalic_A , italic_B âˆˆ caligraphic_F, A and B disjoint

Note that many of the notions that are usually associated with probability spaces are immediately generalized to â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-probability space, like independence of â€˜eventsâ€™ (namely sets in â„±â„±\cal Fcaligraphic_F) and conditional probability: if Pâ¢râ¢(A)â‰ 0ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ´0Pr(A)\not=0italic_P italic_r ( italic_A ) â‰  0 then the conditional probability of B given A, is

Pâ¢râ¢(Bâˆ£A)=Pâ¢râ¢(Aâˆ©B)Pâ¢râ¢(A).ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğµğ´ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ´ğµğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ´Pr(B\mid A)=\frac{Pr(A\cap B)}{Pr(A)}.italic_P italic_r ( italic_B âˆ£ italic_A ) = divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_A âˆ© italic_B ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_A ) end_ARG .

See [6] for sophisticated applications of non-standard probability spaces. A useful way of getting â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-probability spaces is by using hyperfinite sets, sets which are considered by â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be finite.

Definition 31

An internal object AâˆˆVâˆ*ğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰A\in V^{*}_{\infty}italic_A âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is called hyperfinite iff there exists a function fâˆˆVâˆ*ğ‘“subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰f\in\mbox{$V^{*}_{\infty}$}italic_f âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and hâˆˆğ*â„superscriptğh\in{\bf N}^{*}italic_h âˆˆ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that f is a 1-1 mapping of h onto A. Note that we follow the usual set theoretical convention by which a natural number is identified with all smaller natural numbers. Of course here we apply this convention also to non-standard natural numbers.

By applying the Leibniz principle we can show that if A is hyperfinite and B is an internal subset of A, then B is hyperfinite. Given an â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-valued function f which is internal, and A an hyperfinite subset of the domain of f, we can naturally define the â€˜sumâ€™ of the values of f on A, âˆ‘xâˆˆA*fâ¢(x)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ´ğ‘“ğ‘¥\sum^{*}_{x\in A}f(x)âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ). âˆ‘*superscript\sum^{*}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTÂ is defined by taking the *{}^{*}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT * end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT of the standard operation of taking the sum of a finite set of real numbers. âˆ‘*superscript\sum^{*}âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTÂ shares many of the properties of its standard counterpart, for example

âˆ‘xâˆˆAâˆªB*â¢fâ¢(x)=âˆ‘xâˆˆA*â¢fâ¢(x)+âˆ‘xâˆˆB*â¢fâ¢(x)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ´ğµğ‘“ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ´ğ‘“ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğµğ‘“ğ‘¥\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{x\in A\cup B}f(x)=\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{x\in A}f(x)+\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{x\in B}f(x)âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ italic_A âˆª italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ) + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x )

for A, B hyperfinite and disjoint. The next definition generalizes the notion of a finite probability space.

Definition 32 (Hyperfinite Probability Space)

Let AâˆˆVâˆ*ğ´subscriptsuperscriptğ‘‰A\in\mbox{$V^{*}_{\infty}$}italic_A âˆˆ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be an hyperfinite set, let f be an internal â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-valued function on A, which is not constantly zero and such that for xâˆˆAğ‘¥ğ´x\in Aitalic_x âˆˆ italic_A fâ¢(x)â‰¥0ğ‘“ğ‘¥0f(x)\geq 0italic_f ( italic_x ) â‰¥ 0. Then the â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-probability space generated by A and f (denoted by Pâ¢R*â¢(A,f)ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘…ğ´ğ‘“PR^{*}(A,f)italic_P italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_f ) ) is âŸ¨A,â„±,Pâ¢râŸ©ğ´â„±ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿ\langle A,{\cal F},Pr\rangleâŸ¨ italic_A , caligraphic_F , italic_P italic_r âŸ© where â„±â„±\cal Fcaligraphic_F is the collection of all internal subsets of A, and Pâ¢rnormal-Pnormal-r{\em Pr}normal_P normal_r is given by

Pâ¢râ¢(B)=âˆ‘*xâˆˆBâ¢fâ¢(x)âˆ‘*xâˆˆAâ¢fâ¢(x)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğµsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğµğ‘“ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ´ğ‘“ğ‘¥Pr(B)=\frac{\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{x\in B}f(x)}{\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{x\in A}f(x)}italic_P italic_r ( italic_B ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x âˆˆ italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_x ) end_ARG

One can verify that under the conditions of DefinitionÂ 32, Pâ¢R*â¢(A,f)ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘…ğ´ğ‘“PR^{*}(A,f)italic_P italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_f ) is a â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-probability space.

B.3 Non-standard Probabilistic Models and Their Consequence Relations

An â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT probabilistic model is an â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-probability measure on some subset â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_MÂ of ğ’°ğ’°{\cal U}caligraphic_U. Of course, we assume that for every formula of our language, Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, the set Î±^^ğ›¼\hat{\mbox{$\alpha$}}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG is measurable, namely it is in â„±â„±\cal Fcaligraphic_F. The probability measure induces a non-standard probability assignment to the formulas of the language by Pâ¢râ¢(Î±)=Pâ¢râ¢(Î±^)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿ^ğ›¼Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})=Pr(\hat{\mbox{$\alpha$}})italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± ) = italic_P italic_r ( over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG ). The â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT probabilistic model â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M is said to be neat if for every formula, Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, if Pâ¢râ¢(Î±)=0ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼0Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})=0italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± ) = 0 then Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is satisfied in no world of â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M.

Definition 33
  1. 1.

    Let â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M be an â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT probabilistic model. The conditional assertion Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² is valid in â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M, â„³âŠ§Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î²modelsâ„³Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î²\mbox{${\cal M}$}\models\mbox{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}}caligraphic_M âŠ§ italic_Î± italic_âˆ¼ italic_Î², if either Pâ¢râ¢(Î±)=0ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼0Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})=0italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± ) = 0 or the conditional probability of Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î² given Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î± is infinitesimally close to 1, i.e., 1âˆ’Pâ¢râ¢(Î²âˆ£Î±)1ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›½ğ›¼1-Pr(\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})1 - italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î² âˆ£ italic_Î± ) is infinitesimal. Note that this is equivalent to saying that Pâ¢râ¢(Î±)=0ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼0Pr(\alpha)=0italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± ) = 0 or Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î²âˆ£Î±)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›½ğ›¼Pr(\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î² âˆ£ italic_Î± ) is infinitesimal.

  2. 2.

    The consequence relation defined by â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M is:

    Kâ¢(â„³)={Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î²âˆ£â„³âŠ§Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î²}ğ¾â„³conditional-setÎ±Â âˆ¼Â Î²modelsâ„³Î±Â âˆ¼Â Î²K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})=\{\mbox{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}}\mid\mbox{${\cal M}$}\models\mbox{\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\beta$}}\}italic_K ( caligraphic_M ) = { italic_Î± italic_âˆ¼ italic_Î² âˆ£ caligraphic_M âŠ§ italic_Î± italic_âˆ¼ italic_Î² }
Theorem 10 (Soundness for Non-standard Probabilistic Models)

For every â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT probabilistic model â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M, K(â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M) is a rational consequence relation.

Proof: Left Logical Equivalence, Right Weakening, and Reflexivity are immediate. And follows from:

Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¡(Î²âˆ§Î³)âˆ£Î±)=Pâ¢râ¢((Â¬â¢Î²âˆ¨Â¬â¢Î³)âˆ£Î±)â‰¤Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î²âˆ£Î±)+Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î³âˆ£Î±)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›½ğ›¾ğ›¼ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›½ğ›¾ğ›¼ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›½ğ›¼ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›¾ğ›¼Pr(\neg(\mbox{$\beta$}\wedge\mbox{$\gamma$})\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})=Pr((\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\vee\neg\mbox{$\gamma$})\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})\leq Pr(\neg\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})+Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ ( italic_Î² âˆ§ italic_Î³ ) âˆ£ italic_Î± ) = italic_P italic_r ( ( Â¬ italic_Î² âˆ¨ Â¬ italic_Î³ ) âˆ£ italic_Î± ) â‰¤ italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î² âˆ£ italic_Î± ) + italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ£ italic_Î± )

and from the fact that the sum of two infinitesimals is infinitesimal. Or is proved by the following manipulation:

Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î³âˆ£Î±âˆ¨Î²)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›¾ğ›¼ğ›½\displaystyle Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$}\vee\mbox{$\beta$})italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ£ italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² ) =\displaystyle== Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î³âˆ§(Î±âˆ¨Î²))Pâ¢râ¢(Î±âˆ¨Î²)â‰¤ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¾ğ›¼ğ›½ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼ğ›½absent\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge(\mbox{$\alpha$}\vee\mbox{$\beta$}))}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$}\vee\mbox{$\beta$})}\leqdivide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ§ ( italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² ) ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² ) end_ARG â‰¤
Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î³âˆ§Î±)Pâ¢râ¢(Î±âˆ¨Î²)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¾ğ›¼ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼ğ›½\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$}\vee\mbox{$\beta$})}divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ§ italic_Î± ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² ) end_ARG +\displaystyle++ Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î³âˆ§Î²)Pâ¢râ¢(Î±âˆ¨Î²)â‰¤ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¾ğ›½ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼ğ›½absent\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$}\vee\mbox{$\beta$})}\leqdivide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ§ italic_Î² ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± âˆ¨ italic_Î² ) end_ARG â‰¤
Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î³âˆ§Î±)Pâ¢râ¢(Î±)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¾ğ›¼ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})}divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ§ italic_Î± ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± ) end_ARG +\displaystyle++ Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î³âˆ§Î²)Pâ¢râ¢(Î²)=Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î³âˆ£Î±)+Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î³âˆ£Î²)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¾ğ›½ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›½ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›¾ğ›¼ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›¾ğ›½\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\beta$})}=Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})+Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\mid\mbox{$\beta$})divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ§ italic_Î² ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î² ) end_ARG = italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ£ italic_Î± ) + italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ£ italic_Î² )

and again using the fact that the sum of two infinitesimals is infinitesimal. We assumed above that Pâ¢râ¢(Î±)>0ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼0Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})>0italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± ) > 0 and Pâ¢râ¢(Î²)>0ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›½0Pr(\mbox{$\beta$})>0italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î² ) > 0. If this fails then the argument is easier. We shall prove Rational Monotonicity by contradiction, so we assume that Î±Â âˆ¼Â â¢Â¬â¢Î²Î±Â âˆ¼Â ğ›½\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\neg\mbox{$\beta$}roman_Î± âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î² is not in K(â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M), and that Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ is in K(â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M). We shall prove that Î±âˆ§Î²Â âˆ¼Â Î³ğ›¼Î²Â âˆ¼Â Î³\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\gamma$}italic_Î± âˆ§ roman_Î² âˆ¼ roman_Î³ is in K(â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M). We can assume that Pâ¢râ¢(Î±âˆ§Î²)>0ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼ğ›½0Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})>0italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² ) > 0 (hence Pâ¢râ¢(Î±)>0ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼0Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})>0italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± ) > 0) otherwise the argument is trivial.

Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î³âˆ£Î±âˆ§Î²)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›¾ğ›¼ğ›½\displaystyle Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ£ italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² ) =\displaystyle== Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î³âˆ§Î±âˆ§Î²)Pâ¢râ¢(Î±âˆ§Î²)=ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¾ğ›¼ğ›½ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼ğ›½absent\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})}=divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ§ italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² ) end_ARG =
Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î³âˆ§Î±âˆ§Î²)Pâ¢râ¢(Î±)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¾ğ›¼ğ›½ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})}divide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ§ italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± ) end_ARG /\displaystyle// Pâ¢râ¢(Î±âˆ§Î²)Pâ¢râ¢(Î±)â‰¤ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼ğ›½ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼absent\displaystyle\frac{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$})}{Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})}\leqdivide start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± ) end_ARG â‰¤

Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î³âˆ£Î±)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›¾ğ›¼\displaystyle Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ£ italic_Î± ) Ã—\displaystyle\timesÃ— 1Pâ¢râ¢(Î²âˆ£Î±)1ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›½ğ›¼\displaystyle\frac{1}{Pr(\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î² âˆ£ italic_Î± ) end_ARG (21)

Since Î±Â âˆ¼Â â¢Â¬â¢Î²Î±Â âˆ¼Â ğ›½\mbox{$\alpha$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\neg\mbox{$\beta$}roman_Î± âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î² is not in Kâ¢(â„³)ğ¾â„³K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})italic_K ( caligraphic_M ) , we get that Pâ¢râ¢(Î²âˆ£Î±)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›½ğ›¼Pr(\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î² âˆ£ italic_Î± ) is not infinitesimal, hence 1Pâ¢râ¢(Î²âˆ£Î±)1ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›½ğ›¼\frac{1}{Pr(\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î² âˆ£ italic_Î± ) end_ARG is finite. By LemmaÂ 43 Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î³âˆ§Î±)Ã—1Pâ¢râ¢(Î²âˆ£Î±)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¾ğ›¼1ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›½ğ›¼Pr(\neg\mbox{$\gamma$}\wedge\mbox{$\alpha$})\times\frac{1}{Pr(\mbox{$\beta$}\mid\mbox{$\alpha$})}italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î³ âˆ§ italic_Î± ) Ã— divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î² âˆ£ italic_Î± ) end_ARG is infinitesimal. Hence by EquationÂ B.3, Î±âˆ§Î²Â âˆ¼Â Î³ğ›¼Î²Â âˆ¼Â Î³\mbox{$\alpha$}\wedge\mbox{$\beta$}\mbox{$\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim$ }\mbox{$\gamma$}italic_Î± âˆ§ roman_Î² âˆ¼ roman_Î³ is in Kâ¢(â„³)ğ¾â„³K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})italic_K ( caligraphic_M ). Cautious Monotonicity now follows easily. Suppose Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Î³similar-toğ›¼Â ğ›¾\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\gammaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ italic_Î³ and Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±Â âˆ¼similar-toÂ absent\>\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\simâˆ¼ Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²Â are both in Kâ¢(â„³)ğ¾â„³K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})italic_K ( caligraphic_M ). If Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â¬â¢Î²similar-toğ›¼Â ğ›½\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î² is not in Kâ¢(â„³)ğ¾â„³K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})italic_K ( caligraphic_M ), we conclude by Rational Monotonicity. If Î±â¢Â âˆ¼Â¬â¢Î²similar-toğ›¼Â ğ›½\alpha\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\neg\betaitalic_Î± âˆ¼ Â¬ italic_Î² is in Kâ¢(â„³)ğ¾â„³K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})italic_K ( caligraphic_M ), we must have Pâ¢râ¢(Î±)=0ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼0Pr(\mbox{$\alpha$})=0italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± ) = 0, since Pâ¢râ¢(Î²âˆ£Î±)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›½ğ›¼Pr(\beta\mid\alpha)italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î² âˆ£ italic_Î± ) and Pâ¢râ¢(Â¬â¢Î²âˆ£Î±)ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿconditionalğ›½ğ›¼Pr(\neg\beta\mid\alpha)italic_P italic_r ( Â¬ italic_Î² âˆ£ italic_Î± ) cannot be both infinitesimally close to 1. Therefore Pâ¢râ¢(Î±âˆ§Î²)=0ğ‘ƒğ‘Ÿğ›¼ğ›½0Pr(\alpha\wedge\beta)=0italic_P italic_r ( italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² ) = 0 and we conclude that Î±âˆ§Î²â¢Â âˆ¼Î³âˆˆKâ¢(â„³)similar-toğ›¼ğ›½Â ğ›¾ğ¾â„³\alpha\wedge\beta\hskip 2.79999pt\rule[-1.13809pt]{0.28453pt}{8.53581pt}\sim\gamma\in K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})italic_Î± âˆ§ italic_Î² âˆ¼ italic_Î³ âˆˆ italic_K ( caligraphic_M ). â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

B.4 Completeness for the Non-Standard Probabilistic Interpretation

Theorem 11

Suppose the language â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L is countable (this assumption cannot be dispensed with) and Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P is a rational consequence relation on â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L. Let â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be any non-standard model of analysis, then there exists an â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-probabilistic neat model â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M such that Kâ¢(â„³)=Kğ¾â„³ğ¾K(\mbox{${\cal M}$})=Kitalic_K ( caligraphic_M ) = italic_K.

Proof: Let W=âŸ¨S,l,â‰ºâŸ©ğ‘Šğ‘†ğ‘™precedesW=\langle S,l,\prec\rangleitalic_W = âŸ¨ italic_S , italic_l , â‰º âŸ©, with ranking function rğ‘Ÿritalic_r, be a countable (i.e., Sğ‘†Sitalic_S is countable) ranked model that defines the consequence relation Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. The model built in the proof of TheoremÂ 5 shows that such models exist. If Sğ‘†Sitalic_S is finite, or even if each level in Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is finite and Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is well-founded, one may simply use the construction described just before LemmaÂ 22, with some arbitrary infinitesimal Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ. In case the model Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is infinitely broad, i.e., has some level containing an infinite number of states, then the construction has to be slightly more sophisticated, but the real difficulty appears when Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is not well-founded, and we have already remarked that there are rational relations that have no well-founded ranked model. Following the proof of LemmaÂ 22 we would like to assign a (non-standard) probability distribution to the states of the model in such a way that the relative probabilty of a level to that of a lower level is infinitesimal, but, for every formula which is satified at a given level, we would like to keep its relative weight within the level non infinitesimal. To each formula we shall assign a positive real number rğ‘Ÿritalic_r such that, if the formula is satisfied at level lğ‘™litalic_l, its relative probability within this level should be at least rğ‘Ÿritalic_r. In order that these requirements not be contradictory, the sum of the rğ‘Ÿritalic_râ€™s so assigned should be at most 1111. Quite arbitrarily, we pick for the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th formula r=1/2i+1ğ‘Ÿ1superscript2ğ‘–1r=1/2^{i+1}italic_r = 1 / 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Now we have to show that we can find a probability assignment satisfying these requirements. We shall define a set Bnsubscriptğµğ‘›B_{n}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of all probability assignments that are good up to rank nğ‘›nitalic_n. An assignment which is good for every nğ‘›nitalic_n will satisfy our requirements. So, we would like to intersect the Bnsubscriptğµğ‘›B_{n}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s. The overspill principle will tell us that this intersection is not empty.

Since Sğ‘†Sitalic_S is countable we may assume that S=ğğ‘†ğS={\bf N}italic_S = bold_N. Since every countable linear ordering may be order embedded into the real numbers, we may assume without loss of generality that the ranking function, rğ‘Ÿritalic_r, is into R. Since â‰ºprecedes\precâ‰º is a partial ordering of N, â‰º*superscriptprecedes\prec^{*}â‰º start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a partial ordering of ğ*superscriptğ{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT which is ranked by the ranking function r*superscriptğ‘Ÿr^{*}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT mapping ğ*superscriptğ{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT into â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

For each formula Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, let AÎ±=(Î±^)*subscriptğ´ğ›¼superscript^ğ›¼A_{\mbox{$\alpha$}}=(\hat{\mbox{$\alpha$}})^{*}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( over^ start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that AÎ±subscriptğ´ğ›¼A_{\mbox{$\alpha$}}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a subset of ğ*superscriptğ{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (but must not be a subset of N). We can now associate a world, ğ’°hsubscriptğ’°â„\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{h}caligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with each hâˆˆğ*â„superscriptğh\in{\bf N}^{*}italic_h âˆˆ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, defined by ğ’°hâŠ§pmodelssubscriptğ’°â„ğ‘\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{h}\models pcaligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ§ italic_p iff hâˆˆApâ„subscriptğ´ğ‘h\in A_{p}italic_h âˆˆ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It is easily checked that, for standard hâ„hitalic_h (i.e., hâˆˆğâ„ğh\in{\bf N}italic_h âˆˆ bold_N), one has ğ’°h=lâ¢(h)subscriptğ’°â„ğ‘™â„\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{h}=l(h)caligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_l ( italic_h ) and that, for arbitrary hâ„hitalic_h, ğ’°hâŠ§Î±modelssubscriptğ’°â„ğ›¼\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{h}\models\mbox{$\alpha$}caligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ§ italic_Î± iff hâˆˆAÎ±â„subscriptğ´ğ›¼h\in A_{\mbox{$\alpha$}}italic_h âˆˆ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Our idea now is to find an hâ„hitalic_h in ğ*superscriptğ{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and an internal function fğ‘“fitalic_f, from hâ„hitalic_h into â„›*superscriptâ„›{\cal R}^{*}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that, if we consider the probability distribution given by the hyperfinite probability space Pâ¢R*â¢(h,f)ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘…â„ğ‘“PR^{*}(h,f)italic_P italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_h , italic_f ) on the set of worlds {ğ’°kâˆ£kâˆˆğ*,k<h}conditional-setsubscriptğ’°ğ‘˜formulae-sequenceğ‘˜superscriptğğ‘˜â„\{\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{k}\mid k\in{\bf N}^{*},k<h\}{ caligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ italic_k âˆˆ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_k < italic_h }, we shall get a probabilistic model whose consequence relation is exactly Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P (recall that we are identifying a member of ğ*superscriptğ{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with the set of smaller members of ğ*superscriptğ{\bf N}^{*}bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). Fix an enumeration âŸ¨Î±nâˆ£nâˆˆğâŸ©inner-productsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ\langle\mbox{$\alpha$}_{n}\mid n\in{\bf N}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ italic_n âˆˆ bold_N âŸ© of all the formulas of our language. For iâˆˆğğ‘–ği\in{\bf N}italic_i âˆˆ bold_N let xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the real number such that the ranking function fğ‘“fitalic_f maps all the states minimal in Î±i^^subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–\hat{\mbox{$\alpha$}_{i}}over^ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG to it.

We are now going to define a sequence of sets of possible approximations to the object we are looking for, namely the appropriate hâˆˆğ*â„superscriptğh\in{\bf N}^{*}italic_h âˆˆ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the appropriate fğ‘“fitalic_f. For nâˆˆğğ‘›ğn\in{\bf N}italic_n âˆˆ bold_N, let Bnsubscriptğµğ‘›B_{n}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the set of all triples of the form (k,Ïµ,f)ğ‘˜italic-Ïµğ‘“(k,\epsilon,f)( italic_k , italic_Ïµ , italic_f ) that have the following properties:

  1. 1.

    kâ‰¥nğ‘˜ğ‘›k\geq nitalic_k â‰¥ italic_n,

  2. 2.

    Ïµâˆˆğ‘italic-Ïµğ‘\epsilon\in{\bf R}italic_Ïµ âˆˆ bold_R, Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0, Ïµâ‰¤1/nitalic-Ïµ1ğ‘›\epsilon\leq 1/nitalic_Ïµ â‰¤ 1 / italic_n,

  3. 3.

    fğ‘“fitalic_f is a function from N into R such that for any sâˆˆğğ‘ ğs\in{\bf N}italic_s âˆˆ bold_N, fâ¢(s)>0ğ‘“ğ‘ 0f(s)>0italic_f ( italic_s ) > 0,

  4. 4.

    for any x,yâˆˆğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘x,y\in{\bf R}italic_x , italic_y âˆˆ bold_R such that x<yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x<yitalic_x < italic_y, if xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y are in the range of the ranking function rğ‘Ÿritalic_r on kğ‘˜kitalic_k, then

    âˆ‘m<k,râ¢(m)=yfâ¢(m)âˆ‘m<k,râ¢(m)=xfâ¢(m)â‰¤Ïµ,subscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ‘šsubscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘šitalic-Ïµ\frac{\sum_{m<k,r(m)=y}f(m)}{\sum_{m<k,r(m)=x}f(m)}\leq\epsilon,divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m < italic_k , italic_r ( italic_m ) = italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_m ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m < italic_k , italic_r ( italic_m ) = italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_m ) end_ARG â‰¤ italic_Ïµ ,
  5. 5.

    for Î±isubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–\mbox{$\alpha$}_{i}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i<kğ‘–ğ‘˜i<kitalic_i < italic_k, if C=Î±i^âˆ©{jâˆ£râ¢(j)=xi}âˆ©{0,â€¦,kâˆ’1}â‰ âˆ…ğ¶^subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–conditional-setğ‘—ğ‘Ÿğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–0â€¦ğ‘˜1C=\hat{\mbox{$\alpha$}_{i}}\cap\{j\mid r(j)=x_{i}\}\cap\{0,\ldots,k-1\}\neq\emptysetitalic_C = over^ start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ© { italic_j âˆ£ italic_r ( italic_j ) = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } âˆ© { 0 , â€¦ , italic_k - 1 } â‰  âˆ…, then

    âˆ‘mâˆˆC,m<kfâ¢(m)âˆ‘m<k,râ¢(m)=xifâ¢(m)â‰¥12i+1subscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘šğ¶ğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘“ğ‘šsubscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘Ÿğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘“ğ‘š1superscript2ğ‘–1\frac{\sum_{m\in C,m<k}f(m)}{\sum_{m<k,r(m)=x_{i}}f(m)}\geq\frac{1}{2^{i+1}}divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m âˆˆ italic_C , italic_m < italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_m ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m < italic_k , italic_r ( italic_m ) = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_m ) end_ARG â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG

It easily follows from the definition of the sequence of sets âŸ¨Bnâˆ£nâˆˆğâŸ©inner-productsubscriptğµğ‘›ğ‘›ğ\langle B_{n}\mid n\in{\bf N}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ italic_n âˆˆ bold_N âŸ© that Bn+1âŠ†Bnsubscriptğµğ‘›1subscriptğµğ‘›B_{n+1}\subseteq B_{n}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for nâˆˆğğ‘›ğn\in{\bf N}italic_n âˆˆ bold_N. One may also verify from itemÂ 4 that, if (k,Ïµ,f)âˆˆBnğ‘˜italic-Ïµğ‘“subscriptğµğ‘›(k,\epsilon,f)\in B_{n}( italic_k , italic_Ïµ , italic_f ) âˆˆ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and if xğ‘¥xitalic_x is in the range of rğ‘Ÿritalic_r on kğ‘˜kitalic_k, then:

âˆ‘m<k,râ¢(m)>xfâ¢(m)âˆ‘m<k,râ¢(m)=xfâ¢(m)â‰¤âˆ‘i=1âˆÏµi=Ïµ1âˆ’Ïµsubscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘šsubscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1superscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµ\frac{\sum_{m<k,r(m)>x}f(m)}{\sum_{m<k,r(m)=x}f(m)}\leq\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}\epsilon^{i}=\frac{\epsilon}{1-\epsilon}divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m < italic_k , italic_r ( italic_m ) > italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_m ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m < italic_k , italic_r ( italic_m ) = italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_m ) end_ARG â‰¤ âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_Ïµ end_ARG (22)
Lemma 44

For any nâˆˆğğ‘›ğn\in{\bf N}italic_n âˆˆ bold_N, Bnâ‰ âˆ…subscriptğµğ‘›B_{n}\neq\emptysetitalic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  âˆ….

Proof: The proof is essentially similar to the remarks preceding the proof of LemmaÂ 22 in SectionÂ 4.3. Let, indeed, Wnsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘›W_{n}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the finite ranked model defined by âŸ¨{0,â€¦,nâˆ’1},â‰º,lâŸ©0â€¦ğ‘›1precedesğ‘™\langle\{0,\ldots,n-1\},\prec,l\rangleâŸ¨ { 0 , â€¦ , italic_n - 1 } , â‰º , italic_l âŸ©. We can easily arrange a probability assignment for it such that the ratio of the probability of each rank and and each smaller rank will be at most 1/n1ğ‘›1/n1 / italic_n. Within the rank we have to satisfy itemÂ 5 in the definition of Bnsubscriptğµğ‘›B_{n}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but we can easily arrange for i<nğ‘–ğ‘›i<nitalic_i < italic_n, that if Î±isubscriptğ›¼ğ‘–\mbox{$\alpha$}_{i}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has a non empty intersection with this rank, then its relative probability within this rank is at least 12i+11superscript2ğ‘–1\frac{1}{2^{i+1}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG. This may be arranged because âˆ‘iâˆˆğ12i+1=1subscriptğ‘–ğ1superscript2ğ‘–11\sum_{i\in{\bf N}}\frac{1}{2^{i+1}}=1âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ bold_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = 1. If we extend this probability assignment to any function from N into R, we see that (n,1n,f)âˆˆBnğ‘›1ğ‘›ğ‘“subscriptğµğ‘›(n,\frac{1}{n},f)\in B_{n}( italic_n , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG , italic_f ) âˆˆ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

Claim 1

Using the Leibniz principle we get:

{mâˆ£mâˆˆğ*,m<h~,ğ’°mâŠ§Î±}âŠ†{mâˆ£mâˆˆğ*,r*â¢(m)â‰¥x}.conditional-setğ‘šformulae-sequenceğ‘šsuperscriptğformulae-sequenceğ‘š~â„modelssubscriptğ’°ğ‘šğ›¼conditional-setğ‘šformulae-sequenceğ‘šsuperscriptğsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¥\{m\mid m\in{\bf N}^{*},m<\mbox{$\tilde{h}$},\mbox{${\cal U}$}_{m}\models\mbox{$\alpha$}\}\subseteq\{m\mid m\in{\bf N}^{*},r^{*}(m)\geq x\}.{ italic_m âˆ£ italic_m âˆˆ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_m < over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG , caligraphic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ§ italic_Î± } âŠ† { italic_m âˆ£ italic_m âˆˆ bold_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) â‰¥ italic_x } .

Let us define now

and

Ï=âˆ‘mâˆˆh~,r*â¢(m)=x*â¢f~â¢(m).ğœŒsubscriptsuperscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘š~â„superscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ‘¥~ğ‘“ğ‘š\rho=\mbox{$\sum^{*}$}_{m\in\mbox{$\tilde{h}$},r^{*}(m)=x}\mbox{$\tilde{f}$}(m).italic_Ï = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m âˆˆ over~ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG , italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) = italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG ( italic_m ) .

For every formula Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ define:

since obviously Ïâ‰¥Î·ğœŒğœ‚\rho\geq\etaitalic_Ï â‰¥ italic_Î·. (end of proof of ClaimÂ 1) â€ƒâ€†Â â€†

We have already noticed that â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_MÂ is a neat model. ClaimÂ 1 shows that it has the desired property. (end of proof of TheoremÂ 11) â€ƒâ€†Â â€†
